1. The present Australia national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag incorrectly proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Broadcasting Act 1942 and the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act 1987, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to clarify and refine the operation of certain provisions in the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act 1987 (the Ownership and Control Act). That Act, which was introduced in the context of the Government's equalisation scheme for providing additional commercial television services in regional areas, replaced the `two station rule' for commercial television prescribed interests with the `60 per cent population reach' rule. It also introduced new multi-channel service (MCS) and cross-media prescribed interest limits, together with associated directorship limits and provisions to grandfather interests or directorships acquired before specified dates. In the case of the cross-media limits, the prescribed date for the provision of grandfathered protection was 28 November 1986, being the date of the announcement by the previous Minister of the Government's intention to introduce new media ownership legislation.

The principal focus of the Bill is the technical operation of the MCS and cross-media grandfathering provisions. I should point out, however, that the amendments in the Bill in relation to the MCS limits and associated grandfathering provisions will have no immediate practical application.

Each of the current approved markets for regional commercial television will be proceeding directly to service area aggregation, rather than additional television services being provided by regional stations within their existing service areas under the MCS option. The MCS limits will therefore have practical operation only in the event that a new approved market is declared (in, say, South Australia or Western Australia) and if MCS permits are then issued in respect of licences within that market.

The technical operation of each of the amendments in this Bill is explained in some detail in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I will provide a brief overview of those amendments which related to the cross-media limits and associated grandfathering provisions in the Ownership and Control Act. The cross-media grandfathering amendments are also mirrored in those provisions in the Bill dealing with the MCS grandfathering rules.
Service Area Aggregation

Perhaps the most important amendments in this Bill are in new sub-sections 27 (6a) and 27 (10) of the Ownership and Control Act (paragraphs 9 (b) and 9 (e) of the Bill). These amendments have the effect of exempting a person who has acquired relevant interests or directorships before 28 November 1986 and who would otherwise contravene the cross-media limits as a consequence of service area aggregation in accordance with the Government's equalisation scheme.

The absence of grandfathered protection to cover these circumstances has been a matter of strong concern within the broadcasting industry. The basis of this concern is that it is inequitable to penalise licensees who were involved in service area aggregation in compliance with Government policy and who had held relevant interests before the new cross-media rules were announced by the previous Minister. The provisions in this Bill recognise that these concerns are legitimate and rectify the unintended consequences of the existing grandfathering provisions.
Licence Consolidation

This Bill also provides for maintenance of grandfathered protection under the cross-media limits where licensees in an approved market elect to have their licences consolidated within a combined service area for the purpose of service area aggregation. The grandfathering provisions of the existing Ownership and Control Act do not take into account the effect of licence consolidation on a person who held grandfathered prescribed interests in one or more of the former licences.

New sub-sections 27 (4a)-(4b) of the Ownership and Control Act (paragraph 9 (b) of the Bill) therefore provide for maintenance of grandfathered protection where a grandfathered person continuously held a prescribed interest in one or more of the former licences between 28 November 1986 and the grant of the new consolidated licence. This will ensure that only a person who had grandfathered protection in respect of a former licence will be able to claim protection in respect of the consolidated licence. At the same time, the provision allows sufficient flexibility in corporate restructuring so as to encourage voluntary licence consolidation in accordance with the planning objectives of the Government's equalisation scheme.
Acquisition of New Interests After the Grandfather Date

The amendment of sub-section 27 (3) of the Ownership and Control Act in paragraph 9 (a) of the Bill confirms that a person will lose grandfathered protection during the period while that person holds any new interests acquired after 28 November 1986, but that the person can regain protection by the subsequent divestment of those interests. During the period while new interests are held, the person will contravene the cross-media interests limit, but will have the benefit of the statutory period of grace provided in the Act (six months, or longer with Australian Broadcasting Tribunal approval) before the contravention becomes an offence.

Paragraph 9 (b) of the Bill also introduces new sub-sections 27 (4a)-(4b) of the Ownership and Control Act. These provisions provide a mechanism for regaining grandfathered protection where new `interests' are attributed to a person through the acquisition of shares by another company in the corporate investment chain. Under the existing provisions of the Ownership and Control Act such a person could regain protection only if that other company were to divest the new shares which it had acquired. That other company may not be grandfathered and may have no incentive to take such action.

The provisions in this Bill allow a person who is indirectly attributed a new interest to regain protection by subsequently reducing to the percentage shareholding interest which was held in the licensee or newspaper company before 28 November 1986. This is subject, however, to an overall requirement that the person is not in any position to exercise greater control of the licensee or newspaper company than before 28 November 1986.
Cross-media Directorships

Clause 6 of the Bill includes a drafting clarification to confirm that the cross-media directorship limits in section 92fad of the Broadcasting Act 1942 do not prohibit the holding of a directorship in a single company holding controlling cross-media interests. Such a prohibition in unnecessary because a non-grandfathered company would contravene the cross-media prescribed interest limits in section 92fab of the Broadcasting Act by holding such interests. More importantly, such a prohibition would prevent a grandfathered company from replacing any of its grandfathered directors on their death or resignation, because each replacement director would then be contravening the cross-media directorship limits.

The existing provisions of the Ownership and Control Act would also not allow a grandfathered person holding more than one directorship within a grandfathered corporate group to be replaced by another single person. Each of the original directorships would need to be filled by separate replacement directors. This is an unnecessary restriction on the replacement of grandfathered directors because no more cross-media control can be exercised by a director of a company holding grandfathered cross-media interests if the person were also to hold other directorships within the same corporate group.

Paragraph 9 (d) of the Bill overcomes this unnecessary restriction by introducing a new sub-section 27 (8a) of the Ownership and Control Act which allows a person who holds a directorship in a grandfathered company also to hold a directorship in any subsidiary of that company without contravening the cross-media directorship limits.
Other Matters

The Bill also includes other minor drafting improvements to provisions in the Ownership and Control Act. For example, clause 5 of the Bill corrects a technical drafting defect in relation to the period within which notices of the acquisition of a prescribed interest in a newspaper must be provided to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal pursuant to section 92fac of the Broadcasting Act. Paragraph 9 (f) of the Bill also introduces a new sub-section 27 (14) of the Ownership and Control Act to ensure that grandfathered protection is maintained where an `old system' commercial radio or television station licence, held under the previous Broadcasting and Television Act, 1942, is converted over to the current Broadcasting Act.

The Ownership and Control Act has facilitated fundamental changes in the patterns of media ownership in Australia. These structural changes have complemented the Government's equalisation policy of providing competitive commercial television services within larger and more viable regional markets. The `fine tuning' amendments in this Bill are designed to ensure that the technical operation of the Ownership and Control Act is more certain and equitable for those persons who held legitimate interests before the new media ownership legislation came into effect.
Financial Impact
There are not expected to be any additional costs to the Commonwealth in the administration of the provisions in this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SEA INSTALLATIONS BILL 1987SEA INSTALLATIONS LEVY BILL 1987SEA INSTALLATIONS (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the following package of legislation: the Sea Installations Bill 1987, the Sea Installations Levy Bill 1987 and the Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987. The Opposition will support this legislation. In recent years there has been an increased interest in the establishment of sea installations, such as floating hotels, along the Australian coastline. Those which may be established within the three-mile territorial sea of Australia are subject to appropriate State and Federal laws. However, those which may be established beyond the three-mile limit, but still within the outer limits of the continental shelf or the Australian fishing zone, would not currently be subject to State or Federal laws, in particular those relating to customs, excise, migration, quarantine, safety, health and pollution control.

SPEECH.PARA: I note in passing that platforms used for petroleum exploration and certain other mineral exploration and exploitation activities are not affected by this legislation as they are already covered by the provisions of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. It is proposed that this legislation come into effect on 15 October. It will initially apply only to the proposed floating hotel to be constructed in the lagoon of the John Brewer Reef some 72 kilometres off Townsville. This hotel, which will cost in excess of $30m, will be a seven-storey, 200-bed hotel and is being constructed by Reef Link Pty Ltd. However, one can expect that there will be further similar developments; indeed, I am aware that there are proposals for the establishment of a similar hotel development on the Fitzroy Reef.

I turn to the provisions in summary of the three Bills. Firstly, the Sea Installations Bill 1987 imposes requirements on proposed developers to obtain permits from the Minister. These may be given subject to terms, conditions and safeguards resulting from appropriate environmental impact considerations and from other matters, such as the necessity to ensure that insurance arrangements are properly in place. Secondly, the Bill makes relevant State laws applicable to the installations. It treats the State laws with exceptions which can be made by legislation, in effect, as if they were laws of the Commonwealth applied per medium of this piece of Commonwealth legislation. Thirdly, the Bill applies a series of relevant Commonwealth laws where no general body of civil or criminal law otherwise exists in relation to the installation concerned. There is a schedule to the legislation which lists some 33 Commonwealth Acts which will now have application. They include a whole range of navigation Acts, air accident Acts, civil aviation Acts, crimes Acts, environment and extradition Acts, taxation Acts, health Acts, postal services Acts, racial and sex discrimination Acts, various telecommunications Acts and the like. Fourthly, the legislation allows the States to be recompensed for their administrative costs where their authorities act to enforce or give specific application to this legislation. Finally, commercial fishing and pearling vessels, navigational and meteorological aids, commercial cargo carriers, wharves and jetties, historic shipwrecks, resource industry fixed structures and mobile units, defence structures, submarine cables and other prescribed structures are specifically exempted from the provisions of the legislation.

The Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill separately imposes the relevant provisions of the Customs Act 1901, the Excise Act 1901, the Quarantine Act 1908 and the Migration Act 1958 to sea installations. The Sea Installations Levy Bill imposes a levy on installations expressed as either a percentage of the market value of the installation or the gross revenue derived from the installation, whichever is the higher. It sets this levy at a maximum of 20 per cent. The aim is to recoup revenue equal to that which would have been paid in State and local government taxes had they been applicable so that the sea installations do not operate at the expense of the mainland economy. The levy money will be used, by and large, to help offset the cost to the states for their administrative costs relating to this legislation and some classes of installations. For instance, scientific and research installations may be exempt from the levy by regulation.

The history of this legislation is such that it was before the Parliament prior to the dissolution of the Parliament for the last election. The legislation was passed in the House of Representatives but had not been dealt with in the Senate. Since then it has been slightly amended-fine-tuned, I suppose would be a more appropriate way to put it-on two specific occasions. Firstly, prior to its reintroduction to the House of Representatives there were some changes made to the legislation. Secondly, amendments were introduced by the Government in the House of Representatives during the debate.

I turn to those amendments. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills raised a number of matters about this legislation when it examined it some months ago. Arising from the comments of the Senate Committee the Government has looked at a number of these matters. It has picked up a number of the concerns which the Senate Committee raised. For instance, the decision to impose the 20 per cent maximum ceiling on the levy arises from the fact that the Committee was concerned about the otherwise open-ended nature of the proposed levy regime. That has been attended to. The Committee expressed concerns over inconsistencies in the power of entry of inspectors without warrants. Again, the legislation has picked that up. Interestingly, there are now some differences between the powers of inspectors as far as sea installations are concerned and the powers of inspectors in relation to fisheries legislation, in particular in relation to warrants under those pieces of legislation. At some stage it may be useful for the Government to look at the different regimes that operate as far as those pieces of legislation are concerned and take some steps to bring a greater degree of uniformity into those matters.

It is also important to note that this legislation-that is to say, the October legislation, if I may described it in those terms-differs from the May legislation in that it extends its coverage to Antarctic waters and to the protection of those areas adjacent to the Heard and Macdonald islands which were previously not encompassed within the provisions of the original legislation. As I have said, the previous legislation excluded the external territories of Heard and Macdonald islands and the Australian Antarctic Territory. The difficulties that led to that initial exclusion having been overcome, and there having been Press reports that Barrier Reef Holdings was looking at establishing an off-shore installation off the coast of Antarctica, have led to this new regime being put in place.

The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposal) Act of 1974 now applies, and a consequential amendment provides that the time limits within which the Minister must finalise an application are subject to, inter alia, whether or not an environmental impact statement is required. Norfolk Island is brought into the consultative regime, and I am glad to see that that has also been included in this revised piece of legislation.

The legislation also provides for more exemptions from its operations than was originally proposed in the May package of Bills. The applications of the criminal law, the jurisdiction of the courts and the issuing of orders and injunctions are spelt out in greater detail and with more precision. In particular, it is made clear that, unless for exceptional reasons, entry to a sea installation must be made from a place within Australian territorial jurisdiction.

As I have said, two amendments were introduced by the Government when the matter was before the House of Representatives. The first relates to the general operation of the exemption clauses provision of the legislation. Whereas in the past in order to get an exemption, if not specially provided for, an application had to be made, the legislation now provides that the Minister may, in advance of any application, grant a series of exemptions from the operations of the levy. This is particularly useful because it will allow the Minister the discretion to exempt scientific and research vessels and installations from the payment of the levy. I was very concerned initially that there was not an adequate mechanism for ensuring that research operations were not subject to an unnecessary levy. I believe that has now been attended to, and it also allows the Antarctic Treaty regime to operate without any interference when one considers that other nations may be involved in terms of what would otherwise be Austraian territorial waters because of the unique international co-operative regime that exists under the Antarctic Treaty.

One curious amendment-the officers may be able to provide the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) with some explanation on this-concerns the newly introduced definition of the word `aircraft'. In the Sea Installations Bill it is proposed that an aircraft means `a machine or apparatus that can derive support in the atmosphere from the reactions from the air or from buoyancy'. That is somewhat different from the definition of the word `aircraft' which appears in the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. There, `aircraft' is designed to include:
(a) any machine that can derive support in the atmosphere from the reactions of the air; and

(b) an object that was designed or adapted for use as an aircraft but is incapable of being so used because-(i) . . . parts have, been removed from it; or (ii) it is in a wrecked or damaged condition;

I think I am correct in understanding that the word `aircraft' has been redefined in order to encompass adequately the airship, as the emergence in recent years of airships back into commercial operations of one sort or another in Australia is such that the term `aircraft', as otherwise understood in Commonwealth law, might not have covered adequately the operations of airships. As a result, if an airship is moored or anchored either on one of the reefs or within the area of sea over which this legislation extends control, or it is in some way associated with some other structure which is operating as a sea installation, the airship itself is also fully encompassed within the provisions of the legislation and, I presume, is therefore subject to the levy arrangements. I would be grateful if it could be confirmed that my understanding of the definition of the term `aircraft' is correct.

I believe that one of the advantages which will derive from this legislation and which to the best of my knowledge has not been the subject of very much debate-in particular attention was not drawn to it by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in his second reading speech, but I am sure it is of particular concern to Senator Gareth Evans, who is the Minister at the table-

TALK.START.PARA: —On the contrary.
—The advantage is that pirate broadcasting--
—Oh, I see.
—I knew that Senator Evans would be interested. Pirate broadcast- ing--
—In the piracy or the broadcasting?

—It is a question of which one he is practised at and which one he is interested in, I suppose. The legislation will operate in such a way that the problems which other countries have encountered with pirate broadcasting can be adequately controlled as far as Australia is concerned. I believe that there has been a gap in this area of the broadcasting regime in Australia. Undoubtedly, there was no positive intention to deal with this problem through the mechanism of the Sea Installations Bill. Nevertheless I believe that the Government has the power to deal adequately with any problems which might arise and we certainly have no objection to that being perhaps one of the unintended consequences of this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Having the operations of this legislation give effect, as it were, to State law per the medium of a piece of Commonwealth legislation is perhaps a slightly unusual way to proceed. The Opposition is not entirely happy with the way in which this operates but, in the absence of any other mechanism which we can see clearly available, we do not press any problem as far as that is concerned. But I would not like the long term development whereby any regime in which the use of Commonwealth legislation to extend the operation of State laws, without specifying precisely which State laws are to be applied, becomes a general rule of thumb.

In this legislation, the 33-odd Commonwealth Acts which are to be given effect to are specified in the schedule. I think there needs to be some fairly precise control mechanism for the way in which State laws will be identified and then applied. One can see a whole series of problems arising from State laws which relate to things such as liquor licences, the regulation of gaming terms and conditions of employment, and workers compensation legislation, which will vary enormously from State to State and which indeed may be extremely controversial pieces of legislation in relation to particular causes or particular times. Again I would be grateful if the Minister, when responding to the debate, would draw our attention to the mechanisms which will be in force or in place for giving effect to State legislation and the proper notification to the Commonwealth Parliament of the legislation which it is proposed to give effect to, using what is in fact a piece of Commonwealth law.

As I said, we have pleasure in supporting this legislation. It is part of the continuing problem which is faced with the development of new legal regimes, which goes back quite a considerable way to the attempt to negotiate a package of legislative arrangements which, around the 1970s, really started to be a major problem in terms of the territorial sea and Australian coastal waters. The old rules, which used to be applicable only within three-mile limits, suddenly became no longer relevant with the development of regimes about the law of the sea and, indeed, the development of a concept of responsibility and control over exclusive fishing zones extending up to 200 miles off the coast. Difficulties which arose in relation to precise definition of high water marks, low water marks, continental shelves and which government had jurisdiction, the various rulings of the High Court of Australia, the constitutional off-shore settlement, which Senator Durack, as the then Attorney-General, put into place-all of these continue from time to time to throw up particular problems which need to be addressed. This package of legislation addresses those problems as they relate to sea installations and, in particular, has been brought forward as a result of the development of one of those pieces of legislation, the one to which I have already referred, concerning the floating hotel adjacent to the city of Townsville. As I said, the Opposition has pleasure in supporting these three pieces of legislation and looks forward to an explanation from the Minister on the two particular matters which I have raised. We are happy to give the Bills speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sea Installations Bill, the Sea Installations Levy Bill and the Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill are important because they deal with a very important area of Australia. The reason for the introduction of the Sea Installations Bill at this time is to give some legislative framework for a new development which is occurring on the Great Barrier Reef. The Great Barrier Reef is the longest and in fact one of the most interesting reefs around Australia. It extends from near the mouth of the Fly River in Papua New Guinea down the coast of Queensland to Lady Elliott Island, which is at a latitude of 24 degrees south. The total length of the reef is about 2,000 kilometres. I suppose to say the `barrier reef', as Matthew Flinders did, is a bit of a misnomer, because it is a collection of islands and reef flats which extend across that area. This has long been recognised as an important ecological area and an important tourist area.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1976 the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park was established. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority was put together under Commonwealth legislation and it is responsible for making recommendations to the Minister on the care and development of the marine park. The Great Barrier Reef region covers 348,700 square kilometres-a massive area. In 1981 the whole region was inscribed on the World Heritage List-I will come back to this later-established under the Convention for the Protection of the World's Cultural and Natural Heritage. This is the highest possible international conservation status. It is also an indication of the value of this area to the rest of the world. Not only is it an honour for Australia to have this award bestowed on the Great Barrier Reef, but also we have a responsibility as a country to defend this area from those who would despoil it. The entire reef region is also included on the Register of the National Estate under the Australian Heritage Commission Act. Part of the region was listed in 1980 and the remainder in 1982. The Convention obliges the Commonwealth Government to ensure that effective measures are taken for the conservation of sections of the World Heritage situated within its territory.

The Federal Government has the ultimate responsibility for and control of the reef region, including the territorial seas, to the low water tide line on the islands. This is a very important point. What is happening to the Great Barrier Reef area? We all know that many of the islands have already been developed-in fact, overdeveloped-for tourism. Tourism is a two-edged sword. On the one hand it can create jobs and local revenue; but on the other hand it often tends, by its very nature, to destroy the very features that the tourists want to come to see.

There is a rather frightening development in the Great Barrier Reef area in that, instead of concentrating on island areas, the developers are now looking off-shore in boats to see the reef. There have been some temporary facilities or bases for people to visit so that they could snorkel and have a look at the reef. But now the new developments-and the developments which prompted this legislation-are the emplacement of huge floating hotel structures; and I mean massive. Such developments are changing the nature of the whole management problem for the reef, because no one really knows what will happen if we moor a huge barge, hundreds of metres long and a hundred metres wide containing 100 or so rooms-which is essentially what it is- over a section of the reef. Certainly there will be some effect on it, but no one knows exactly what it will be.

There are a number of proposals. The first has, I believe, been mentioned by Senator Puplick. It is also the reason for this Bill. I refer to the John Brewer Reef proposal. That proposed development is included in the provisions of the Sea Installations Bill. But there are others which are being mooted and which are not included under this Bill, and it is our concern that they are not given the protection of this Bill. There are two proposals in addition to the John Brewer Reef proposal. I quote from the public notices in the Courier-Mail of 27 April 1987. One notice refers to a proposal to conduct a program including a floating accommodation for 100 persons on Lady Musgrave Island lagoon, and states:

The placing and operating of a floating accommodation complex within Lady Musgrave Island lagoon. Snorkelling, scuba diving, windsurfing, coral viewing, reef walking and bird watching within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, Capricornia section, and the Capricorn-Bunker Marine Park. The zoning of the area is General Use ``B''.

The proposed structure will accommodate 100 overnight guests and 100 day visitors. The dimensions of the proposed structure are approximately 46 metres by 12 metres. The structure will have three decks above water level and will be accompanied by a 20 metre by 8 metre pontoon to be used as a helipad recreation area. The proposed location is 300 metres east-south-east of Lady Musgrave Island.
Another proposal is for a development in Fitzroy Reef lagoon. The notice in respect of that development states:

The floating hotel will be on a base of 100 metres by 38 metres and will accommodate 360 guests. It will be accompanied by a 37 metre square pontoon containing an underwater restaurant and will provide a day-trip destination from other centres. Transport to the facility will be by two 220-passenger catamarans and one 4 passenger helicopter.

That represents a massive use of the reef area and this, too, will not be within the purview of the Sea Installations Bill. We feel that these developments should be subject to the control of this legislation. We strongly believe that the concept of floating tourist hotels is dramatically inconsistent with the purpose and intent of the marine park and that a proliferation of such structures would be an irresponsible breach of Australia's responsibilities towards world heritage of the Great Barrier Reef region. It was initially argued by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority that floating hotels would take the pressure off Barrier Reef islands, many of which have suffered irreparable damage in the name of tourism. However, to date there is no evidence to suggest that this pressure on Barrier Reef islands has decreased. In fact, the apparent prospect of free real estate on the Great Barrier Reef has caused a rash of floating hotel proposals. This is an entirely inappropriate privatisation of the Great Barrier Reef because, after all, it belongs to all the people of the world. What right should a private individual have to take away a world treasure?

At the very least very stringent baseline and monitoring studies should be required at the John Brewer Reef site. This will require several years. In addition, for health and safety reasons, the John Brewer Reef hotel should be required to endure successfully at least one major cyclone because of the obvious liability if a disaster occurred. In other words, when the John Brewer Reef hotel operation is in place we should wait and see what happens; we should see what are the ecological effects, what are the sociological effects and what it does to other tourist ventures in the area. It is really too soon to go ahead with any other developments when this one is so experimental. I understand that this development is fully constructed and is now waiting in Singapore. It is undergoing tests and will soon be brought to Australia. Not only the Australian Democrats have expressed concern over these activities. Peter Milton, a member of the Australian Labor Party in the other place, has also recognised these difficulties. On page 1343 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 22 October 1987, he said:

In common with the Wildlife Preservation Society of Queensland and the Australian Conservation Foundation, I have strong concerns about the potential impact which floating hotels and other structures will have on the Great Barrier Reef. As I mentioned in my previous speech in this House, on 5 May, in relation to the present legislation, the prospect of freehold real estate on the Great Barrier Reef, and the consequent uncontrolled development of both private and tourist facilities, could present a great threat to the fragile environment of the reef. It is vital that stringent monitoring studies should be undertaken of the impact of the John Brewer Reef floating hotel tourist facilities on the Great Barrier Reef as a whole.
Peter Milton has expressed these concerns and I only hope that the Government is listening to its own members. Peter Milton continued:
Another proposal is also in the pipeline for the construction of a $20m floating hotel to be anchored in the Fitzroy Reef Lagoon off Gladstone. This proposal-
as I mentioned in my presentation-

includes a five-storey hotel accommodating 360 beds and includes an underwater restaurant and facilities for day trippers. It seems to me that it is absolutely vital that consideration of this proposal should be deferred until a satisfactory monitoring study of the John Brewer Reef floating hotel has been completed.
So he, too, agrees with our stand that no further developments should be made until the John Brewer Reef situation has been evaluated. Peter Milton continued:

Another problem is the fact that a third proposal for a floating hotel, accommodating 100 overnight guests and 100 day visitors, proposed for the Lady Musgrave Island Lagoon does not come under the provisions of the present Bill, because it is in waters under the control of the Queensland State Government. However, the proposal also comes under the provisions of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and its accompanying regulations. The reef is also part of a World Heritage area, and therefore, Australia has a responsibility to the international community to ensure that the reef is protected from environmental damage, and that includes controls on tourist development.

Once again, a member of the Labor Party in the lower House agrees with our stand and the conservation stand that we should tread very carefully on the Great Barrier Reef because it is indeed a fragile area. Peter Milton also brought up another interesting point. Because of his interest in the Antarctic, he pointed out, as did Senator Puplick, that this legislation has application in the Antarctic. Tourism in the Antarctic is, if anything, even more controversial than tourism on the Great Barrier Reef. The Antarctic in its own way is a fragile environment. There has been some talk recently of tourist developments, perhaps in conjunction with the Antarctic Division, with airstrips being put in at Davis, for instance, into which tourists could fly. I am unable to picture a floating hotel structure in the Antarctic. I think the problems inherent with ice and general life support systems there could make it quite difficult. I would hope that this will never come to pass but, if it does, that too should be treated with great caution.

My own view of tourism in the Antarctic is that it should not be necessary. Often we are told that we must have some economic value in an area in order for it to be saved from other development; in other words, if we can develop a tourism industry in the Antarctic it may be possible to save it from mineral exploitation or oil drilling. I do not accept that argument at all. I feel that if an area has intrinsic value, as do the Antarctic and the Great Barrier Reef, it does not require a tourist development to justify it. Its own existence is justified by the mere fact that it exists. It has a right to exist and we do not have to figure out some economic justification for its existence. Therefore, I reject any moves to introduce tourism in the Antarctic merely to familiarise people with the Antarctic so that perhaps when they go home they will try to save it. I think the Antarctic deserves to be saved in its own right.

We have received a number of inquiries about the Sea Installations Bill, and we were concerned that it might not include the right for the public to seek injunctions in relation to anything that happened in the area that was in contravention of the Bill. We find that the public does have that right and that it is assured. It is based on section 14 (1) of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, and we are quite gratified to find that. We feel that preliminary environmental advice should be incorporated as part of the application for the Minister's information regarding initial permits and variation and renewal of permits, which are dealt with in part III, clauses 20 to 28. I understand that the Government may have some comment on that. We would like ministerial discretion to be widened to allow the Minister to vary the standard 60 day notice requirements in order to allow consultation with the public and interested parties. At all stages in the implementation of this legislation we would like to have full public participation, hearing procedures and routes available for the public to be involved. After all, as I have said before, this is a public resource.

The final thing that we would like to see-and I foreshadow an amendment that I will move in the committee stage-is an extension of the coverage of the Sea Installations Bill to include all of the waters to the level of low tide. At the moment State waters are excluded. We feel that this is absolutely illogical because the World Heritage listing includes all waters to low tide, the National Estate listing includes all waters to low tide, and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority covers all waters to low tide. However, the Sea Installations Bill does not cover these waters, and that is why Lady Musgrave Island will not come under the control of the Sea Installations Bill. I think this is a grievous oversight on the part of the Government. I know that the Government often does not want to pick a fight with State governments, particularly those in the deep north and the deep south, but I think this is one area in which it must grasp the nettle. I do not think it would find all that much opposition to its including all of the waters of the Great Barrier Reef in the areas covered by the Sea Installations Bill. It is not as if there is massive public support for State control of these waters. The only people who would really be disadvantaged would be the white-shoe brigade. It is obvious that they are moving off-shore from their island bases. They will be moving into territorial waters if they find that the laws there are less strict, less environmentally sound, than those applying in Commonwealth waters. Because of this Bill there may be a move to emplace these structures not on the reef, where they can be controlled by this Bill, but in territorial waters. Therefore, we shall be moving in committee amendments to tidy up the boundaries and to make them into one logical whole which will match the boundaries of the other authorities I have mentioned.

That concludes my remarks on the second reading. As I foreshadowed, we shall be introducing amendments. I have not yet had any indication from the Government, or for that matter from the Opposition, as to its thoughts on the amendments. I hope that it supports them because they are logical, necessary and would extend what I believe is a very good and timely piece of legislation to cover all waters of the Barrier Reef. This could only benefit the people of Australia and the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to this debate on the Sea Installations Bill 1987 and allied Bills will be brief, but I wanted to participate in order to point out that the introduction of this legislation is timely. I am aware of the growing interest in this type of tourist venture in the Northern Territory as well as in the places which have been mentioned in this debate and also in the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). I approached my participation in this debate with some degree of trepidation, because I felt, after the last 24 hours of debate on the proposed transport system at Ayers Rock, that if I dared to mention a floating hotel in any context at all, it would probably be blown out of the water. It is a fact that proposals such as this have been made in respect of, for example, Cobourg Peninsula National Park in the Northern Territory, as well as particular areas of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I concur with the contribution made this morning by Senator Sanders in two respects. The first is that in the implementation of this legislation a great deal has been left, as necessarily it must be left, to ministerial discretion in the environmental impact of such proposals. The Minister obviously felt the same degree of sensitivity towards this necessary area as he concentrated to some considerable degree on explaining the purpose of the legislation in his second reading speech. He pointed out that not only are permits required to get the proposals off the ground and into the water in the first place, but also that revocation and review provisions exist in the Bill in case problems arise a little further down the track. I would make the obvious comment that it is far more practical to prevent a proposed venture from going ahead than it is to revoke its permit or close it down after considerable sums have been invested and it is operating. The most careful scrutiny will have to be given to all aspects of these installations, particularly where they impinge on protected national park areas.

Senator Sanders also raised the important perennial question of preservation for its own sake. It is in this regard that Senator Sanders made the second statement with which I concur completely. There is a view in many sections of the community, particularly where I come from, that of necessity national parks and preservation mean tourism and visitation. I go along with Senator Sanders in saying that there are many areas of the world where endangered species of flora, fauna and entire ecosystems must be properly preserved as they have a right to exist, as he said, in their own right without necessarily being subjected to tourist pressure.

That gets me on to a very important area on which I am sure Senator Sanders would agree with me, and that is that without question one of the major management problems around the world of any national park is visitor pressure. It was in that context that the question of the transport system-I find it difficult to get my tongue around the word `monorail' at the moment-at Ayers Rock, the people mover, whatever one wants to call it, was raised. It was raised only in the context of the key question of what provides the lesser damage to an environment. My first reaction was to recoil in horror when it was initially suggested. It intrigued me last night to hear a statement on the national news by a representative of the Wilderness Society who said that he found the proposal bruited in respect of Ayers Rock to be an obscenity. He asked how one could possibly consider introducing that kind of modern technology into a primitive landscape. I agree with those sentiments but I am somewhat bemused that people can look at a proposal for a very safe, quiet transport system with horror and at the same time not consider that there is the slightest problem with 20 miles of brand new, sealed bitumen road with 50 or 60 tourist buses charging up and down it at 100 kilometres an hour. That is not exactly what I would call Stone Age technology.

It is important to raise these issues in this debate, because with this legislation we are entering into the recognition of a brand new form of human intrusion into the ecosystem. I refer to off-shore tourist installations which, because of problems of waste disposal and so on, bring into effect a whole new ball game. Senator Sanders commented on areas such as the Antarctic, and once again I concur with his statements. The Antarctic is in the fortunate position-and few places in the world are in such a fortunate position-of being a fairly pristine area in respect of tourist traffic. Indeed, considering the potential for damage that would exist from tourist intrusion on a wide scale-and I have no hesitation in supporting Senator Sanders on this-it is very desirable indeed to prevent such intrusion where it currently does not exist.

The major problem in the management of national parks in Australia these days is in trying to repair damage and exercise damage control. A classic example is the spectacular rock art that exists in Kakadu National Park. There are 5,000 known rock art galleries; it is the largest repository of indigenous Aboriginal rock art in the world. Spectacular galleries such as Obiri and Nourlangie face obvious tourist pressure. In the past that has been catastrophic, and it is with extraordinary dismay that we view the great need for legislation such as this in the face of actions by some members of the public. One can only stand back in total dismay and disbelief at the damage caused by someone who would go to a rock art site, as someone did at Nourlangie many years ago, cover the entire rock surface where the paintings existed with a combination of what was obviously petroleum and diesel fuel, set fire to it and burn the paintings off the rock surface. It is a constant source of concern, as it will be when these off-shore installations get going, to management staff. They have to tread the daily tightrope-and often a political tightrope, because it often gets into the public arena-between preserving the resource, not just for tourism but for its own sake, while at the same time trying to accommodate the natural pressure for people to go in and view what is there. That causes resentment and there is no question that it will occur with the off-shore installations which are now being discussed in the Northern Territory, because there are people in the community who demand the right, as they see it, to travel at will across the great wilderness, the frontier of Australia, without any restrictions being placed upon them at all.

I remember an incident which occurred many years ago and which stands out in my mind. When I was working in Kakadu National Park for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), we were constructing the first fence-15 kilometres of it-to preserve from intrusion an area which was to be the subject of ecological studies. One day I was working on this fence, putting the line up with a couple of other workers from CSIRO, when, out of the scrub and knocking trees down in its path, came a classic sight in the Northern Territory- a huge four-wheel drive with an enormous bull-bar on the front. The vehicle was bashing trees left, right and centre and it contained half a dozen blokes, armed to the teeth with shotguns and high-powered firearms. We were subjected to 10 minutes of fairly vitriolic and colourful verbal abuse, such as `What are you so-and-sos up to?', `It wont be long before a man cannot drive across this country' and `We should knock the bloody, so-and-so fence line down'. In view of the 12-gauge shotguns and .243 magnums that were bristling out of the vehicle, we politely stood back from the fence line and said, `Please be our guests; go ahead, remove it'. They proceeded to do that. It took a couple of hundred yards of fence line to get the dirty water off their chests-there were a few people doing that in the House of Representatives yesterday, I noticed-and we then proceeded to spend a couple of hours putting the fence back after the men had gone. The point I am making is that I am familiar on a day to day basis with the constant tightrope that has to be walked in the management of our national parks, balancing the question of preservation for its own sake, which is an essential role for national parks to play, and the very obvious pressure exerted by people who want to see the resource that is available.

I suspect, as Senator Sanders obviously suspects, that in this area of sea installations in tourist areas balancing act will provide the Minister responsible for the environment-whoever he may be-with some real headaches in future years. There is no doubt that this will be a highly desirable market to get into. There is a certain attraction and novelty in being in an off-shore hotel or, indeed, an off-shore casino-and I dare say that we will see some of those around the place before too long. I believe that we cannot get away completely from the fact that much of this will have to be left to ministerial discretion. There are many arguments about the extent to which ministerial discretion should extend, but in my view-and I held this view very firmly when I was in opposition and expressed it many times-I do not think that one can argue too hard about that because, by and large, the system of government under which we operate is that governments stand or fall on the decisions of their Ministers. That is not an unreasonable way to run the country. I do not have any particular objections to the discretion provided in this legislation for the Minister to determine whether an environmental impact study has to be carried out. Indeed, that has been invoked, in the case of the installations that are currently proceeding, in the powers that the Minister has for cracking down on any abuses of the development once it has actually gone ahead.

Along with Senator Sanders, I share a feeling of some trepidation about the likely blossoming of these proposals. As I said, I believe the legislation is absolutely essential. I hope that it gets a speedy passage through the Senate and comes into law without too much undue delay, because there is no question but that there will be many such applications on the Minister's desk before too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the Senate is debating the Sea Installations Bill 1987, the Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 and the Sea Installations Levy Bill 1987. As Senator Puplick said in leading this debate, the Opposition supports this legislation. The legislation has come back to the Senate because of the premature election and there have been some minor changes to it in respect of such matters as the levy. I think Senator Collins made a very valid point when he said that it was timely. There is a need for legislation in this direction because, not only in the Barrier Reef area of Queensland but also in several other parts of Australia, there are movements towards building tourist facilities off the coast.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sea Installations Bill sets out to regulate the operation of certain off-shore sea installations fixed or moored to the sea-bed of the Australian continental shelf or adjacent to Australian territories. It is facilitating the development of technically sound, environmentally acceptable and economically viable installations of this nature. It effectively makes those installations subject to the same legal requirements as those that apply to land-based facilities. It provides for the application to be made, for a fee, prior to the issue of a permit and for the issuing of permits under which the installations operate. This permit can be issued for up to 15 years and may be reviewed and varied as circumstances change. It excludes items such as defence structures, cargo ships, dumping vessels, shipwrecks, pearling vessels, navigational aids and cables. The Bill defines the areas involved and adjacent areas and provides substantial penalties for any contravention of the legislation. It provides safety zones around installations and defines the rights that inspectors have in seeing that the Act is complied with.

The second Bill we are discussing-the Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill-provides relevant amendments to the Customs Act, the Excise Act, the Migration Act and the Quarantine Act as a consequence of the main Bill. It also repeals certain parts of the Customs Tariff Act and the Excise Tariff Act. Finally, the Sea Installations Levy Bill provides for a levy to be paid to the Commonwealth by a permit holder. The levy is either a percentage of the market value of the installation or a percentage of the gross revenue derived from that installation.

The first real application of these Bills will be to the Reef Link Pty Ltd construction at John Brewer Reef, which has been referred to earlier in the debate. This will be sited on the John Brewer Reef, 72 kilometres north-east of Townsville. This Reef Link hotel will be managed by Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts, but it has its origins in Mr Doug Tarca, the tourist operator in Townsville, who is the principal of Reef Link. Mr Tarca is a very experienced diver who has spent a lifetime on the reef. One must give him full credit and express admiration for the imagination he put into this development. There are not too many people who would have thought of building what will be a seven-storey hotel, weighing about 11,000 tonnes and mooring it out on a very attractive part of a lagoon on the reef and coping with the myriad technical and financial problems that come from an installation of this size. It is really a very creative and innovative approach that Mr Tarca has set in train.

Having had some knowledge of the operation in its planning stage, I think it has been very carefully and sensitively handled. I can find no fault with it at present. It will provide a platform on a very beautiful part of the Barrier Reef. The hotel has been sited, not to help Townsville per se, but because in Mr Tarca's judgment John Brewer Reef provides the best facilities for a tourist hotel with a view to seeing the Barrier Reef features at close hand. It is an investment of about $40m. It will provide 200 rooms and will have its own tennis court, swimming pool and desalination system, together with a system of floating rafts around it. The whole structure has been built in Singapore. My understanding is that it is already in transit. It is coming out on one of the oil rig supply ships. The structure is made of concrete and steel and weighs 11,000 tonnes. Parts of the hull of the oil rig supply ship are submerged underneath the hotel. It should be installed next month. Senator Sanders said that the structure was hundreds of metres long. It is not. My information is that it is 90 metres long by 27 metres wide.

It is a very exciting and imaginative project. It has been vetted very carefully with respect to its possible environmental impact on the reef. It has the full support of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Senator Collins was talking about conservation for its own sake. I take the view that conservation is more profound than that. There is no such thing as a static environment. There is no such thing as a static ecosystem. It is a dynamic and evolving environment. The belief inherent in some conservation thinking, that if one puts a fence around an area or a system or if one does not intrude on it, it will somehow be preserved in perpetuity, is not scientifically correct at all. Things are subject to natural growth and development. Having said that, I am not arguing for destruction because they are going to change in any case. That is not the point at all. Conservation is a matter of good housekeeping and common sense.

I often feel that the environmental argument has moved far beyond the greenies and many members of the Labor Party. The community now recognises the benefit of preserving the distinctive features of our physical environment for as far as can be seen into the future. But at the same time it wants an intelligent use of those features, provided they are not going to be destroyed. The community recognises now that we have environmental management plans that enable us to use very beautiful and rare resources and not destroy them. It is a matter of management, not of isolation. Senator Sanders was very much putting the old isolationist argument.

I compliment the Government on having had the courage to go ahead with this legislation. It incorporates the principles I was talking about. It incorporates the preservation of the environment but it also allows for its use. As a Queenslander, I am bemused as to why we have a double standard. Why can we go ahead and, in a responsible way, develop the Barrier Reef for tourist facilities, yet we have all this nonsense about rainforests? Apparently, under the Richardson scheme, we cannot have any intelligent maintenance of rainforests in the form of controlled logging, a system which it has been demonstrated over 60 years does not do any harm. It applies to only a very small part of the rainforests, less than 18 per cent, leaving over two million acres in its virginal state. I contrast that with the approach to the reef, which is both intelligent and responsible.

The Reef Link program for the John Brewer Reef will be of great benefit to Australia and, in particular, to north Queensland and Townsville. Townsville has come a long way since I had my first job there at the Townsville General Hospital in the latter part of the 1950s. Its population has grown three or four times. It is developing as a tourist centre, both for Australians and for people from overseas. This year will see the completion of the domestic airport terminal. The international terminal has already been finished. Tourist traffic in Townsville has shown remarkable growth in recent times. The accommodation takings in the September quarter last year were $4.8m. That is an indication of the number of national and international travellers who have visited the area.

Townsville has also taken a great step forward with the building of the Great Barrier Reef Wonderland facility, which had its origins with Mr Graeme Kelleher, the Chairman of the Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. The proposal was to build, on land, a simulated reef environment with fish, reef structures and corals. It is a world first. It is a very imaginative development. It involved the Commonwealth Government in providing funding through the bicentenary program. The Queensland Government was also involved. Private enterprise built it and contributed to its financial base, principally through Avago Holdings Pty Ltd in Townsville, a well-managed private enterprise group in the region. I watched Reef Wonderland being built. I have been through it since it was completed. I commend it to anyone who visits Townsville. As I said, it is a world first. It is the first time a large reef structure has been built on land. A lot of scientific advice came from the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. It is a very rewarding and interesting experience to visit Reef Wonderland in Townsville. As more money becomes available and as a result of the experience of creating a world first, a reef environment, the facility will be one of the great scientific and tourist attractions of the world.

Let me list the essential points of this legislation. Firstly, there has to be concern for the preservation of the environment. The legislation ensures that. Secondly, the legal aspects of the operations of a hotel or facility have to be adequately covered by legislation the same as that applying to the rest of Australia with respect to customs, excise, general law and order, and migration. Thirdly, there have to be safety provisions for the lives involved. Insofar as it is possible to foresee what might happen, the legislation covers all eventualities.

I do not share the concern of Senator Sanders about environmental risks from the John Brewer Reef program. As I understand it, it provides for the total retention of all liquid and solid wastes from the hotel that will be moored on the reef. About the only scientific argument one could advance is that the shadow of the moored structure might have some effect on the life of some of the living organisms on the reef. I do not know whether that is a serious consideration. It has not been put to me as a serious consideration.

Insofar as it is a fixed structure, it will require heavy moorings to base it on the reef. Whatever is anchored in the lagoon will not move around. It will be in a static spot. So any rubbish that is thrown over the side will be seen in the clear waters by the tourists. Over and above everything else, the people who have invested $40m in this venture are not going to live in their own garbage heap. They are going to be meticulous in the maintenance of the environment about them. Their investment is worthless unless the environment around it is preserved. So I do not have any real reservations about the environment. Without creating a monopoly for the people who have made this initial move, I think it is prudent to let five or 10 years run before we go on to other developments. I do not share the view that we cannot use national parks. I think they are for the benefit of the human race. The argument that has been put forward that somehow or other we are privatising a resource that is owned by Australians and by the rest of the world leaves me quite cold. That is an argument that cannot be sustained. But, at the same time, we certainly do not want anything like the beach line at the Gold Coast in Queensland, where one garish hotel competes with its neighbour. We do not want that all the way down the 2,000 kilometres of the reef. There is a good argument to proceed slowly on this and to evaluate future developments in the light of the experience that we have gained.

My concern about the legislation relates to the levy. It is not defined, except in the most general terms, what the levy will be for the Commonwealth. I am concerned that the levy could be so high as to provide a commercial disincentive for this venture or for future ones. The other point of concern to me is the one about Antarctic development. Not only the Parliament but all people in Australia are getting inured now to very irrational statements from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mr Brown, when he is in the country. Some of his comments about Antarctica and possible developments there were, to say the least, intemperate. They do not deserve the consideration of the Senate at this time. We support this legislation and we wish it a speedy passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I will return to my point, Mr Acting Deputy President, having been diverted, with your indulgence, for a couple of moments. I think Senator Sanders was implying that the Sea Installations Bill was designed to apply environmental protection to the floating hotel on the Great Barrier Reef. That is wrong. It is acknowledged that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority thereby set up has done a magnificent job in protecting the environment. The original aim of the Sea Installations Bill was to apply other Commonwealth laws to the Great Barrier Reef outside the territorial sea in terms of taxation, Customs or immigration. In preparation it was decided to extend it to cover all areas around Australia outside the Great Barrier Reef in relation to environmental protection and other matters.
