SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be proposing amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, which are being debated together now. Two of these amendments deal with the Government's attempts to alter the existing procedures whereby the current income tax scales are presented to the Parliament on an annual basis, can in fact be debated annually and are subject to scrutiny by the Parliament annually. The Government seeks instead to institute those income tax rates, including the Medicare levy, as a standing order. In other words, they will be re-introduced into Parliament only when those rate scales change. The Opposition just disagrees totally with that principle and will be endeavouring, we hope with the support of the Australian Democrats, to bring both the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill back to the traditional basis of annual imposition Bills, so that they will be subject, of course, to the same scrutiny as any measure which raises large amounts of revenue should have. We believe this principle is of major significance.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to moving amendments to bring that into effect-that is, amendments to clauses 4, 5 and 6 of the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and clause 11 of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill-we also wish to move an amendment to clause 8 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). That is the clause which proposes the insertion of a new section, section 46e, into the Income Tax Assessment Act to counter certain schemes involving the payment of dividends out of profits arising from the revaluation of assets. We also are concerned about another element relating to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) which I understand is presently under consideration in the office of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Depending on the outcome of those discussions we will determine what course of action we should adopt in relation to section 207.

On the question of clause 8, to which I have just referred, originally the Government made an attempt to deal with this matter in June of this year. But that Bill was not continued with because of the election. The current Bill proposes that the date that was stated in that original legislation-that is, 4 June-be the date from which the new proposed section 46e of the present legislation operates. It appears to us that the proposals put forward in the legislation before us are not the same as those detailed in the earlier Bill, and we will be seeking to avoid what is clearly the retrospective nature of these changes by moving forward the effectiveness of this part of the legislation to 23 September 1987-the date on which this legislation was introduced into the Parliament. Obviously we will be taking that matter up at the committee stage of the Bill.

It is the broader aspects of these Bills which are of major concern to the Opposition. I refer, of course, to the attempt by the Government in these Bills to deny the annual review of tax scales by the Parliament. The Government is apparently suggesting that it is simply proposing to put the legislation for income tax on the same basis as most other tax law; that is, subject to standing legislation which does not come up for annual review. But the Opposition is strongly of the view that, because income tax represents well over 60 per cent of the total receipts of the Commonwealth Government and because a large proportion of those receipts are embodied in the legislation before us, there is a very strong case for treating this legislation on a different basis. As Mr Peacock, the shadow Treasurer, said in the House of Representatives when debating this matter:

The life blood of government is, after all, supplied through these sorts of Bills. The Opposition would be failing in its duty to uphold the supremacy of Parliament to allow such an enormously important means of debating government policy just to disappear.

I must say that I totally agree with the point of view Mr Peacock has expressed. It is the duty and responsibility of the Parliament to conduct a thorough debate to make all Australians totally aware of the impact of the Government's taxation policies, and this should be capable of being done on an annual basis.

It seems quite ridiculous that the Government should seek to ride roughshod over the Parliament in this way, particularly in a situation where it is pretending to the people of Australia that there are significant taxation cuts and that its policy is aimed at reducing tax revenues, when we know that the facts are to the contrary. We know, for example, from this Budget that this Government is planning to increase total income tax by 9.2 per cent this year. The consumer price index is forecast by this Government to be 6 1/2 per cent, although heaven knows what would happen to that forecast if the current problems with the stock markets around the world lead to any kind of reduction in the value of the Australian dollar; who knows what would happen to the level of inflation if the Australian dollar did fall! But on current expectations the Government is looking to a substantial real increase, after accounting for inflation, in the level of tax paid by Australians. For the Government to seek to diminish the Parliament's capacity to deal with the rates of tax by removing this opportunity which in the past has been with us on an annual basis is, I believe, another attempt by the Government to hide the realities and to give it a greater opportunity to use its now well established system of government by Press release to convey a totally false impression to the people of Australia in the area of income tax. I might say that this Government has become expert at misleading Australians about the level of income tax. As I said, the latest Budget figures show a 9.2 per cent increase this year in the level of income tax to be paid by Australians. That is an increase of $4.2 billion from a government which is going around the place claiming that it is reducing the tax burden.

The total increase in all taxation revenue this year, by the way-and I spoke only of income tax when I talked about $4.2 billion-is budgeted to be $5.6 billion. If every time we have a tax `cut' we end up with a tax increase of $5.6 billion, heaven protect us from further tax cuts by this Government. I believe it is a matter of major concern that this kind of legislation aims at removing the prime opportunity of the Parliament to examine the rates of taxation in this country and to debate them, as it should do. That is the purpose of the Parliament; it is the reason that people have chosen representatives to debate this area, which is surely the very essential central element of the whole process of government.

The Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) formally seeks to impose the tax payable on the basis of the new tax rate scales announced in the September 1985 tax reform package. I should interpose that to call that package a reform package is a total corruption of the word `reform'. What the Government means is `change' and it has achieved the apex of hypocrisy by corrupting the word `reform' by applying it to every change, whether it be for the better or the worse, in order to try to create a false impression that the changes it makes are reforms, are for the better.

The great reform Acts of the nineteenth century improved the capacity of people to be adequately represented in the Parliament. If one is taking the word `reform' seriously, one certainly cannot regard with anything other than distaste the downgrading of the word `reform' by this Government. So often the word `reform' hides a mass of badly thought out, in many instances, and inappropriate changes which do not improve the lot of Australians. Tax reform is supposed to be about achieving efficiency, simplicity and equity. Certainly the changes this Government introduced into the tax arena have been far from that. The hundreds and hundreds of pages that have been added to the Income Tax Assessment Act have not achieved that aim. One great reform that sections of the Government tentatively set out on at one stage was Mr Keating's attempt to smarten up the whole tax structure. Of course, that attempt was sabotaged by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in a secret meeting in a Canberra hotel. Mr Keating's attempts to have an effective change in the tax structure by introducing a different approach were sabotaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Keating wasn't even there, was he?

—As Senator Stone says, Mr Keating was not even given the courtesy of being asked to attend the secret meeting at which he was stabbed in the back by his leader. In this legislation there are more examples of what is loosely called reform. Let me deal with a few aspects of it. The company tax rate has been increased from 46c to 49c in the dollar. The Government argues that this helps to defray the cost of the new imputation system which has been welcomed by many people. What it has really done-this is the practicality of the issue-is increase the company tax rate to the top personal income tax rate. Clearly, there are benefits for the Government in doing that because it makes certain that a person does not benefit from changing his status in order to get a more beneficial personal tax rate as against a corporate tax rate if he is on the top of the personal income tax scale. What is the real purpose of doing this? For heaven's sake, the Government says that it will totally review corporate tax rates. If it is going to do that, one assumes from all the hype and propaganda about it that it is aimed at reducing the corporate tax rate. Why is the Government increasing the corporate tax rate if its intention is to reduce it, unless it is to have the phoney hype, the phoney self-congratulation which will take place when the tax rate is eventually reduced by 3 per cent more than it will be reduced in reality? In other words, it is putting up the tax rate by 3 per cent in order that it may congratulate itself even more when it ultimately reduces the rate.
—What about tax imputation?

—We hear the question, `What about tax imputation?'. I have just been explaining-the honourable senator would know this if he had been listening-that whether or not there is tax imputation this Government apparently plans, unless it is again seeking to mislead the Australian people, which I would not put past it, to reduce the company tax rate. If it intends to reduce it, the claim that it is increasing it temporarily to offset the imputation system clearly falls down. There is a great case for ensuring that it should not increase the rate because, presumably, that would decrease its enthusiasm for proceeding speedily with the company tax reduction which is clearly needed and which has been foreshadowed by this Government. In any event it could well be argued that if the Government is determined to make the corporate tax rate and the personal tax rate the same-49c in the dollar-perhaps it would be more sensible to have them at the same rate but at a lower level. Many people take the strong view, as I do, that in income tax terms Australians are overtaxed.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the review of the corporate tax arrangements proceeds speedily. While it is recognised that the Australian tax rate of 49 per cent is offset in some areas for some companies by various deductions-in contrast with the trend in the United States and some other areas where the rate is significantly lower-of course it would be far more attractive for foreign investors who wished to assist us in the sort of investment of which we are desperately short at the moment, investment aimed at increasing our capacity to export and increasing our capacity to replace the extraordinarily high volume of imports that is taking place, which is the fundamental crisis we now face in Australia, if the corporate tax rate were lower. A lot of the criticism and complaint in Australia about the low rates of tax paid by some corporations could be resolved if there were a generally lower tax rate and fewer opportunities for people to minimise paying tax; in other words, if we followed overseas tax arrangements.

Along with the other Bills being debated, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is chock full of revisions to Labor's previous legislation. The Government seems to have developed a pattern whereby it brings in legislation, dumps more constraints and taxes on people, finds that the legislation is not working well enough and brings in more legislation to tighten it even further. As Mr Peacock said in the House of Representatives, this Bill is full of alterations to hastily prepared and obviously ill-considered legislation. He continued:
Honourable members may care to note that the largest number of those revisions apply to the capital gains tax legislation.

Of course it does, and that underlines the reality that when this Government continues to rush ahead not on what is required but on some philosophic, extraordinary approach to running this nation we end up with these wonderful words that the Government dumped on us-unintended consequences. This is one of the many Bills aimed at resolving some of the unintended consequences-which is another term for injustice-that abounds. The whole question of the capital gains tax seems to fit in with the Government's philosophic view that the wealthy should somehow be punished. Let us recognise that this Government is not thinking simply of the rich people of Australia when it talks about the wealthy. It is talking about the great bulk of Australians, those who dare, for example, to own their own home, who have tried to put some money aside for their old age.

The intention to have a wealth inquiry is not really aimed at the few Australians who have conspicuous wealth. There would be no benefit in wasting public money on such an inquiry if it were aimed only at that small minority of Australians-and in any event, the wealth of many of them has significantly diminished over the past week or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Serves them right.

—I do not make that kind of moral judgment. I do not play God in these areas, as do the Australian Democrats in so many instances. I take the view that, if people contribute to society and work hard, they are entitled to accumulate resources and are entitled to reward. The manner in which they do it is of interest only to the extent that the accumulation of those assets leads to the creation of jobs in this nation. If we did not have an accumulation of assets, an accumulation of what the Australian Labor Party (ALP) likes to describe in a disparaging way as `wealth', we would not have the capacity to invest in new plant and equipment and we would not have the capacity to create new jobs unless we called on the Government to do it for us, in which case we would end up with the sort of socialist society that apparently many people in the socialist left of the ALP still seek to obtain.
—Senator Haines has suggested that anybody who invests on the stock exchange deserves what he gets, including those people who have invested their money in superannuation funds.

—I think that Senator Stone has made an excellent point, noting that some of the major investors in Australian stock markets have been ordinary Australians whose superannuation funds have invested in shares so that the future of these people can be provided for when they retire. It is absolutely absurd for Senator Haines or anyone else to dismiss people who buy shares on stock exchanges as simply being gamblers and deserving all they get if the market falls. We should recognise that very few Australians who are involved in superannuation funds in preparing for their retirement will not be affected-not because they have gambled but because they have invested in Australian corporations and have assisted in the provision of capital for the creation of jobs and the creation of new plant and equipment aimed at resolving the economic crisis that this Government has helped Australia into.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that it is because of the lack of local capital, which is one of the factors in the disastrous collapse of investment in new plant and equipment and one of the structural crises that we face, that we are not exporting enough and why we must import so much. However, that is a diversion. I will deal now with the ALP's whole attack on the concept of `wealth': in other words, people being entitled to get rewards for effort. That is really striking at the heart of small business in Australia, at the heart of the entrepreneurs-the real spirit, if you like, of the Australian people. The Taxation Institute of Australia has highlighted that one of the most serious deficiencies of the legislation is the inadequate provision for dealing with the roll-over of business assets in relation to capital gains tax. There is no doubt that that is a serious problem. The Treasurer forecast in the Budget an increase in investment in plant and equipment of only, I think, 3 per cent. He has been travelling around the world saying that this year it will be more than that. I doubt very much whether that forecast in the Budget will be met in view of what has happened in recent weeks, let alone the significant increase that he tried to suggest while he was overseas.

There is no doubt that investment in new plant and equipment is the basis on which economic growth will occur in Australia, but it has simply not happened. The Taxation Institute, when dealing with this area of the legislation, said that this deficiency was a serious disincentive to business investment where a small businessman, for example, had a question of doubt over whether capital gains tax was applicable when he rolled over an asset. I will explain what happens in the case of a small businessman, for example, wishing to upgrade his premises or move into new and expanded premises. He must pay capital gains tax on the disposal of the old premises with no roll-over relief. Clearly, that type of situation is intolerable.

There are many more areas that I would like to deal with-and intend to deal with-in terms of the amendments that we plan to move in the committee stage, but I think it is vital to stress that the most important contribution that can be made to getting Australia out of the major crisis it is in-and the most important contribution that can be made to removing the level of poverty in Australia to reduce the proportion of Australians who are poor-is not to have the sort of approach that this Government has of taxing capital gains or diminishing the incentive to invest or having wealth inquiries and wealth taxes. The best way to do it is to reduce the high level of unemployment, and that can be achieved only by quickening the pace of economic advance in Australia and by increasing the level of investment in new plant and equipment. In fact, the Government is doing exactly the opposite. The only way to achieve what is required is for the Government to do exactly the opposite in relation to the sorts of policies that it is pursuing.

I will deal quickly with changes in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). Clause 15 of that Bill seeks to replace existing sections 108 and 109 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to remove certain technical deficiencies which have become apparent in the legislation's application. New legislation is being introduced to cover the instances where loans and reimbursements are made to associates of shareholders. The Opposition has no problem with that principle, but it does draw attention to the fact that there is some concern that the revisions to section 108, in particular, could result in a deal of uncertainty in the minds of those who are making what could be considered legitimate intercorporate loans, because the decision on what constitutes a legitimate or illegitimate use of loans is made at the discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation. Now discretion obviously must be given to the Commissioner in many instances, but the big question is: How often should this discretion be given, how wide should it be and to what extent is it a government's duty to give a clear indication to the Commissioner of the manner in which that discretion should be exercised? In this particular instance it appears that there is an open-ended aspect of the discretion which is inappropriate and creates uncertainty and may well hinder business investment. It would seem appropriate in this case that the Government should request the Commissioner to draw up extensive guidelines as to what he expects will be covered by section 108.

In conclusion, I restate my hope that the Government will respond to the concerns that we have raised with the Treasurer about Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) in relation to some specific matters. In that event, if there is a response, I hope that we can deal with the matter today. I hope that otherwise the committee stage can be deferred until we receive a response from the Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating three Taxation Bills jointly. The Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) formally declares the rate of income tax for the current financial year and subsequent years, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) contains anti-tax avoidance measures relating to the imputation of company dividends and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill increases the Medicare levy from 1.145 per cent to 1.25 per cent of taxable income and lifts the threshold below which people will be exempt from Medicare levy. The first two Bills form part of the Hawke Government's tax reform package. That package, which has been progressively implemented since 1985, involves a major overhaul of the Australian taxation system. The package that we began implementing after the National Taxation Summit in 1985 aims to restore fairness and equity to the tax system by reducing marginal income tax rates for pay as you earn taxpayers and by cracking down on the tax avoiders and evaders who, regrettably, still exist in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The main difference between the Hawke Government's tax package and the Liberal Party's July election tax bribes is that the Government's tax cuts will be paid for out of tax base broadening measures-that is, a number of measures to broaden the tax base to include further activities in the definition of income, whereas the Liberals' tax bribe for the July election would have blown out the Budget deficit instead. Had Mr Howard's tax policy bribed enough electors, we would have seen a massive blow-out in the Commonwealth Government's Budget deficit.

To refresh the memories of honourable senators, I point out that some of the base-broadening measures that we have implemented in this tax package have included items such as the fringe benefits tax, a tax levied on non-monetary incomes earned by a number of the high-fliers in the community. That very fair measure, implemented by this Government, was opposed by the Liberal Party. At the end of 1985 we cracked down on the tax subsidised business lunch which was enjoyed by a minority who had long lunches at the expense of the taxpayer. That measure, again opposed by the Liberal and National parties, was estimated to have saved revenue of $300m a year. That is a stupendous amount of money through the crackdown on tax subsidised lunches.

Then this Government introduced the capital gains tax, one of the fairest capital gains taxes in the world, because it indexed asset values for inflation. It was a long overdue tax measure which was very important in cracking down on tax avoidance in the community. It stopped people converting income which was taxable into a non-taxable gain. That income tax avoidance measure was removed by this Government after strenuous opposition by the conservative parties. The Government introduced a package of measures involving the fringe benefits tax and ending the tax-subsidised lunch and the introduction of the capital gains tax, to promote fairness. The Opposition parties in this place sought to oppose those measures, which brought greater fairness and social justice into the taxation system.

In looking at those measures it was interesting to recall a speech made some weeks ago in this place by Senator Cooney in regard to the Australia Card. He pointed out that there had been a pattern of opposition by the Liberal and National parties to those measures which brought greater fairness to the tax system. It was not as though they were opposing those measures in isolation, which was one of the fictions they tried to create in the debate on the Australia Card. In fact, every one of the measures in the tax package introduced by this Government which cracked down on those who were avoiding tax, which made the wealthy pay their fair share of tax, was opposed by the Opposition parties. We are all indebted to Senator Cooney for pointing out that pattern of opposition.

The final instalment of the Hawke Government's tax package as it relates to income tax is being delivered in this financial year as from 1 July. The tax rate cuts encompassed in one of the pieces of legislation came into effect on 1 July, and to date the tax cuts for a person earning $400 weekly up to 30 June this year were estimated to be $13 to $14 a week. These further reductions in income tax, which apply in this financial year, add to those $13 to $14 a week reductions for somebody on $400 weekly.

The Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) sets out the marginal tax rates for 1987-88 and subsequent years. As I have pointed out, they enable even further reductions to occur in income tax rates in the community. In effect, the legislation constitutes stage 3 of the Government's reductions in marginal income tax rates, beginning with the first round from November 1984, the second round from last year, and the third round from July 1987. The rates include a marginal tax rate of 40c in the dollar on annual taxable incomes between $19,500 and $35,000, and a top marginal rate of 49c in the dollar for annual taxable incomes above $35,000. The rates in that tax distribution represent substantial reductions in marginal tax for taxpayers. It should be noted that the average tax rates-the rates of tax on all dollars in a person's income-are well below those marginal tax rates.

In recent years the Liberals on a number of occasions have tried to create the fiction that the tax rate effectively paid by all taxpayers was the same as their marginal tax rate. They were trying to create the fiction that the tax paid on all dollars of a person's income was the same as the marginal tax rate, which is the rate paid on the last or the highest dollars of a person's income. It is interesting to note that, in the 1985-86 financial year, while there was a marginal rate of 46c in the dollar on a number of incomes, the average rate-that is, the rate paid on all dollars of a person's income subject to that marginal rate-was 21.5c in the dollar. I make the point that there are very big differences between marginal and average tax rates, and the fiction that the Liberal Party and its allies in the National Party have tried to promote can be shown to be discredited by the use of those figures.

This legislation provides for an increase in the income tax threshold to $5,100 in the current financial year. In other words, the first $5,100 of a person's taxable income will now be exempt from taxation. That is a figure that never existed when the Liberals sat on the treasury bench. The best they could achieve was a tax threshold of $4,595; we are exempting the first $5,100 from tax.

It is interesting to note that this Government has cut the top marginal tax rate-that is, the rate of tax applying in the highest income bracket-from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. The bottom marginal tax rate has been lowered from 30c in the dollar, as it was under Mr Howard, to 24c in the dollar. That measure will be of great benefit to low income earners, including those who receive social security payments. The $5,100 tax free income provided by the threshold, combined with the reduction in marginal tax rates from 30c in the dollar in the lowest income bracket under Mr Howard to 24c in the dollar now, will provide that much more of a pensioner's income and the income of a low salary earner will be exempted from taxation. For example, in this financial year a person receiving the $250 pensioner rebate will find that instead of $5,914 of income being exempt from taxation, as was the case last financial year, the figure will be $6,142. As that pensioner rebate shades out on higher incomes, it can be shown that pensioners will receive some taxation relief up to and including a taxable income of $8,142 this financial year. This is a quite important taxation relief measure for those receiving social security pensions.

The middle tax bracket for this financial year will be reduced from 46c in the dollar to 40c. That is the most important bracket in the community, it is where the largest single number of wage and salary earners are to be found. As I pointed out, their marginal tax rate will be lowered this financial year from 46c in the dollar to 40c in the dollar. From these figures it can be seen that the Hawke Government has delivered its promise to reduce tax rates for ordinary Australians. There have been very substantial reductions in marginal tax rates, beginning in 1984, occurring again in 1986 and finally on 1 July this year.

The Hawke Government has achieved the reductions in marginal income tax rates that Mr Howard found impossible in his five years as Treasurer. It has to be remembered that Mr Howard, who is the present Leader of the Opposition, brought down five Budgets as the Commonwealth Treasurer from 1978 to 1982 inclusive. In five Budgets he had the opportunity to frame Australia's taxation policy. It is quite illuminating to look at those Budgets and to realise that when Mr Howard left office in 1983 the top marginal tax rate was still 60c in the dollar. As I have pointed out, under this Government the highest marginal tax-the rate of tax applying in the highest income bracket-has been lowered to 49c in the dollar. When Mr Howard left office in 1983 after bringing down five Budgets as Commonwealth Treasurer, the marginal income tax rate faced by the lowest income earners in the community was 30c in the dollar. But now, as a result of the tax package introduced by the Hawke Government, the marginal tax rate is 24c in the dollar-or 6c in the dollar lower than the best marginal tax rate Mr Howard, as Treasurer, was ever able to achieve.

It is little wonder, therefore, that the Australian electorate on 11 July rejected Mr Howard's tax bribes. Clearly his performance as Treasurer could not give people confidence that he would be able to deliver promises made in an election context. As Mr Howard was not able to cut taxes from 1978 to 1983 why should anyone believe him now? It is a very relevant point to raise. Why should anyone believe someone who, in the present day and age, says that he can cut taxes when his very record in government clearly shows a total incapability to do so? The Liberal Party's credibility on taxation is in tatters. It was incapable of cutting taxes during the years Mr Howard presided over the Treasury. Mr Howard procrastinated over tax cuts, just as he did on the matter of deregulation. That has been exposed in the last few days in the biography of Mr Fraser. It says that Mr Howard, despite the image created, was a procrastinator on deregulation just as he was on the matter of tax reductions and tax reform in Australia.

The Liberals were incapable of putting together a tax package which added up at the last election. Of course Senator Michael Baume, who preceded me in this debate, was one of the people who pulled the rug from under the Liberal Party's policies in the election. I well remember door-knocking in a key marginal electorate on the day after Senator Baume announced the Liberals' health policy. It was quite evident that the voters were swinging to Labor as they came to terms with that health policy, which did not add up and which confused them and conflicted with the Liberals' overall tax policies. We certainly owe Senator Michael Baume a great debt for that particular gaffe in putting down a health policy which did not add up in the context of the Opposition's tax policy.

Irresponsibility and opportunism are the hallmarks of the Liberals' approach to tax reform over the past two years. The Liberals and the Nationals opposed all this Government's major tax base broadening measures and anti-tax avoidance measures. Those are the facts and the realities. On the other hand, the Liberals and the Nationals in this place were quite prepared to support the reductions in marginal income tax rates and the so-called poverty trap measures which gave taxation relief to people receiving social welfare payments. In other words, the Liberals blocked the measures that would have raised extra revenue for the Government, but supported those which cost the Government revenue. The Liberals and the Nationals wanted the tax package goodies but not the tax nasties. Of course, we were warned about this some time ago when a document was leaked out of a shadow Cabinet meeting. I think the author was Senator Messner, from South Australia. To give him credit, he warned his colleagues on the Opposition front bench that they would be seen as being rather grubby and tatty if they were to go around the country opposing all the so-called tax nasties but endorsing the tax goodies which reduced taxes and revenue available to the Government.

The Opposition glibly promises tax cuts but shirks proposing the measures to pay for them. Mr Howard claims that he will cut Government expenditure to pay for tax cuts. But at the last election Mr Howard was not able to tell the Australian people just which government programs would be cut. He could not and would not specify the areas. He would not do it this week, either. Again he has been challenged on the areas where he would cut government programs and spending, but he has not come up with any specifics. Yesterday I raised the question of Senator Stone's position on this matter, because he also has been talking about cutting government programs, but he too has been quite non-specific about the areas in which he would prefer to see government spending cut. The Liberals' tax and fiscal policies are built on shifting sands, and their promised tax cuts are merely a mirage.

The Opposition has criticised the Government for the level of tax receipts in the Budget, but again it is suffering from selection amnesia. On the one hand it criticises us for the level of tax receipts in the Budget, but on the other hand, it wants to forget all about its own record in government. It is very interesting to compare total Commonwealth receipts and income tax receipts at the end of the Howard years with the figures for the beginning of that period. When looking at these figures we should remember that, broadly speaking, over the period that Mr Howard was the Treasurer of this nation he was advised by the then Secretary to the Treasury, Senator Stone. They were both in their respective positions as Treasurer and Secretary to the Treasury over the same period. It is very interesting that day after day and week after week Opposition senators claim that this Government has rapidly increased the share of taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP). But it is very illuminating to look at what happened when Mr Howard was Treasurer and Mr Stone was advising him. It is interesting that between the financial years 1977-78 and 1982-83, the share of Australia's GDP, taken by Commonwealth taxation through the Budget, actually rose. It did not fall, it rose. It rose by 1.5 percentage points. These facts are readily available in Budget Paper No. 1. I invite honourable senators to read them. They are not figures I have pulled out of the air. Despite the claims by the Liberals in the mid-1970s that they would cut taxes and despite the claims by Mr Howard that he would reform taxation and reduce the level of taxation in the economy, the record shows the opposite. From the beginning to the end of the Howard years the share of gross domestic product taken by Commonwealth taxation rose by 1.5 percentage points.

As I have pointed out, Senator Stone was Mr Howard's chief adviser in the Public Service. He presided over the Department of the Treasury during a period when the share of gross domestic product taken by taxation rose. So I am rather offended, as I am sure other senators are, when Liberals and Nationals come into this place and try to lecture those of us in the Hawke Government who have been involved in the tax reform process for over two years. When they lecture us about cutting taxes they should look at their own record. They should be honest enough to acknowledge that, under Mr Howard's stewardship of the Treasury, taxation took an increasing share of Australia's resources. The Liberals' record and the Liberals' rhetoric cannot be reconciled.

Senator Stone said here on 7 October that no purpose was served in examining the economic record of the Fraser-Howard Government. I remind honourable senators that that record included double digit inflation, double digit price rises and double digit unemployment. If the Fraser-Howard Government had had a successful, rather than unsuccessful, economic record, would Senator Stone be so modest? Would he then want to bury the past? Would he then want history to be ignored? That is a very relevant question and needs to be asked. Obviously, Senator Stone is sensitive about his record under the Fraser Government, and so he should be. The Fraser Government left office with double digit unemployment and double digit price rises.

The credibility of words can be judged only by corresponding actions. The Fraser-Howard Government's inability to cut taxes lends very little credibility to the Opposition's criticism of the Hawke Government's tax reform package. The Hawke Government has delivered its promise to reduce marginal tax rates. These tax cuts have been paid for by base-broadening measures, such as the capital gains tax, the cracking down on tax-subsidised lunches and the taxation of so-called fringe benefits. These measures have reduced the extent of tax avoidance in the community. I am pleased to say, as a government senator, that income tax is no longer a voluntary tax for the wealthy, as it was in the Howard years. The Government's tax reform package has lowered the tax burden on the great majority of honest taxpayers by closing the tax loopholes and ending the rorts. The result is a fairer and more efficient tax system. In contrast, the Opposition's approach to tax reform is a sham, more concerned with winning easy votes than with any genuine desire to create equity and efficiency in the community.

Since Senator Evans is the relevant Minister, I would have thought the question should be addressed to him. The question in no way relates to the Minister's responsibilities for finance or for the Treasury.

I will be interested to see what they are. I think it unlikely, however, that Senator Hill will be going public on the question of tax reform, because he felt the heel of the South Australian Liberal Party boot a few months ago and was dropped from first place to third place on the Liberal Party Senate ticket for espousing traditional small `1' Liberal Party views.
—You were much more pleasant when you were drunk last night.
—Order! Senator Puplick will withdraw that comment.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to answers the Minister gave last Monday on the views of Professor Galbraith, which the Minister indicated at the time were known to and supported by the Government, and to his statement at that time that the Government simply did not see any need for, and had no plans for, a mini-Budget. I ask the Minister whether this is the same Professor Galbraith who, in his book `The Great Crash 1929', predicted that, in the event of a future major speculative share market crash, government policy inaction was likely in the short term, even though it would mean deep trouble in the future, because governments invariably wanted to avoid disturbance of what the professor called their `orderly life and convenience'. If so, I ask the Minister whether he also agrees with Professor Galbraith that, in circumstances such as those now prevailing, government inaction is the real threat to our economic system, or that, to quote the professor, `It is what causes men who know that things are going quite wrong to say that things are fundamentally sound'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Somebody asked what the question was. I must confess that I am a little confused about it myself-almost as confused as I am about whether or not Senator Stone believes that there should be some government action and intervention. A few days ago he certainly indicated that governments should keep right out of this area-to the point where governments should return to the sorts of policies they followed in the nineteenth century, or perhaps even the eighteenth century, and, among other things, withdraw the lender of last resort facility that the Reserve Bank of Australia makes available for the trading banks. I was surprised when Senator Stone expressed that view last week, but now he seems to be calling for some government intervention.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone's own record about government intervention is a very spotty one. When he was Secretary to the Treasury he opposed the floating of the dollar and the entry of foreign banks. He wanted to maintain the variable deposit requirement, he opposed the tariff cuts of 1973, and so on. So Senator Stone's record as a regulator or a deregulator is about as spotty as that of the present Leader of the Opposition. However, I understand some purpose in this line of questioning, and that is, of course, that Senator Stone, like Mr Howard, wants to induce an economic crisis. That is how oppositions think they can get into government in periods of economic crisis. If they think they can induce an economic crisis, they will do all they can to do just that.

Last week I spelt out the two major possible consequences of the share market collapse which could damage the real economy; that is, a decline in our export prices or a major withdrawal of capital from Australia. As for a so-called mini-Budget, which is a term that I never use, and I do not think it has ever been used by the Treasurer or the Prime Minister-nobody in the Government that I can recall uses that term-for most of the years we have been in government we have brought out an economic statement in the autumn, and that may be done again. There has been no decision about that, and I suppose it is an option that remains open.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

It would be logical, however, for China to store nuclear waste in remote areas such as Qinghai and Xinjiang, both to the north of the Tibetan autonomous region. —Has the attention of the Minister for Justice been drawn to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning reporting comments by Mr Reith, shadow Attorney-General, that the power of the States to veto references to the National Crime Authority (NCA) should be reviewed? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Commonwealth or the States have ever exercised that power? What is the Government's view of the efficacy of the intergovernmental committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the newspaper article referred to by Senator Foreman, who takes a keen interest in matters of law enforcement in its various jurisdictions throughout Australia. Having had this matter drawn to my attention, I have looked at the Press release put out by Mr Peter Reith in which he said that the NCA should operate free of political direction and veto. I find that a very misleading use of language because, as I have always made it very clear to this chamber, it has never been the case-certainly not in my predecessor's time or in mine-that any political direction of the National Crime Authority has been attempted. If it were attempted, I am sure that it would be repudiated and commented upon, even publicly, by Mr Justice Stewart. The idea that the National Crime Authority should be subject to political direction is one that would be abhorred by all sides of this chamber.

ANSWER.PARA: The function of the intergovernmental committee is to approve references given to the National Crime Authority. When the National Crime Authority seeks a reference into a particular type of organised criminal activity and/or against particular targeted criminal figures it is very important that an intergovernmental committee review that request to undertake those sorts of investigations. Once a reference is given to the National Crime Authority the whole range of very special and extraordinary powers conferred on that Authority by legislation of this Parliament are then brought into play-powers of a coercive kind that go far beyond those available to the ordinary law enforcement agencies and police forces throughout the Commonwealth. For example, I refer to the power to summon people and require answers, powers of arrest and powers which can lead to a person forfeiting his passport.

It is very important that we, as politicians, take responsibility on that intergovernmental committee, which in general consists of the Police Ministers of the various jurisdictions, for the exercise within Australia of those extraordinary powers, which, as I have said, can be used against those who might be targeted crime figures or ordinary citizens who the Authority might think could be useful as it gathers intelligence and assembles evidence for a prosecution.

There is also probably a misunderstanding by Mr Reith. The fact is that in a purely Commonwealth matter, for example, a taxation conspiracy, a reference can be obtained by the Authority seeking the approval of the Commonwealth Minister and the concurrence of the States is not needed. But such is the overlap in criminal activities throughout Australia that, of course, it is very rare for the sorts of relevant criminal activities which are the subject matter of the Authority's investigations to be confined to the Commonwealth jurisdiction. Invariably there is territorial overlap and overlap between the various criminal offences created by Commonwealth and State laws. If there is to be a successful concerted attack on organised criminal activity throughout Australia, clearly the National Crime Authority, exercising its coercive powers, needs to have the ability to move within the Commonwealth and relevant State jurisdictions. Indeed, it was this that led to the recommendation by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-and this was the basis for this particular provision within the legislation-to this effect:

Recognising the force of the constitutional and practical constraints which favour the involvement of the States with the Federal Government in combating relevant criminal activity, the Committee recommends the continuation of an Inter-Governmental Committee.

Senator Robert Hill and Senator Austin Lewis sat on that Senate Standing Committee and I think realised the worth and political sense in having such an intergovernmental committee to ensure that the National Crime Authority could operate successfully in all jurisdictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the Chairman?

—I believe the Chairman was Senator Michael Tate, in a previous incarnation. As to whether the veto power, so-called, has been abused or misused, the fact is that the National Crime Authority has sought some seven references. Seven references have been granted and a new reference is to be considered at the Hobart meeting of the intergovernmental committee in late November. That is a useful discipline on the National Crime Authority, but, more importantly and as I have said, in our democracy it is very important that, as politicians and as Ministers, we take political responsibility for the exercise of these extraordinary powers throughout the community.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, the National Crime Authority has performed sufficiently well-there is no question of that-in the short period of its existence to have led the Prime Minister, during the election campaign, to state clearly that the sunset clause of the legislation should be repealed. Instructions are going to Parliamentary Counsel to ensure that that legislation is brought in during the autumn session. In the meantime, the fact is that morale at the National Crime Authority is extremely high. In searching for a replacement for Mr Max Bingham, QC, we are having good candidates come forward because they understand the situation, namely, that the National Crime Authority will continue. Its precise form and scope of powers will still have to be subject to the report of the joint parliamentary committee, which has a pre-eminent role in making its assessment. I believe that the National Crime Authority is performing extremely well, and the intergovernmental committee is performing its function as it ought to in a democracy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 October, Senator Parer asked me a question concerning a letter which appeared in the 18 September edition of Australian Dr Weekly. Senator Parer asked whether there was any truth in the allegation made in the letter that a Department of Social Security officer advised a woman to insist that her doctor sign a certificate, against his better judgment, stating that she was permanently unemployable because of ill health. Senator Parer asked whether this was an isolated case and whether, in order to disguise unemployment figures, Social Security officers have been instructed to encourage long term unemployed people to apply for other benefits such as sickness benefit, invalid pension and special benefits. Inquiries have been made into the allegations the letter makes.

ANSWER.PARA: The allegations are wrong. The officer of the Department involved in the case followed proper procedure in informing the woman, who had told the Department that she was too ill to work, that if she wished to claim sickness benefit she would have to have a doctor's certification that she was unfit for work. If a person is temporarily unfit for work on medical grounds the proper benefit to be paid is sickness benefit-a short term benefit. There are regular reviews of those who have been receiving sickness benefit for more than a few weeks to ensure that they still qualify for the benefit and to determine, if they are still in need of social security assistance, whether a pension such as invalid pension or other benefit such as unemployment benefit, should be paid instead. There are no departmental instructions to staff to encourage long term unemployed people to apply for other benefits in order to reduce unemployment benefit numbers. In fact the statistics show clearly that no such thing is occurring. In the last year unemployment benefit numbers have declined by 60,230 while the number receiving sickness benefit has increased by only 9,850. The reduction in unemployment benefit numbers has occurred through the Government's economic policies which have increased employment, and through improved social security administration.

More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to recognise that a crisis of confidence has arisen in Australia's defence forces as a direct consequence of the policies of the Labor Government and a lack of both leadership and genuine concern about service pay and conditions by the Ministers for Defence and Defence Science and Personnel.

This is very much a matter of urgency for Australia. The situation in our defence forces and the crisis in confidence is something with which all Australians should be concerned. The Government clearly is not. When I look at the Government benches I see what little interest there is in this subject by the people who rule this land. Let them know that dissatisfaction in the Services has reached boiling point. It is leading to a severe decline in morale and in our defence capability. These are desperately serious matters. Even the very well oiled media machine of the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, has been unable to keep a lid on this boiling pot any longer. When one looks at the lack of leadership and protection that the Government gives to the servicemen and when one compares it with the leadership, co-operation and protection that it gives to its friends in the Australian Council of Trade Unions, one sees that there is a world of difference between the treatment of two very important areas of our community. One dines at the Government's table, the other catches the crumbs if it is able.

This dissatisfaction is not just affecting servicemen and their families; it is affecting all of us because of the enormous cost of replacing those who leave the Services and because it is also having the effect of leaving our country inadequately defended. The situation is so serious that the Opposition cannot sit by while the Government tells the nation that all is well, while it conceals and fudges the figures which show just how bad the situation is. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) is no longer releasing the monthly figures for separation rates. We have had quite an argument as to whether the September figures as published in the Australian and in Jane's Defence Weekly-two quite independent publications-are correct or whether they are as the Minister tells us. We suspect that a new accounting method-a creative accounting method-has entered the Department of Defence. I hope not, but maybe this is so-at the Government's urging. We on this side of the chamber will not rest until the problem is addressed and until these servicemen get a better deal.

I have been travelling around the country over the last few months talking to service men and women and their families. This is the job that the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel should have been doing. But have they been doing it? Not on your live. They are hiding away in coward's castle here. They either do not know, do not want to know or do not care what is happening. But we care. We know that the rate at which people are leaving the forces is at an all-time high. The number of people leaving the forces went from 6,700 in 1983-84 to 9,000 in 1986-87, and we expect it to be between 10,000 and 11,000 this year. It is absolutely disgraceful. The rate of officer resignations has gone from 5.4 per cent to 12 per cent over the same period. These figures do not lie. The Government should acknowledge them.

More and more service personnel are thinking about, and openly discussing, leaving the Services. This is starting to have an effect on operational tasks. It means that Australia is increasingly having difficulty in keeping its planes in the air, its ships at sea and its soldiers in the field. Mrs Kelly refuses to face the seriousness of this problem. She spends a considerable amount of time making creative and stupid comments about the subject. She has been telling the nation that it is good for morale. I can imagine only that she means that the few defence personnel who are left will get more rapid promotion. How else can it possibly be good for morale to see people leaving the forces in droves? She tells us that it is usual for pilots to leave. Of course it is, but not in the numbers we are suffering today. She tells us that it has something to do with women in the forces, that it has something to do with the Vietnam hump. She tells us that morale is something that she is working on. In case anybody should think that I am being creative I would like to quote some of Mrs Kelly's interviews with the media. On 10 August she told Pru Goward on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Morning Show:
. . . frankly, I think the whole issue is being incredibly exaggerated. There's no doubt there is an increase in our separation rates over previous years, but it isn't very dramatic.

An article which appeared in the Canberra Times the next day, 11 August, reports Mrs Kelly as saying that she `does not believe that there is a major problem with separation rates in the Services overall, but there are problems in some areas'. A week later she is reported in the Australian as saying that a high turnover was `not necessarily a bad thing unless it was concentrated in a few areas'. I think Mrs Kelly does not know what she is talking about. Whether she does know or she does not, when will she do something?

She had to be prodded into going to see the wives in Townsville. Honourable senators may recall that in this chamber I asked why she was not going to see the wives. She was going to see the men. Although she had been asked to see the Royal Australian Air Force and Australian Army wives, she was not going. Finally she went, but to do so she cancelled a visit to the wives in Brisbane. She has not seen them yet. When is she going to see the wives in Holsworthy? Next month. These are major defence establishments. Her job is to implement the recommendations of the Hamilton Review of the Effect of Service Life on Spouses to upgrade the conditions of service for service personnel. She is not getting around the country; she is not talking to the people who are suffering. The Hamilton report came out 18 months ago. It made 15 major recommendations and so far only one has been partially implemented. The Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service has just been established but it is still not operating. From this Government we get a lot of talk but we get very little action.

The Government has known for a long time that it had a problem, but it would not admit it. It has made it worse with its own stupid actions. I draw the Senate's attention to the cut to the Defence Force retirement and death benefits pension base last year. This scheme is contributory, with servicemen having to contribute 5.5 per cent of their income to the scheme. When we were debating the matter in September last year, Senator Walsh said:
. . . the measure does not affect conditions in the Australian Defence Force because, by definition, it affects only people who have retired from the Defence Forces.

If ever there is an example of the Government refusing to face the facts of what it is doing, those words of Senator Walsh should say it all. The Government will not face up to the fact that these cuts affect the confidence and morale of defence personnel. The Government is breaking the deals on the basis of which personnel enlisted in the first place.

There have been inexcusable delays in setting up the Defence Housing Authority. The Government will find the problem far worse than it has admitted when the Authority finally gets under way. There is no service spouse representation on the Defence Housing Authority, just a token female with `experience in social planning' on the interim board. The Government could appoint a spouse to the Authority under clause 26 but it has not. I urge it to do so. The Government is treating defence personnel on the same basis as it treats public servants who sleep in warm, dry beds every night of their lives. We know about the unrealistic service allowances. Personnel, in their latest increase, got about an extra $1 an hour in overtime, which is just nonsense. They are working up to 55 hours a week. The Department was arguing against the interests of its own personnel.

There are unreal restrictions on the education allowance to help personnel finance their children's education. Only 87 families out of the 70,000 defence personnel receive an education allowance. Minister Kelly set up Helen Mayer as a consultant at a great cost to the nation to find out once again what the problems are. The Government should be finding the solutions. Far too many studies have been done already. Believe it or not, we discovered in an Estimates committee hearing the other night that the Department's defence housing repairs and maintenance vote has been cut. Can honourable senators imagine what that will do to the morale of the forces, whose members are already, by the Department's own admission, living in sub-standard accommodation. As an economy measure, the thing the Government cuts is repairs and maintenance to defence families' housing. That must be just about the end for some families who cannot get repairs done to their sub-standard houses. The standard of housing, we know, is one of the major reasons why people leave the forces.

The change to the defence service homes loans scheme that was announced in the Budget is the last straw for our service men and women. There was no consultation. They are furious. I remind the Senate that at the very time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was taking the salute at the welcome home parade for the Vietnam veterans-20 years too late-he was ripping off home loans for today's servicemen. Clearly, the leopard does not change his spots.

Families from far north Queensland to southern Tasmania have spoken to me. They have cried out for help. For the first time they are holding public meetings, they are sending letters, they are signing petitions and they are getting publicity in the newspapers. This is unknown for service people. They are quiet, conservative people devoted to serving the government of the day. By `conservative' I do not mean conservative in politics, but that their way of life traditionally is out of the public eye. Their dissatisfaction has been evidenced by the unprecedented step of holding public meetings. It is evidenced by the motion that was passed at the Holsworthy public meeting the other night:

This meeting condemns the Government for its failure to consult with the services over the defence services home loan scheme and calls on the Government to preserve all existing benefits available under the scheme.

It is absolutely remarkable for a public meeting of service men and women and their families to condemn the government they serve. It may be a common or garden-type action outside the defence forces but it is unheard of inside.

The dissatisfaction of service personnel is also evidenced by documents which are starting to fall off the backs of Land Rovers and wash off the backs of submarines. This may happen in other departments, but it has not been the way of the Department of Defence. Dissatisfaction is evidenced by claims that have been made to me that answers to the Estimates committee have been cooked by the Department, a most serious allegation and one that I understand can be proved. It is evidenced by a very courageous general, the commander of the First Division, who spoke out recently in the Australian about the effects of this problem on our defence capability. It is evidenced by the anger, unhappiness and confusion which was so eloquently expressed at the Holsworthy meeting. Five hundred Army, Royal Australian Navy and Air Force personnel and their spouses packed a public hall on a wet night to complain about what the Government is doing to their conditions of service. But there were no Ministers there to listen to them.

Three invitations were sent to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) but not one was acknowledged, let alone answered. He is well known, of course, for his preference for the equipment side of his portfolio. Mrs Kelly found it more convenient to attend a private engagement in Sydney the same night. I can assume only that her earlier meeting with the wives in Townsville has taken away her taste for such meetings. Sadly, the families who went to that meeting left more fearful than when they arrived. It is incredible to recount, but Mrs Kelly's public service representative told that meeting that the Government could do what it liked to conditions and pay; it could put them up or put them down. I suppose it will come as no surprise to honourable senators that he, the messenger whom the Minister sent to her defence personnel, was howled down.

Those families have a right to be outraged. They have been treated as second-class citizens. They are in a quite different position from other Australians. They have no right to organise their labour. They cannot fight back when conditions are taken away from them. They see their conditions and their treatment by the Government as a breach of their contract of employment. The soldiers, sailors and airmen that night said, `What gives the Government the right to change the rules? Why should servicemen not break their contracts and get out now?'. One private soldier said that the wives are having to take all this action because the soldiers cannot speak up. They have to go through proper channels. But their officers cannot help them; their officers do not know the answers. The officers have a lack of trust and confidence in the Government. The soldiers end up having a lack of confidence and trust in their officers. What are we doing to our defence forces? This Government must stand condemned.

I want to quote very briefly from a letter which was sent to the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, on 14 October by the Townsville Area Consultative Group of Service Spouses. I quote a couple of paragraphs:
It is clear that the recent Budget proposal to introduce a $10,000 grant to replace the DSHL-
that is, the defence service home loan-

was either ill conceived or has been deliberately introduced without regard for the human dimension of the problem. There are many significant cases where both serving members and retired veterans are grossly disadvantaged by the loss of a previously accepted condition of service. Apart from the loss of trust this has engendered, there are numerous cases of real hardship and anguish caused by the precipitate way in which the issue has been presented.
A further paragraph states:
As representatives of the TACGSS we wish to inform the Minister that our people feel insulted and indeed betrayed by the proposed withdrawal of the DSHL.
A further paragraph states:
You should be aware that there is a ground swell of concern in our community which is taking a form of mistrust of the Government's motives in all areas of service conditions.

What a damning letter for the Minister for Defence to receive. These are the people who have taken pride in their service and who have felt that the job they had to do was a vital one and was honoured as such by their fellow Australians and by their governments. They feel they are being cheated now on their defence service home loans. I do not have time to go into that in detail but, when honourable senators know that 56 per cent of the applications for defence service loans in fact come from existing servicemen, they will realise just how the changes to this scheme will affect them dramatically. The Government is now making noises that it is changing its proposals that were in the Budget, but there is still unsatisfactory consultation with the servicemen because, although the Returned Services League, public servants and one businessman will be represented, this working group will not have a representative of the Armed Forces Federation of Australia, it will not have a representative of the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses and it will not have a representative of servicemen's welfare organisations.

Although we have real difficulties due to separations of the defence forces, we have even more difficulties because of the ceiling which this Government has set on them. The terminal strength for the Australian Army will be under 32,000. That will be extremely tight and is likely to affect the field force capability. That was acknowledged by the Department in Estimates Committee E hearings. The lesson already being learned on Diamond Dollar, the exercise in Queensland, is that the job of coping with a low level threat in that area is very labour intensive. It is a big area. There are bridges and microwave dishes to be dealt with. With the limited manpower, men get tired from being on duty around the clock, and they need reinforcements. But the resupply of men and equipment is very difficult because of the lack of amphibious lift capacity, and that too partly depends on manpower. The Government has been warned over and over again. Rear-Admiral Ralph, Deputy Chief of Naval Staff, said that three landing craft heavies had had to be laid up because of manpower priorities and they may not have the ability to reintroduce one into service because of a shortage of manpower. Major-General Fitzgerald, the Deputy Chief of the General Staff, told the Estimates Committee that the Army was taking one medium battery off the order of battle and was moving one troop of air defence weapons battery and one squadron of the armoured regiment to the Reserve.

We have heard a lot about pilots. We have lost 75 in the last three months. Air Vice- Marshal Bradford, the Deputy Chief of the Air Staff, said at the Estimates Committee hearings that there are not enough qualified flying instructors and the ability to make up the shortfall is limited. I could go on and on. There is a crisis of confidence throughout the Defence Force between the servicemen and their officers and between the officers and the Government. This has led to a critical situation. Our fathers' generation was appalled by the suggestion that we might be able to defend Australia only south of the Brisbane line. God forbid that this becomes a reality under this Government.
