TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman has such a penchant for grandstanding that she could have built the Melbourne Cricket Ground in a day. I have noticed a rather curious fact emerging from the Opposition. Opposition female members of parliament seem to keep a bit of extra vitriol up their sleeve when attacking female Labor Ministers. It has become most noticeable in this chamber. I am curious about it, but I cannot explain it.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the points raised by Senator Newman first off was that Mrs Kelly was not getting around to enough defence establishments. I point out that we have been in fairly constant session here in Parliament. The moment Ministers disappear off on duty, Senator Chaney or someone else jumps up and makes the point that they are unavailable at Question Time and that their real duty is to be here in the chamber. Mrs Kelly has made a major effort to get to as many defence establishments as is possible, given the constraints on meeting times in this chamber.

Of course, Senator Newman raised the question of cuts in superannuation and was obviously arguing that those on Australian Defence Force (ADF) retirement pensions should be exempted, in isolation from the rest of the community. The reality is that those cuts last year were brought about by this Government wanting to share the sacrifice amongst all sections of the community. We had a high inflation rate in this country, induced primarily by the collapse in our terms in trade, by an external factor, and so all pensioners and all groups were asked to make a one-off sacrifice. Many people in the defence area have written to members of parliament saying that they were happy to be included in that whole group in the community, although obviously not all were happy.

I want to make one or two additional points. Firstly, this Government has appointed a Minister responsible for defence personnel for the first time. Secondly, what did the Liberal Party of Australia do? How important does it regard defence? The shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), has now left the gallery, but he is not even placed in the shadow Cabinet. That is how irrelevant the Opposition regards defence. It will not even include the shadow Defence Minister in the shadow Cabinet.

Never before has a government been more committed to Australia's defence and, more importantly, to improving the well-being and conditions of service for Australian Defence Force personnel and their families. In March 1987 the Defence Minister, Kim Beazley, tabled the Government's White Paper on defence. The paper outlines this Government's strategy for defence self-reliance within a framework of our alliances and regional associations. It set out the direction for the Australian Defence Force within realistic budget parameters. The paper was very well received by the Australian Defence Force, the Returned Services League and generally throughout the community-and, I might add, by the Opposition. The Canberra Times, in its editorial of 2 April 1987, said:
It is a good, sensible White Paper. It pays proper regard to financial constraints, and the nation can have confidence in it.

The Opposition has no credibility in the defence debate. For example, Mr Sinclair calls for more spending on defence. At the same time, Mr Howard wants more tax cuts. The reality is that, under the tories, cuts in defence expenditure will be inevitable. This would affect the whole gamut of defence activity-new equipment, housing and pay.

The record of the coalition in government in the defence area is abysmal. The answer to that is very simple. First of all, it instituted a wage freeze on the defence forces. We saw a general erosion of conditions in the Defence Force in its time in government and we saw a general deterioration in housing standards. We must ask ourselves: Were the Opposition ever to regain government, would it be able to agree on what it would cut in the future? I would be interested to know what items it would scrap to redeploy defence expenditure. Would it cut out the six new submarines, the 39 Black Hawk helicopters; the eight light patrol frigates, the 6,000 radios for the Army, the 67,000 new Steyr rifles, the 3,000 trucks for the Army, or the 75 FA18 aircraft for the Air Force? Why does the Opposition not come clean and tell us exactly where its expenditure cuts in defence would be and what its policies would be? Or is it saying, `We can slosh another $5, $6 or $8 billion into defence expenditure'? If members of the Opposition come into this chamber and say that they had better detail all their other policy cuts because they are on record as saying that they want balanced budgets. They want tax cuts as well. They are trying to have their cake and eat it.

The Opposition's record on defence strategy is highlighted by a number of factors. The first is a mesmorisation about aircraft carriers, which has been legendary in this chamber over the last few years. Opposition members have set their sights on aircraft carriers as a be-all and an end-all. Secondly, whenever they can, they send expeditionary forces to far off places. They have a total lack of understanding about Australia's defence requirements. They invent fanciful threats which absolutely skewers Australia's defence policy. Look at the gaps they left in Australia's defence policy: no minesweeping capability, inadequate mobility for the Army, a lack of infrastructure in the north, a one-ocean Navy, no joint operational command system and no air to air refuelling. That is the legacy that the Opposition left the Government in this area. Time after time it left massive gaps in the defence area.

Those opposite are incorrect in asserting that there has been a reduction in the operational capabilities of the Australian defence forces. For the first time in the nation's history, this Government has put in place a comprehensive buildup in Australia's Defence Force tailored to our unique strategic circumstances. This is something that the Opposition has failed to do through its decades of neglect of developing a Defence Force capable of defending Australia. This Government, in having a realistic regard, firstly, to our unique strategic circumstances, and, secondly, to the economic realities, seeks to achieve a balance between investment in new capabilities, ADF operations which emphasise credible contingencies, and redressing the Opposition's neglect of such important matters as Service housing and single living accommodation. Members opposite did not provide this country with a viable Defence Force capable of defending the nation, its sovereignty and its vital interests.

Let me turn to the area which Senator Newman concentrated on most-that is, conditions of service. This Government is concerned to ensure that Australian defence personnel and their families receive proper and acceptable conditions of service. This Government has acted properly in regard to gradually improving conditions for the Australian Defence Force in the areas of pay and housing. This Government was not responsible for the wage freeze; those opposite introduced the wage freeze and of course, they continue to oppose all extra pay grants anywhere in the economy. Can honourable senators remember when Liberal senators last supported a pay rise, assuming, of course, that doctors' salaries are not regarded as a pay rise? Of course, they do not. They will be back to their old tricks of wage freezes, once again badly affecting the defence forces.

Our record on pay and allowances is a proven one. We created an independent pay tribunal to which defence personnel have direct access. Defence personnel have received all national wage increases. Specialist allowances for submarines, general service and personnel who serve in the field have recently been increased. The submarine service allowance led to an increase of over 100 per cent, the general service allowance was increased by 22 per cent, and the field allowance was increased from $4.01 per day to $12 per day. The Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal is shortly to examine a request to increase flying allowances. The Government has taken steps to protect the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme. The 2 per cent discount applied in 1986 was the same as for general wage earners. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has indicated that the Government will legislate to restore that minor discount when economic circumstances permit.

I move now to the question of housing. This Government has legislated to create a Defence Housing Authority. We debated this in this chamber some weeks ago. Seventy-five million dollars has been allocated to defence housing in this Budget. A further $60m is being allocated to single person accommodation and $750m will be spent on new and improved housing over the next decade. The Opposition is responsible, in the main, for the sorry state of defence housing. This Government is doing much to redress that neglect.

On housing rents, defence personnel can be assured that the Government will continue to be fair and reasonable. The majority of defence personnel pay less than $50 a week for housing. Under the tories opposite those rents would increase to over $100 a week, as foreshadowed by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who wants to privatise all housing. Before the last election the honourable member for O'Connor went around this country saying, `We will privatise housing but we will not put any limits on the rents'. If honourable senators opposite ever got back into power, people's rents would move from $50 to $100 overnight and that cannot be denied. Opposition senators know that the honourable member for O'Connor went round the country. I am sure that it shocked and disappointed them because it lost them a lot of votes at the last election.

As foreshadowed in the Budget, consultations are continuing to improve the defence home loans scheme. The Government is examining options for greater flexibility in the new arrangements and a decision on them can be expected shortly. As a result of the report of the Hamilton Review of the Effects of Service Life on Spouses, to which Senator Newman has alluded, a national consultative group of spouses has been formed. It provides a forum for defence spouses to present conditions of service concerns to the Chief of the Defence Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you won't consult them on it.

—What did the previous Liberal Government do about this? Absolutely nothing. The problem with honourable senators opposite is that they talk big about defence but then they put no money in whatsoever. They talk patriotically about defending the defence forces and about the people in those defence forces, but when it comes to the bottom line of helping them out, honourable senators opposite are in the land of the missing. They should remember that since 1939 they have had 30 years in government to redress a lot of the problems of the defence forces, but all they have ever done is try to exploit defence for political points. Honourable senators opposite can go back through history, if they like, to the various times under Menzies and other Prime Ministers when foreign policy in defence matters was dictated not by the strategic needs of Australia but by the strategic needs of the Liberal Party of Australia. It got all sorts of McCarthyist campaigns going in which it could look more patriotic than anyone else. Now that kicking the communist can has gone down the drain, we have this bogus militarism from those opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go to the question of separation rates for the Defence Force. The average rate for the last 10 years has been 11.1 per cent. In 1986-87 that rate of separation rose to 12.8 per cent. We are obviously concerned about the increase in the separation rate and we are making a variety of policy decisions to help turn that around. It is important to note that the separation rates have in fact reflected certain changes in our society that may be with us for the foreseeable future. Conditions of society do change-and that does affect overall separation rates-not the least of which is that we have been able to establish far many more employment opportunities in this country. Many hundreds of thousands of jobs have been created in the life of this Labor Government, which provide many other alternative forms of employment that were not available in those dark, dingy Fraser days when unemployment went through the roof, and many people may have joined the armed forces, not out of desire to serve in those forces, but because it was an available opportunity at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying you are a training ground for Qantas pilots?

—Senator Messner raises the question of pilots, and let us look at that. For over 20 years the average loss rate has been 47 per year. In 1985-86 that rose to 70, and to 107 in 1986-87, and so far this year the figure is 75. The average number of pilots graduating per year is 55 to 65. So obviously that, of all the separation rates in the armed forces, is the one that would give the Government most concern. Of course there are complex reasons why the Royal Australian Air Force has been so affected. First of all, there is no doubt that the influence of Qantas Airways Ltd and its recruiting policies has had an effect on accelerating the separation rate, because what we are seeing in this country under the enlightened Labor Government is a massive increase in tourism, the fastest growing industry in this country. As a result of that-we need only to have read the newspapers in the last few days-Qantas has had to put on an extra 137 flights to cover the peak period. But we are getting many more in-bound passengers and Australians returning here, and therefore pilots are at premium demand.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as that, we have obviously had to take steps to remedy that situation. The responsible Minister has met with Mr Menadue from Qantas, and a whole range of measures have been adopted to minimise those recruiting policies. It is also true to say that pilots are very expensive to train and so to lift the training rate automatically and immediately is not easy. We are intending to increase the Service obligations from six to eight years. The Chief of the Air Staff is taking other steps. We are working towards increasing the compulsory retiring age of pilots of wing commander rank to 55 years.

In conclusion in looking at the motion, as I said at the start, Senator Newman is of course grandstanding on this issue. It has been her speciality to go around and to try, if you like, to lock into these particular issues. I welcome the fact that Senator Newman specialises in this area. I think it is one of the functions of parliamentarians. The fact that she is so blinkered and does not consider or think about anything else is probably a tragedy for this chamber, because I am sure that we could listen with a lot of interest to her yapping away on a lot of other subjects. But the reality is that today she has totally failed to make out a case because she has a certain disease that is applicable to all of those opposite, and that is political amnesia. Opposition senators have suddenly fallen to earth since 1983 and have started to make comments on politics. They have just wiped their responsibility for the period 1975 to 1983. It is like a black hole. Everything disappears into it, nothing exists. That is what they are saying. They say: `We have no responsibility for it'. It is like trying to find a nazi in Germany after the Second World War. Everyone says: `No, it wasn't me, it was someone else'. That is what they used to say. It is very hard to find a Fraser supporter. Where are they? Every time I challenge them in the Senate to say who over there in fact supported Fraser, they all say: `No, no I was not really a Fraser man. I have learnt. I am not responsible for the events of 1975 to 1983'.

Once again those opposite come into this chamber and criticise this Government, which has taken more constructive steps on defence and poured more money into defence than the proper strategic thinking in the area of defence and all they can do is whinge and whine, because they have lost their ace up the sleeve. Their chance to bleat about defence and accuse this Government and the Labor Party of not caring about defence has now gone. They can no longer get out into the electorate and try to take advantage of it. This urgency motion is a contemptible one and it deserves to be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats in essence support the thrust of this urgency motion, but we do have some reservations about it. Obviously we must acknowledge that there is a crisis of confidence in Australia's defence forces. The evidence of that is overwhelming. This crisis is not recent. In fact, although it has climaxed in recent years, it has existed for several decades. It is the product of several governments. In all fairness we must acknowledge that it has a long history, if we are to understand it and if we are to react responsibly to it. In that respect the Opposition is not innocent. Reference was made earlier in this debate by Senator Newman to the fact that there have recently been reductions in the Defence Force retirement benefits allowances. We make the observation that the Australian Democrats were the only party in this chamber to vote against such reductions and at that time the Opposition voted with the Government. That happened as recently as the last 12 months. However, as I said, this has a long history. The decline of our defence forces goes back over several decades and several governments. I simply ask the Opposition to acknowledge its fair share of neglect.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Government is in a bind. It has committed itself to reductions in expenditure and, therefore, when it comes to the area of defence, it addresses itself to the four main dimensions of defence policy; namely, the organisational dimension, the materiel dimension, the personnel dimension and the management dimension. The Government is presented with really only two opportunities to cut expenditure and they are in the areas of materiel and personnel. I believe that there is a bias in the Government's present defence posture and let us refer to it as the Beazley bias.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a big one, too.

—As Senator Richardson points out, it is a considerable bias and it is a bias in favour of materiel as opposed to personnel. We think that is most unfortunate and we are now beginning to see the implications of it. I would like to probe the implications of it, as the Opposition has done, quite effectively I believe, over the last 10 or 12 days. If there is a Beazley bias, there is also a Beazley neglect, as I have just pointed out and that Beazley neglect covers the whole area of personnel management in our Services. These biases are reflected in the Dibb report on the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, in the White Papers and in the other statements that have been made in the other place as well as from the Government benches in the Senate. The most recent suggestions of bias have come from the Defence Budget statement, which is an interesting document. On 9 October Senator Ray, representing the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) incorporated the document in Hansard. But as we were not treated to some of the rhetorical gems inherent in it therefore I would like to quote some of them, because it is quite extraordinary to think that the Government can incorporate a statement such as this as recently as 17 days ago, supposedly for us to accept it as valid 17 days ago, only to be confronted today by a well-founded urgency motion from Senator Newman, in support of the earlier urgency motion the subject of which, through a motion moved by Senator Messner, now finds itself before a Senate committee. Let us look at this dreamtime document which was the Government's defence budget statement. It says that this defence budget:

SPEECH.PARA: is the first in which the delineation of Australia's Defence Force for the 1990's and into the 21st century can clearly be separated from the concepts and strategies of the 1950s and 1960s.

In other words, we are told that this Government is taking a quantum leap forward into the next century in its defence planning. We will be citing evidence to the contrary. Such evidence has already been cited by Senator Newman. I quote further from the statement:
This Government believes that our service men and women should know that they are members of an organisation that has clear cut direction-
that would seem appropriate-
that they are at the heart of the most fundamental of national responsibilities-the security of the nation; and that the Government takes its responsibilities for defence seriously.
It goes on to cite efficiency improvements in the last two years, which it says are now providing-this is a beautiful phrase-`a dividend to defence'. We are told:
The role of the reserve forces has been given higher status than at any time since World War II.
The Minister also says:
I am pleased to be able to report to the Parliament-
get this one-
that the ADF is responding very well. Australia's service men and women did not join up for an easy life. They joined for a challenging life and to serve their country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that disgusting?

—It is an extraordinary statement in the document incorporated in Hansard in this place 17 days ago, presumably for us to accept as credible. The responses to that document by the Australian Democrats and the Opposition were, I believe, reasonable and responsible. They rejected them outright. The Opposition, in its urgency motion of 20 October, cited the bias and sought to focus the Senate's attention upon it by referring it to an appropriate committee. I commend Senator Messner for the contents of that motion. It is interesting to cite the action of the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate at that time, Senator Gareth Evans. He acknowledged, albeit reluctantly, that this was an appropriate thing to do. In fact, he used this colourful phrase:

SPEECH.PARA: Without any enthusiasm-
that is understandable-
but with a healthy sense of realism . . .

He said that the Government has a healthy sense of realism about the state of defence in this country at the moment. Good heavens-the document that was incorporated 17 days ago is hardly one of inherent realism. Nevertheless, the present Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate has said that he has a healthy sense of realism about the situation. Let us hope that that realism comes through in his reaction to this urgency motion. Obviously, the Government will not support it, but hopefully it will react to it. That is what we are striving for-action and reaction. We accept the limitations of this chamber. We accept the limitations of the political play within it, but we do have a reasonable and responsible expectation of the Government-that it will react.

These limitations of present defence posture were probed, I must say very diligently, by both Senator Newman and Senator MacGibbon in the Estimates committee hearing, and they have come to an appropriate focus in the Press recently. As honourable senators will know, in today's and yesterday's Press a number of items have cited the extraordinary and incredibly poor state of morale in this country's defence forces. Air Marshal Funnell in fact provided statements to David Humphries of the Age, citing a number of pertinent facts, which have already been stated by previous speakers in this debate and to which I will not return now.

In essence, this is a question of morale within the defence forces. As I have said previously, morale is the second principle of war. It should, I would imagine, be the second principle of defence preparedness. It would be hard to imagine any organisation in our community where morale is in a more shattered, depleted state than that which is evident in our defence forces today. Morale is a complex phenomenon. As a former serving officer, I would like to cite some of its dimensions. I would like to paint, in fact, the psychological-cum-social-cum-domestic situation which has engendered this extraordinarily low level of morale and which renders it understandable. Let us look at three aspects of morale: those which affect service men and women specifically, such as pay and conditions, leadership, career structures, opportunities inside the Services, a sense of relevance of serving and the organisation in which one is serving having a sense of relevance to the community which it is serving; an appropriateness of training; and a comparison with opportunities outside the Services. In any of those senses service men and women have every reason to be demoralised. Those are the dimensions of the morale of the people within the Services.

Let us look at the general social context and the way in which Australia has reacted to people in the Services in the post-Vietnam situation. I recall having been a serviceman and having served under a standing order from my unit which told me not to wear my uniform to work. Would honourable senators believe that for a certain time in this country serving members were under an order not to wear their uniform in the community which they were serving?

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that?

—That was from 1970 through to 1974, when they would have been harangued and ridiculed by virtue of the community attitude towards them in the post-Vietnam climate. We in this Party and we on this side of the chamber aspire to peace, as does everybody in this chamber, but in this atmosphere of growing peace aspirations, being in the Services can be seen as having moderately negative connotations. Let us look at the context of the service family. The report produced by Sue Hamilton, Supporting Service Families, has been cited by both the previous speakers. It enunciates quite clearly the social, domestic and psychological climate in which spouses of Australian service men and women live.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the dimensions which affect them. One is pay and the inability to attract supplementary income. If these people seek such income they are asked what their husband or wife does for a living. If they say that their spouse is a service man or woman they are told, `Sorry, we are not interested.', for the simple reason that their pattern of movement and their general assurance about remaining in that location and being able to hold down the job are called into question, even though this might be unrealistic. The dimension of housing is horrific. Education is another dimension. My own children went to 14 schools in 10 years while I was in the regular Army. The constant requirement to move one's family around and hence relocate one's children from one school to another only adds to this extraordinary dislocation. There is the turbulence associated with what was for many years the concept of posting everybody without question, just moving them willy nilly, every two years. Every resignation in the Services today necessitates a whole chain of movement, of children in schools and of families from home to home. This takes place simply to accommodate the incredible turbulence associated with the extraordinary resignation rate.

In a question addressed to the Minister for Defence on 20 October or thereabouts, I cited the impact of travel. I do not see the solution to these problems as being easy. Clearly there has to be an urgent dramatic short term response on the part of our Government to arrest this extraordinary erosion of our Services, otherwise there will not be any. But in the long term the traditional models of organisation do not have the answer. We will have to be far more imaginative and far more dramatic. I and my colleagues in the Australian Democrats will be attempting in the next few months to put forward models which we believe address the long term problems of reversing morale in the defence forces. I sense that there is great urgency about the conditions of service. I commend the Opposition for bringing the urgency motion forward and, with some reservation, which I enunciated earlier, the Democrats support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt that the matter we are discussing this afternoon is a matter of urgency. We are talking about the crisis of confidence which has arisen in the defence forces in this country as a result of the Labor Government's lack of leadership and concern about the pay and conditions of the men and women who make up the defence services. It is a matter of urgency; it is a matter of morale. This afternoon the Government led its case through the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray. He suggested that, in his opinion, we were suffering from political amnesia.
—Where is he now?

—He has left the chamber and that is a pity. However, I remind him that we do not suffer from political amnesia. I ask him to remember who ordered the leopard tanks that could not travel around this country because they could not cross our bridges. It was the Whitlam Government. We have not forgotten the xenophobia of the Government over the North West Cape. We know that we cannot trust Labor in matters of defence, because it has a split personality. Senator Ray also said that the Government was committed to Australia's defence, and that may be so. Some of the things he said in today's debate may even have been quite relevant to a different topic but they were not relevant to this one. We are concerned about the people who make up the defence forces-the men and women and their families. We know that unless they get satisfaction from their jobs everything else is meaningless. Commitment to defence is meaningless without a commitment to the people who are in our defence forces. As was said at the address to the graduating class of the United States Naval Academy in June 1942:

SPEECH.PARA: Machines are as nothing without men. Men are as nothing without morale.

The morale of our defence forces is what we are debating today. These days we hear about separation rates. What does the term `separation rates' mean? The word `separation' is used in many places. It is a highly imaginative euphemism for what is really happening-the decimation of the armed services as thousands upon thousands of skilled men and women are driven from their chosen careers by the failure of the Government to restore the morale of the members of the armed forces and their families. Once upon a time we talked about the resignation rate in the Services. A few would resign here and a few there but most service personnel served out their terms quite happily and then went on their way. For a while we heard about the wastage rate but obviously that term was not too popular-it had a nasty ring to it-so now we have the rather fanciful term `separation rate'.

Let us get back to the reality of what we are talking about. Let us abandon the Hawkespeak of separation rates and face up to the fact that what we have seen is a driving from the armed forces of thousands of men and women who chose this career because it was what they wanted to do. They chose a career in which they knew they would be making some sacrifices. They knew they would be moving more often than other people and they knew they would be away from their families at times. However, they felt it was a career that was worth while and it was something to which they wanted to be committed for themselves, their families and their country. What has happened? Those sentiments have been destroyed. This Government has destroyed that sort of commitment. In passing I mention that the Government has also destroyed the commitment of nurses in this country. Nursing is a profession which consists mainly of women who were totally dedicated to what they were doing but because their conditions and wages in recent times have been so poorly attended to we have had strikes in the nursing profession. This situation has not occurred just in the defence forces.

We have been getting the figures relating to those who have resigned from the Services on a monthly basis but they have obviously become so embarrassing to the Government that that has been abandoned. I remind honourable members that it was a Labor Minister for Defence, Lance Barnard, who in 1973 introduced monthly figures for those resigning from the armed forces. He said the reason for introducing this measure was that it was `consistent with the Government's policy of informing the community of pertinent defence matters'. I can only conclude that by 1987 it is Labor policy to see that the community is not informed of pertinent defence matters. The last known resignation rate figures were a disgrace; in June 1987 the figure was 749. Can the Government deny that in July the figure was 1,000 and for August it was 823, including a total of 215 officers? That is an indication that 10,000 men and women will be lost from the Services during 1987 and 1988.

There has been the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, the White Paper and the Hamilton Review of the Effect of Service Life on Spouses. There is no need for there to be such delay in dealing with these important matters. A tribunal brought in a virtually meaningless response to the plight of the armed services. Somehow it decided that 40 hours a week was the average number of hours worked per week in the Services. The evidence given was 52 hours and I cannot think of anyone who would not accept that as being the more likely figure. That is part of the reason why its report generally has been treated as it has.

I want to talk specifically about what it really means to be a service family and what such families have had to put up with. As has been mentioned, the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme has been cut by 2 per cent. Who really believes that the Government will get around to restoring it even if the economy does improve under this Government, which is unlikely. The conditions of service are atrocious. Let us look at them. Nobody is suggesting that in the past there have not been imperfections, and there is no need to go into them in great detail because that fact is accepted and acknowledged. For four years this Government has failed to address the issues that are now coming to a head. With whatever imperfections there have been in the past resignation rates have never been anything like what they are now, as has already been stated in this debate. Of 23,000 Defence Force homes, 12,000 fail to meet the requirements of service scales and standards for accommodation; 6,000 of these have been earmarked for demolition-in other words they have been condemned-but they are still occupied by our defence personnel and their families.

We are told that $75m has been allocated this year to Defence Force housing but let us not forget that $65m of that amount relates to projects that have already been commenced, so the figure needs to be looked at for what it really is. Of that amount, $28m is committed to the new developments at Tindal in the Northern Territory. I am not suggesting that they are not needed but let us get into perspective the housing figure which is being cited. The standard of housing of most of our Defence Force personnel is appalling. I want to talk about the wives, and the conditions in which they have lived. Every time they move they have to change their carpets, their floor coverings. If honourable senators do not think that is costly, I can assure them that it is. The wife of a serving officer who recently retired told me that she had moved 32 times in 32 years. One can imagine the cost of just the floor coverings. As a consequence there is no possibility that personnel can ever afford to have the sort of floor coverings they would like; they are constantly having to make do.

I now turn to adequate security arrangements. More often then not when a family moves into a house they have to spend money changing locks, getting locks fixed and having the house adequately secured. They bear that cost. Many houses are without adequate heating or, in some instances, adequate cooling. In some cases no heating is supplied at all. Honourable senators can imagine that cost which a normal family does not have to bear. Many older houses have no built-in wardrobes, no built-in cupboards, and so service personnel are put to the cost of providing that sort of furniture. They probably have to buy their furniture cheaply, secondhand, and they are not able to live in the sorts of conditions that they would like or would like to provide for their families.

Frequently, on moving to a new house, one has to put up new curtain rods. Honourable senators opposite might smile or laugh at this and think that a few curtain rods are neither here nor there, but it all adds up when it comes to trying to balance a meagre defence family budget. Other things include flyscreens and insulation; and, if one has young children, one must make sure that the fences around the house are high enough to ensure that toddlers do not wander away. That is an additional expense. Little things such as exhaust fans in the kitchens and bathrooms of these old houses, if they are there at all, rarely work and must be attended to. Many of these houses do not have any sort of lock-up shed or accommodation where things can be stored and no shelves or high cupboards where dangerous substances or medicines can be kept. There are no non-slip surfaces on outside steps and no safety rails on high verandahs. Honourable senators may think that this has little to do with defence, but it has a lot to do with the quality of life and the stress that these families are placed under as they move around the country every two years, as suggested by the previous speaker. However, with the resignation rate as it is, relocation is much more frequent: people must move about and uproot everything and start again; take their children out of school and shift them perhaps into a totally new system; change uniforms for their children and buy new ones; and cope with the social changes of their children, who must leave friends behind and make new friends. That places extra stress on families.

What about the careers that so many women must give up when they are part of a defence force family? They are not able to pursue careers in the way that they would like. These people are entitled to a wage which compensates for some of the things that I have loosely mentioned this afternoon. That is what we are talking about-the number of moves. For example, I can describe the difference in Canberra between the rate of pay for serving personnel and the rate for non-uniform personnel working in the same place. I refer to two men-one in uniform the other not-living at Wanniassa and both working out at Fairbairn. Because there are no buses to Fairbairn the non-uniform man receives extra money, but the person in uniform does not receive any extra money and must bear the cost associated with travelling a long way to get to work. That is the reality. I know of men in uniform in Canberra who have second jobs working for security firms to try to make ends meet and support their families, especially when they have young children. They move away from their extended family to areas where perhaps they do not know many people to whom they can call for support. It is particularly difficult then for the wife to go out to work because the children need their mother at home when there is not the sort of support that a young family can get in other circumstances.

The Government says that it is acting on the Hamilton report. That is correct to an extent, but it has had 18 months and it has not made much progress so far. In reality, the Government has done nothing more than set up the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service, which is not yet operational. The first positions in the new organisation were advertised only last month. It really will be more than a year until it is fully operational, which is some 2 1/2 years after the report. Recruitment has virtually only just started, and I think that that is a disgrace. It indicates that the emphasis in defence is not on the men and women of our serving forces.

Recently, substantial changes were announced to the defence service home loans scheme without consultation. The Government has now backed down from that but the arrangement was to replace the low interest $25,000 loan with a cash grant of $10,000 and to privatise the scheme. That may have worked well, but this other arrangement sent fear into the hearts of most serving officers and men in our armed forces. As I said, the Government has backed down but it is another nail in the coffin of morale when these things are done, and that is why the resignation rate is so high. It distresses me enormously to find that people that I have known for a long time, friends of mine who believed in their careers, are resigning because they see no future in the armed forces. They see no point in being a part of the armed services of this country. That is a tragedy. It is a crisis. It is a matter of urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator McKiernan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman also placed some stress on talking not only to service men and women but also to the wives. Finally, in the latter part of the twentieth century, those who make up the Opposition are recognising the value of the role that women in this society, including servicewomen and wives of servicemen, are playing in the Australian armed forces and in Australia in total. TALK.START.PARA: —That is what he said; not what you said a minute ago.
—That is what he said-cut wages. If there is no wage case--
—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: there is no way that it can be interpreted that a suggestion that the national wage case should go ahead means that there will be a cut in wages.
—There is no point of order.
