If the wage increase is not passed on at a particular period, there will be a wage cut. That is what the Opposition is about. The stock market has supposedly crashed, but I would say that it has readjusted itself to the levels of 12 months ago.

—I wish to raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. The honourable senator seems to be a long way from any relevance to the subject under debate. He is talking about the stock market and the national wage case. The matter before the Chair is the need to recognise that there is a crisis of confidence in Defence Force morale. I ask the Chair to call the honourable senator to order.
— Order! Other honourable senators have strayed to the extent Senator McKiernan has. There is no point of order.

—If Senator Newman had been in the chamber at the time, she would have heard reference to service pay, and that is what I am talking about. The Labor Government has brought these payments up to a reasonable standard. We would like to do a lot more, but unfortunately circumstances will not allow it. I argue that if the present Opposition were now in power it would repeat the performance of the 1930s and probably bring in a British economist to cut wages even further than the Opposition is suggesting at the moment. One has to recognise and put on record what this Labor Government has done in the vital area of wages and conditions. The Labor Government-not the Opposition-set up the tribunal to examine salary and wage levels in the defence forces. The Opposition calls for wage cuts and freezes. Indeed, that is what Labor inherited when we gained government in 1983-wage freezes. As Senator Robert Ray said earlier, one cannot remember any Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearing when the coalition Government supported increases in wages and conditions for workers. It has not happened and it will not happen. Senator Short knows that because he is anti-worker.
—I raise a point of order. Senator McKiernan knows perfectly well that that statement was incorrect, and I ask him to withdraw it.

—I rise on the point of order. Senator McKiernan is required only to withdraw unparliamentary language. Senator Short has been here and in the other place long enough to know that. Opposition members-not Senator Short personally but other honourable senators-have been dishing it out today. They should learn to take it.
— Order! There has been a deal of cut and thrust across the chamber. I suggest that Senator McKiernan get on with his speech.

—Perhaps I ought to tone it down a little, but it is difficult, having heard Senator Newman, as she said herself, going on and on and on. It gets the dander up a bit. Let us look at Labor's record on pay and allowances for personnel in the Australian defence forces. We, as I said, created an independent pay tribunal and the defence forces now have direct access to that tribunal. We accept the decisions of the tribunal and give the defence forces themselves direct and immediate access to it. We in government have responsibilities in this respect, as we have in the total area of wage and salary adjustments. We have a responsibility to put our arguments as a government. We do not always go in, as do Senator Newman and her colleagues, and argue against these things. Defence forces personnel receive all national wage increases, a point I mentioned earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition argues that the national wage case should be deferred. In deferring decisions the Opposition would also be denying service personnel any increases that may flow from movements in the consumer price index. We have introduced, as Senator Ray said earlier, special allowances to personnel serving in submarines, an area of employment that I would not like to get into. I do not like the closed confines of small spaces and the dangers associated with that work. General service personnel who serve in the field also received a recent increase in allowances. The general service allowance increased by 22 per cent, the field allowance by $4 to $12 a day. The Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal is shortly to examine a request to increase flying allowances. The Government has taken other steps which have been mentioned by Senator Ray in detail. Therefore, I shall not fill up the Hansard any further by merely repeating those matters for the sake of it.

Senator Reid, in a fairly reasoned though perhaps over-emotional contribution to the debate, talked about visiting the homes of service personnel. She said that we should not go back in history to see what decisions were made in bygone days. She said what mattered was what was happening now. But it is not fair that Senator Reid's side of politics had 30 years in government and did nothing except look at super-duper aircraft carriers and spent no money on housing, but now expects a Labor Government in 4 1/2 years to readjust everything. Senator Ray went into detail on the $750m allocated by this Government to be spent on housing for Defence Force personnel, the wives, husbands and families over the next decade. Again, I shall not labour the point. In talking about the families of Defence Force personnel, we have it on record and can claim to recognise that the spouses of military personnel are as vital to the defence of this nation as are the personnel themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do nothing for either.

—We are the ones who have recognised them-and it is the first time that they have ever been recognised. I could go into what happened under conservative governments in further debate, if Opposition senators want me to do so. We could debate the affirmative action legislation. Then we shall see where the Opposition stands-not only on the question of defence forces wives, husbands and personnel, but on the whole range of equality of the sexes in this nation. We shall see how many Opposition senators cross the floor on that one. I conclude by turning to the honourable member for O'Connor, Wilson Tuckey--
—He wasn't in the debate, was he?

—He was not in the debate, but before the election he promised to privatise the housing given to Defence Force personnel. No doubt there were Opposition frontbenchers who were highly embarrassed about Mr Wilson Tuckey's comments. Indeed, the service personnel and their families must have been horrified because they know what they would be facing if the coalition were elected to government. The rents currently in the range of $50 would undoubtedly be increased to $100 a week, or in places such as Canberra or other places where housing is scarce rents probably would go a lot higher than that. This Government has a commendable record in this area. We do not accept this motion of urgency. We recognise that there are some problems, and we are addressing them as comprehensively as possible because one cannot do things in isolation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) nor Senator McKiernan seems to recognise that we have a crisis on our hands. In fact, those honourable senators seem surprised that the Opposition brought on this emergency motion.
—It is an urgency motion.

—It is an urgency motion, but certainly there is an emergency and a crisis. The figures that have appeared in the last few months are irrefutable. It is ridiculous to go back to every government since the last war in order to blame them for the situation which the present Government has got itself into. It is completely irresponsible for a government to neglect the defence element of its responsibility to the nation. Defence is the most important role of government. Every government of every country has trouble in paying for its defence forces, particularly in peace time, but that is a role that the people want government to take.

SPEECH.PARA: We are a major nation in the South Pacific region, which is becoming more destabilised. The doctrine of `no foreseeable threat' has been exploded. How much warning did we get that Timor would dissolve into a revolution or that Indonesia would have that fracas with Papua New Guinea, which is continuing? How much warning did we have of the Indo-China problems in Vietnam and Korea? We have very little warning. What warning did we have of the trouble in the Philippines or the coup in Fiji? One had very little warning of these incidents and defence preparedness is most important. I am sure that this Government puts more emphasis on buying votes by supplying welfare to people because there are not that many votes in the defence forces. If it keeps treating the defence forces in this way there will be even fewer votes in those forces for the Australian Labor Party.

When the Minister for Home Affairs was speaking he talked about the White Paper that the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, put out. If the paper was good, the results of the Government's treatment of the paper or any action it took subsequently have not been good. Whereas the Government may have bought some materiel, it certainly has not applied itself to the compassionate role it always claims for itself of looking after the people who man the machines and, indeed, the forces themselves. The Minister talked about the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) not visiting Defence Force wives or the defence installations because she was so busy in Parliament. I do not think that any Labor Ministers in this Government have found that their attendances in Parliament are an impediment to visiting any place they want to, including the rainforests.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is just a cat fight; that's all this is.
—No, Senator Ray. She has been opening plenty of fetes in Canberra and attending to her own electoral matters here.
—Or going to parties.

—That is right. To say that the Defence Force retirement benefit (DFRB) is equivalent to age pensions and that everybody had to share in the cutbacks is not really correct because age pensioners were asked to put up with a six-week deferment in their pensions, whereas the DFRB recipients were asked to accept a 2 per cent cut that continues year after year and, of course, gets worse with inflation. I cannot accept those arguments or the arguments that have been raised by the Government against the motion. The Government cannot alter the facts as they exist today. It has a crisis on its hands which is shown in its figures.

SPEECH.PARA: When we talk about the morale of the forces we have to look, on the one hand, at the career structures of the service men and women and the administration within the Department of Defence. On the other hand, we have to look at the pay and conditions and the housing of the wives and children. It has been an eye opener for me this afternoon to hear some of the problems that the wives have suffered. I notice that the next speaker, Senator Burns, has been complimented in this debate as having come from the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. But at one stage the Defence Force's wages were tied to the metal workers award. Of course, at that time members of the forces did not get all the benefits, such as overtime. They do now, but it is worth only $1 an hour-it is not the overtime that metal workers would get, plus all the benefits that unionists get. Also, when the defence forces get a wage rise it is often deferred and delayed. They often have to put up with this as they cannot protest. The Minister must accept that there are demonstrations going on by people from the defence forces, their wives and their friends. These are people who would not normally demonstrate at all. They are sending in petitions, writing letters and taking whatever action they can. These are the people who have committed their lives to the service of their country and not to a particular government, as has been stated here. They are demonstrating, but neither the Minister nor Mrs Kelly are going out to talk to them. This is a crisis.

I do not know on whom this Government thinks it can rely. It cannot rely on the United Nations-it has not got a very good friend there. In fact, the United Nations has a very bad record. It was instituted to be an international forum to promote discussions so that we could avoid wars but since the Second World War, when the United Nations was formed, we have had 150 major wars. It has not been a forum that has shown any effectiveness in stopping wars. This Government cannot rely on neighbours; we have to be self-sufficient. Despite all the talk by the Minister this afternoon about self-sufficiency, we have not got it and we are getting less of it as service personnel retire. Heaven knows, the defence forces have different roles in peace and war, during times of confrontation and police actions such as those in Cyprus or the Middle East. They are all different. In peace time, such as now, we have these training exercises, such as Diamond Dollar. That exercise exposed enormous weaknesses. Having to sustain themselves for more than four to six weeks in the north of Australia may not have been important from a defence aspect but it was a good test of our troops. If there were an invading force coming into the north then it would experience the same difficulties as our own forces and probably could not sustain itself for more than four to six weeks either.

I was impressed when I heard of the difficulties of changing houses so often, particularly when the family is given a changing-of-address allowance. I bet that that allowance would not be enough to cover all the reconnection fees for the telephone, water, heating or cooling. I happen to have been on the Joint Committee on Public Works and have had to look at some of our Defence Force housing. It is pretty bad and we are not taking steps to replace it. The further we let it go, the more expensive it will be to fix up those things. I can understand how wives and families would be dreadfully upset with the conditions under which they are forced to live in some of the housing we have.

I turn to the figures relating to defence funding, which are getting harder to get because of the restrictions that have been placed on figures coming from the Department of Defence. Previously, we were spending 4.5 per cent to 5 per cent of gross national product (GNP) on defence. In 1987 the figure is 2.7 per cent, which is an enormous reduction-even if our GNP is up. It is not sufficient to spend on defence. Our dollar is down and, of course, our costs are up. Whatever we are doing is not enough for defence. On the question of materiel we have decided to build six submarines and to build the housing to construct them in Adelaide. I notice that that project will cost $90m, but the components are to be made in Sydney or Melbourne. They are to be trucked to Adelaide to be put together. That is the same sort of problem that the Americans have by making components in suitable electorates. They then wind up having to pay $50 for a nut and $100 for a spanner. These are ridiculous pricing arrangements. We are to spend $28m on the four new survey vessels to map the north. They will not have a gun or platform on them and they would not even be able to defend themselves against Indonesian pirates. The reason why we have to have them is that our current survey vessels keep hitting the ground. Presumably, if we were attacked from the north the invaders would hit the same reefs and shoals. I do not think the danger to Australia will be a snowflake fall of sampans on the top end of the country. The danger is more likely to be a nuclear submarine off Sydney Harbour, which could paralyse Australia in one hit just by being there, rather like the Tirpitz during the Second World War when it was put into the Tromso fiord. It controlled the whole North Sea. It never had to leave the fiord. It was only when the Germans got complacent that the Allies were able to get rid of the Tirpitz.

But I am straying from the subject a little. Honourable senators opposite were talking about materiel. We are talking about the morale of our defence forces. Morale is bad, as shown by the figures. A couple of figures have been quoted this afternoon but I would like to give some figures on total wastage. In 1983 there was 9.37 per cent wastage. This year there is 12.78 per cent wastage. Wastage has steadily increased every year. It is estimated that next year it will be 15.6 per cent. Translated into actual figures, that means that in the last three years 25,250 service men and women, that is, 36 per cent of the Australian defence forces, left the Services. That is an enormous figure. From July this year there has been a complete embargo on getting figures out of the defence forces. I can understand why the Government would not want the figures to come out, but figures do get out as the heads of the Services start to worry and to lobby people. Previously, we had a Minister for the Army, a Minister for the Navy and a Minister for the Air Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —What were you?

—I was the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Members of the three arms of the forces could make representations directly to their own Minister. Now they cannot do that. What is more or less a bureaucratic blockade is causing the forces no end of trouble when they want to make requisitions for men, materiel, pay or conditions or when they want to make representations about their problems. Defence Force problems are largely political. That is why easy approachability to Ministers is needed. One does not want it controlled by the bureaucracy, but that is what is happening now. I understand that there is an enormous row because the bureaucracy cannot agree on the type of compatible computers to be used by the three arms of the forces.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the wastage figure for the last three years is 25,250. If it goes up to the expected 15.6 per cent it will mean that over the last four years we will have lost over 36,000 people. That is 52 per cent of the Defence Force-an unbelievable figure. No wonder a cork has been put on the letting out of information. The male officer wastage figure from 1982 to 1987 has gone from 5.4 per cent to 9.8 per cent. If it keeps escalating at that rate, this year it will be 12.5 per cent, more than double. The figures that the Minister quoted today-I do not know why he let them out if there is a cork on them-are a damning indictment--

TALK.START.PARA: —They were let out in the Estimates committee.
—Is that where they came from? They are bad. The figure for pilot wastage, which is usually around 35 to 40 a year-we train 60 to 65-in 1985-86 was 70. In 1986-87 it was 107.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —One cannot speak in a debate on this issue without thinking about the end result of expenditure on defence-or war, as some people would express it. It seems that every country has a defence capacity but nobody wants to attack anyone else. We can see an illustration of the fallacy of that if we consider the Middle East. I intend to stray somewhat from the very narrow aspect of the defence area. I know I will have your support in this matter, Mr Deputy President. It is necessary to bring into dispute the sincerity of the mover of this motion and those who support her.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the role and history of the Australian Labor Party. It has always worked very hard for world peace. I do not suggest that nobody in the Liberal Party of Australia has similar views, as I know that some of its members do. That is the one area in which they are correct. The Labor Party was opposed to the Vietnam war, and it brought the troops out when it was elected in 1972. It has always favoured the use of diplomacy rather than the use of arms. It has favoured trying with all its capacity to create friendship among nations as opposed to a preparedness to be aggressive to one's own ends. There is a fairly substantial indication of this in the appointment, for the first time in the history of this country, of an Ambassador for Disarmament, Richard Butler, who does a very good job at the world's meeting places in arguing for world peace, looking at the idea not of unilateral disarmament but of gradual disarmament, heading for a peace which would not disadvantage any country.

As a Party we have always extended the olive branch. Nevertheless, we have been prepared to develop our defence capacity against those who think differently from us. Obviously, the armed forces want people who are dedicated to the idea of defending Australia. It has been said that the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, has a bias towards the equipment side of his portfolio. I suggest that if one studies the opinions of people who understand the requirements of a defence force in any country one will find that they point out, using facts, figures and statistics-and even photographs for honourable senators opposite who cannot understand things unless they have photographs-that equipment is becoming much more important in comparison with manpower. There is a fairly big difference in the way that the Battle of Waterloo and the Falklands war were fought. One would agree that equipment is vitally important. I am not suggesting that the people who use that equipment are unimportant. We want people involved in the defence forces because they see the need for a defence force that is properly motivated, financed and developed by a government that is properly motivated, a government that does not want to make war on other countries but that is prepared to defend itself in a very efficient fashion.

It has been said that there is a crisis of confidence in the ALP Government and that it lacks credibility. I suppose that one can say that and ask that it be accepted on face value, but it cannot be accepted in that way. Anyone who believes that people entering the defence forces do so with wonderful, lofty motives, and that nobody does so to get training or because he might not be able to handle a job out there on the civil side of employment, is quite wrong. We have all sorts of people in the Army, the Royal Australian Air Force and the Royal Australian Navy. Some time ago a person who had recently left the forces murdered a number of people. However, that is an exception. I make that point only to show that there are all sorts of people in the forces. Other people have carried our their responsibilities in a very fine way. Some people have given their lives. Many people today carry medals for their efforts.

One of the things people joining the defence forces look for, as do other people, is a proper reward for the effort they make. Under the Fraser Government, there was an Army wage freeze for some 18 months at least. At least we can say one thing about the Fraser Government: it shared wage freezes across the whole nation. The one thing it did not share around was prices control. I make the point that what happened then-and what would be proposed now, if the Opposition were in power, in relation to the $7 increase; an increase which should be granted to all workers, including service personnel-was that we saw a reduction in real wages. I challenge those opposite to question that point.

The Government has decided to continue with an adequate Budget allocation. Of course, this is quite different from what was suggested by the Opposition during the election campaign. It was all gung ho in suggesting that we should reduce spending; in fact it still says that. I have heard Senator Stone remark on that. He is very much dedicated to the idea of reducing Government spending. But I do not know how we can reduce Government spending and leave the defence vote alone and also satisfy the sorts of criticisms made by Senator Reid. Those people who say that they want to reduce taxes or have a flat rate of tax and reduce government spending really want to look after the filthy rich-those people who have recently lost millions and millions of dollars on the stock exchange. Let me say clearly-I hope they will read this, although they probably will not bother-that I have no sympathy for them. If they can make huge paper profits by speculation, they must also be prepared to lose money. But I do express some sympathy for the ordinary people who have lost money as a result of following the moves, initiatives and advice of financial advisers.

A number of questions were raised by Opposition spokesmen and by the Australian Democrats. For instance, Senator McLean talked about the lack of morale. It seemed to me that he put the proposition on the basis that it was the fault of the Labor Government, as though Senator Robert Ray and I were each in charge of a platoon, that we decided what the pay and conditions would be and how communications would be carried out in the Army-as though it was totally the Government's fault. But it is not. Morale has been a problem in armies throughout the world since time began, for all sorts of different reasons. To suggest that there was not a morale problem during the years of the Liberal-Country Party governments in my view would be to tell a gross and deliberate untruth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The number resigning was not as great, was it?

—Again, a number of factors affect the number of people resigning. It is fairly clearly understood that in times of full employment it is much more difficult to get people to join the Army, and when jobs are available outside the Army people are much more prepared to leave because they have somewhere to go.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the pilot situation, of course the Australian Labor Party is concerned about that. But would anybody on the other side suggest, and expect to be believed, that all of the pilots who join the Royal Australian Air Force do so with an absolute dedication to defend this country against the enemy by flying war planes? I suggest that a number of them do; history shows that. But I suggest that a lot of them would work out what it would cost them and the time it would take them to become a pilot with Qantas Airways Ltd through a civil approach as against how they could become a Qantas pilot via the Air Force. So it is not just the case that when people have left the defence forces at any given time in history it has been the fault of a political party or a coalition of parties in power. All of those other factors have had an effect. Wages are another factor.
I have heard some comment made about people being afraid to wear their uniform to work at a given period in Australian history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Told not to wear them.
—They were told not to wear their uniforms to work.

—That was in 1973; I thank the honourable senator. But that was a rather small inconvenience compared with the fact that people who refused to go to Vietnam and murder Vietnamese were put in jail because they followed their conscience and would not support a government that blindly sent people to Vietnam. I think that not being allowed to wear one's uniform to work was a small sacrifice to make.
—So they went to Vietnam and murdered the Vietnamese, did they? Is that what you are saying?

—Yes, they did. We talk about job satisfaction in the Army. I hope that, when people talk about job satisfaction, they mean what people in the Army do in peacetime, which as far as I am aware is to do such things as help people in floods and develop skills that can be used later on in a nation at peace. After all, it has already been said that we all want world peace. I hope that they do not mean that the personnel, in order to feel that they are doing a good job, feel that they have to be trained to kill other people. That is what all armies do-train to be efficient killers. It may be defensive, but that is what they do. I hope we are not talking about that. I hope we are talking about the former, about people developing a capacity that they will use in times of peace, or sharpening up a capacity to protect us if we are attacked by other nations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid talked about nurses' conditions. My heart almost broke when she described how terrible the situation was. Let me remind Senator Reid that over a period of time nurses throughout this nation were expected to take as a reward for their efforts the knowledge that they were serving a noble cause. I could get a copy for her of an industrial gazette of 1930 from Queensland when junior nurses were knocked back for wages and told that they should accept that they were giving a service to the community and that their families should subsidise their living costs until they were trained and competent nurses. In fact it was in this very area, in Canberra, in the early 1960s when the unions who represented the nurses finally went on strike against a Liberal-Country Party government because the nurses refused to do menial work for which they were not trained. They refused to continue to work for low wages, which is what they were receiving under that administration. From that base, the lot of nurses in every State in this country, even if they do not have the wages and conditions that they think they should have, has been improved out of sight.

Mention has been made of old houses and the amount of work required and the facilities that have to be provided by the service personnel renting those houses. The fact is that all of those houses were built long ago. They were built under Liberal-Country Party governments. I suggest that at that time they were probably built within certain budgetary constraints, or built on the cheap, to use a crude term. What the current Government has done is establish an organisation under which better housing conditions can be created.

Finally, the best way that people in the forces can be represented is not in the Senate, but through their own union, which they established when a Liberal-Country Party government was in office and would not listen to them. They found it necessary to develop that organisation, which is a very clear indication of the absolute lack of sincerity of Senator Reid, who I think speaks just to justify being a senator. I suggest to her--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very short space of time that I have, which is about two minutes, I wish to remind the Senate that we are dealing with a motion of urgency which has been presented to the Parliament by Senator Jocelyn Newman. The reason I will take only about two minutes is to enable Senator Newman to respond. I remind the Senate that the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to recognise that a crisis of confidence has arisen in Australia's defence forces as a direct consequence of the policies of the Labor Government and a lack of both leadership and genuine concern about service pay and conditions by the Ministers for Defence and Defence Science and Personnel.

Whoever is responsible, there is, as I think we all know, a crisis of confidence within the defence forces. We would have to be blind, deaf and dumb not to acknowledge that. I am sure that each of us would have had representations of concern from individuals within the Services and from their representative association, the Armed Forces Federation of Australia. I am pleased that Senator Newman has raised this matter in the Senate. I have spoken about defence issues on innumerable occasions in this chamber. Today I am not about to speak on those broad issues that have been canvassed, but I would be very happy to address them when and as the time arises.

Here we have a specific motion which deals with `a genuine concern about service pay and conditions'. If we focus on that, and if this Senate adopts this motion, I think it will strengthen the hand of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) in Cabinet. For that reason, if for no other, I will be supporting this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Clearly, the Government has no answer to this urgency motion. We have had rantings and ravings from members of the Government, but what is of great concern to me-and it should be of great concern to all honourable senators and to the nation-is that they are still refusing to recognise that they even have a problem. Senator Robert Ray concentrated on what a great job the Government is doing spending taxpayers' dollars on materiel-and certainly our equipment needs to be maintained at a steady rate. Senator McKiernan went on and on about cuts in wages. Last, but not least, Senator Burns gave us a burst about unionism in the forces. I am sure that that is all a great help to the servicemen who are so worried about their position and who had hopes that some members of the Government might have appreciated what the situation really was! For members of the Government to talk about events 30 years ago is a complete and utter failure to come to terms with their responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank my colleagues for their support in this debate and I thank Senator Harradine for his brief words and for allowing me the opportunity to close the debate. I also thank Senator McLean for what I believe was a most thoughtful contribution, which I would expect from him with his proper and deep understanding of the subject through his own experience. But the Ministers either do not know the facts or are not reporting them as they are to Cabinet. I can only believe that, if they were doing that, the money needed to keep the defence budget at the standard required by the Government's own White Paper would have to be forthcoming. The Government does not understand just how serious the matter is; it has its priorities wrong. People have to come first. What is the use of expensive equipment if we do not have the experienced personnel needed to operate it?

In the papers today the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) displayed her naivete when she asked where the cuts could be made in order to spend more on personnel. Senator Ray repeated that inanity today during the debate. The point is that the defence budget has been cut to the stage where it is simply not adequate. This Government also has to address its priorities in this area.

The defence forces are being taken for granted, are being neglected and are being discriminated against. They are being expected to accept a standard of living that is not required of the rest of the nation. Therein lies the terrible unfairness of it all. The Government should be showing leadership. It should protect these people, who do not have the right to associate in some form of labour union, despite what Senator Burns said about the Armed Forces Federation, which, by the way, the Government continually refuses to talk to and have a meaningful dialogue with. It never thinks of appointing members of that Federation to bodies such as the working party on the defence service home loans scheme. It is no good Senator Burns talking about unionism, as the Government does not even recognise the professional association that the defence forces now have.

Australia deserves a defence force that is proud to serve the nation, not one that cringes every time the Government mentions defence or what it will do to conditions of service. We are suffering a crisis of confidence in our defence forces. The quicker the Government recognises that and starts to take some meaningful action for the honourable men and women who are serving us, the better our defence will be and, more importantly, the happier people in the defence forces will be and the better protected Australia will be as a nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This afternoon we are debating the annual report of the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) for the financial year which has just ended, 1986-87. The Senate will be aware that the Prices Surveillance Authority was established by the Hawke Government in March 1984, following legislation passed by the Parliament in the previous year. The Authority's offices are located principally in Sydney and Melbourne and its role in the pricing area involves its looking at declared enterprises. Those enterprises must notify the PSA of any proposed price rises. In scrutinising proposed price rises, the Prices Surveillance Authority must also look at such things as the likely impact on investment and the likely impact on employment of any decisions it makes in regard to proposed prices.

The Authority had its origins in the accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions which developed under this Government from 1983 onwards. Of course, that accord involved a strategy of attempting to keep down competing income claims and, therefore, price rises, while expanding the economy and getting away from the very rapid rates of inflation that we had under the Fraser-Howard Government by enabling an incomes policy to work at the same time that inflation was being kept down. In setting up the PSA, the Hawke Government was taking a major step away from the previous policy of the Fraser-Howard Government, which was to manage the Australian economy by creating more and more slack in the labour market. If one reduces to essentials the economic policy adopted when Mr Howard was Treasurer of Australia, one sees that it was a policy very much of raising unemployment to moderate wage claims and price rises in the community. As we know, that policy did not work. Over the life of the Fraser-Howard Government more and more unemployment was required to produce a given effect on prices and the so-called declared policy of that Government of fighting inflation first was a dismal failure. When the Hawke Government was elected to power in March 1983 we inherited double digit inflation from the Fraser- Howard Government. In fact, in the 12 months to March 1983, the consumer price index rose by 11 1/2 per cent, so we inherited both double digit inflation and double digit unemployment at the same time.

It is interesting to note that, at the 1987 election, the Opposition parties, led by Mr Howard, wanted to abolish the Prices Surveillance Authority. I would be interested to hear in the present climate, when we are trying to find out from Opposition spokespersons-both Mr Howard and Senator Stone-where they would put the knife into government spending and where they would specify the detailed cuts in expenditure which they are calling for, whether they would proceed to the abolition of the Prices Surveillance Authority. I would be very interested to hear that, because we can link the operations of the Authority under Labor to the fall in the inflation rate. As I have pointed out, when this Government came to power it inherited an 11 1/2 per cent rise in the inflation rate as measured by the consumer price index. The figures that were released yesterday by the Australian Statistician show that, rather than having double digit inflation, it had been reduced to 8.3 per cent, well down on the figures of four years ago. Inflation, quite clearly, is tracking down. For two quarters in a row, the June quarter and the September quarter of this year, inflation has been running at less than 2 percentage points. With an inflation rate of 2.9 per cent in the December quarter of 1986, I think we can look forward with considerable confidence to a further fall in the inflation rate in the December quarter this year. The annual rate should in fact fall quite significantly below the 8.3 per cent rate that was recorded yesterday. When the figures are available late in January, I think we will see an annual rate of less than 8 per cent for the calendar year 1987. I think that is far preferable to the inflation rate under Mr Howard of 11 1/2 per cent, and the Prices Surveillance Authority has been partly responsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make two points in relation to the annual report of the Prices Surveillance Authority. They both relate to petrol pricing. I draw the Senate's attention to page 28 of the report, which states that of all household weekly expenditures on commodities which amount to $361.84, only $50.25 or 13.9 per cent relates to item which are covered by the Prices Surveillance Act. Of that roughly 14 per cent or $50 of household expenditures, we find that nearly $18 or roughly 36 per cent of that related to the price of petrol, and petrol was therefore a very significant factor in that section of household expenditure covered by the Prices Surveillance Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: In moving around Australia one finds that over time there is an enormous variation in the price of petrol, both from place to place and depending on the time of the week or the month. Petrol prices in Adelaide may indeed be amongst the lowest in Australia. I note that very often in Canberra the price is about 58c or 59c per litre, but recently in Adelaide it was down to as low as 38c per litre. Most country people are paying up to 68c per litre.

With that as a background, I turn to page 57 of the report, which states that there were 218 notices of proposed price changes for petroleum products. While 57 of these 218 were withdrawn, the majority were in fact granted. The report states:
. . . `the Authority offered no objection to the proposed prices.'

It goes on to point out that the Authority endorsed a wholesale price of 53.1c per litre on 30 June 1986, and 49.95c per litre, including excise, on 30 June 1987. It would seem that the price for which petrol is being sold is very often substantially below even the wholesale price which has been agreed by the Prices Surveillance Authority. There is something most odd about the way in which petrol prices are varying so widely around the country and varying from time to time. That brings me to the second point I would like to make in relation to this report.

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that in 1927 the then Government set up Commonwealth Oil Refineries, which gave the Government a direct handle on prices in the purchasing, refining and selling of petroleum products. Commonwealth Oil Refineries was sold by the Menzies Government in 1953, and it would now seem that the Prices Surveillance Authority, and through it the Government, is now in a much poorer position to know precisely the true prices in relation to the wholesale purchase of petroleum, the cost of refining and the cost of marketing those products. I think this bears very much on the issue of privatisation. We have lost the ability to have direct access to those figures because Commonwealth Oil Refineries was sold. In this report we have direct evidence that, had the Commonwealth retained the ability to refine and market petroleum products, we would now be in a much better position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commend the annual report of the Prices Surveillance Authority and commend the Authority for the work that it carries out, because it is very important that the price of fuel is looked at from two sides. Over the last five years workers have been asked to accept a loss in real wages-a loss of at least 9 per cent during the wage freeze-plus other amounts of discount that have been decided upon in the wage fixing tribunals. It is much easier for people to talk to workers about wage restraint if they talk about price control. I know that the Authority does not have the sort of control that many people would like. The report indicates that of 437 applications for increases in prices only 15 failed. The 437 were successful because the companies complied with certain established standards, one being compliance with the wage fixing principles. So there was general acceptance by those companies of established guidelines. Even though there may not be a capacity to penalise the business community or to enforce its compliance by sending along the gendarmes, there is that acceptance, which I think is very good. Even those 15 who failed to satisfy the guidelines accepted that they should not increase prices. TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I hope to be brief in these remarks. I simply want to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that yesterday the Treasurer (Mr Keating) issued a Press release which bears on some of the matters which are addressed in this report being tabled in the Senate this afternoon, the annual report for 1987 of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. In that Press release the Treasurer mentioned a number of measures which the Government proposes to take by way of amending the Commonwealth Bank Act. I confess an interest in this matter, not merely because it is proper for all senators to be interested in it, but because I spent 5 1/2 years on the board of the Corporation in an ex officio capacity during my term in the Treasury. Indeed, the Treasurer's Press release states that the implementation of the measures set out in that Press release `will complete the restructuring of the Commonwealth banks which was commenced in 1984'. I also want to say in passing that that restructuring was put in train in the Treasury at the time when I was privileged to have some connection with that Department and that restructuring process. I make that point not by way of recalling that insignificant piece of history but in order to make a much more important point. That restructuring in 1984 which was referred to in the Treasurer's Press release had to do with an attempt to provide the Commonwealth Banking Corporation with a better structure of capitalisation on the basis of which it could proceed with its lending program, while at the same time remaining acceptable in terms of capital-asset ratios in the eyes of the business community and particularly the international financial community, because increasingly questions were being raised at that time about the capacity of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation to go on lending on the basis of a very slender capital base.

The point that that raises, of course, concerns the future of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and its capacity to continue to raise capital, from whatever source, in order to continue to expand its operations, which I have no doubt most people hope and expect it to do-certainly I would expect the Government side to do so. That, in turn, immediately raises questions about what will be the future of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation in relation to what is sometimes called privatisation and what might be called the commercialisation aspect. I do not want to detain the Senate this evening on that particular matter. We will no doubt have an opportunity to debate those questions further.
There is only one other question which I want to touch on tonight-although I shall seek leave to continue my remarks later-and that is the following reference in the Treasurer's statement:

The Government has also reviewed the role of the Board and the management of the banks and their accountability to the Government. The Government has decided to amend the Act to require the Board of the Corporation to prepare and submit a corporate plan to the Treasurer.
Of course, I am well aware that this is part of a general process which the Government is hoping to apply to many statutory corporations. But the Treasurer went on to say:
The plan, which will be confidential to the Government-
this is the corporate plan of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation -
will define the objectives of the Commonwealth Banks and give an outline of the policies and strategies to be pursued achieving those objectives.

I take it that, as the Treasurer said in that statement, the plan will be confidential to the Government. But I think it raises some interesting and, potentially at least, disturbing questions about what exactly the board of the Corporation will be actually required to inform the Government about and in what detail and in particular whether it will be required to go into, for example, categories of potential borrowers or particular avenues of lending which the Corporation may have in mind. No doubt, in light of the fact that the plan is to be submitted-because, after all, there is not much point in submitting a plan unless it will be subsequently discussed with the Government-I presume that it will be discussed subsequently with the Government. That particular statement by the Treasurer does raise some questions in my mind. I hope that when the legislation that the Treasurer has promised comes forward the Government will be very forthcoming, very frank and very clear about what it proposes under those particular provisions. Mr President, I am aware that there are some important speeches to be made in the very near future in this chamber and I therefore seek leave to continue my remarks later.
