SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —For all of us in this chamber 14 September was a significant day. In the presence of our colleagues, our families, our close friends and the staff of the Senate, we made, some of us for the first time, an oath or an affirmation that we would be `faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth, her heirs and successors according to law'. In this day and age, commitments such as wedding vows and legal contracts are by some so lightly entered into. I am sure that each of my colleagues in this chamber was aware of the enormity of the responsibility associated with the commitment we were making and the trust the people of Australia had placed in us-trust to conduct the business of the Senate to the best of our individual and corporate ability.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously 14 September had particular significance for each of us as individuals. First, for you, Mr President, it was the day when this House, in its wisdom, saw fit to re-elect you to the very high and responsible office of President of the Senate. I congratulate you, albeit somewhat belatedly. From my brief association with you I know that you will bring to this very important parliamentary appointment the wisdom and impartiality it requires. I also wish to congratulate my fellow Victorian, Senator Hamer, on his re-election as Deputy President.

For me it was a memorable day. I wondered as I sat in the chamber what thoughts may have been passing through my father's mind as he watched the proceedings. I wondered whether he should be taking some of the credit for the privilege we had in having the right to be members of a democratic parliament. It was evident to me that the answer to that question was in the affirmative: he did deserve to take some of the credit. It was because of his and others' commitment to a cause and the sacrifices-and the supreme sacrifice in some cases-they made that we live in a free, democratic society. Before his twenty-first birthday he had served in the Second World War in the Middle East, New Guinea and Borneo. With the very little understanding I have of the things those young men and women experienced, I can only say, in the words of Vera Brittain-as our Vietnam veterans on the recent welcome home march may have said-`bygone battles like old sins cast long shadows'. I was reminded, too, on 14 September that-if I may be excused for using some poetic licence-bygone legislation, like old sins, can sometimes cast long shadows.

The condolence motion for Sir Billy Snedden on that day should have reminded each of us of our own mortality and of the ephemeral nature of our existence-in particular, the fugacious tenure of the office we each hold here. But not so fleeting are the implications and at times unintended consequences of the decisions made in this and the other place. One of the great responsibilities with which we have been entrusted is not only to review current legislation, to ascertain its impact on individuals, our States and the Australian population as a whole; we need also to extend ourselves mentally in creative and lateral thought to ensure that our current legislation does not cast long unintended shadows.

I must also admit that 14 September was not without an element of relief for me. It has been said that a week is a long time in politics. If that is the case, then the five weeks it took for the Victorian Senate count to be completed was an eternity. It was a long but worthwhile wait and I am sure that there were even some relieved senators on the other side when they were, so to speak, short changed on the results.

I would like to digress for a moment and address the issue of the delay between the election and the declaration of the poll. Let me hasten to add that I have the utmost regard for the staff of the Commonwealth Electoral Commission. They could not have worked harder to facilitate the final result. Until 1974 there had been only two double dissolutions-in 1914 and 1951. Since then there have been four-in 1974, 1975, 1983 and 1987. There also appears to be a general trend towards an increase in the number of candidates, which results in a slowing down of the count. There were some changes, resulting from the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Act 1987, which attempted to reduce the delay in the count. These amounted to no more than Claytons' changes, as they had little impact on the lateness of the 1987 scrutiny. If we continue the vogue of double dissolutions and there continues to be an increase in the number of Senate candidates, it behoves the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Reform urgently to readdress this matter to put in place procedures which will accelerate the count.

Mr President, as one of the last of the 17 of the class of '87 to make a maiden speech, I take this opportunity to compliment my new fellow senators on their maiden contributions to this chamber. I would also add my sincere thanks to you, Mr President; the Government Whip, Senator Jones; the Opposition Whip, Senator Reid; the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Cumming Thom; and the Senate staff for the planning and the effort which went into the orientation seminar which contributed so much to the initiation of the 17 novitiates. Of those 17 now slightly more experienced tyros, three are women. Senator Ryan, in her maiden speech in 1974, drew attention to the small number of women in the chamber. Of the 64 senators only six were women. Today, if she were present in the chamber, she would be able to take some solace in the fact that of the 76 senators 17 are women.

As a senator for Victoria I follow a distinguished line of women senators-former Senator Marie Breen, former Senator Dame Ivy Wedgwood and the recently retired former Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. It is the latter to whom I wish briefly to refer. While many in both Houses have ineffectually pranced across the political stage, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle executed her role with distinction, dedication and dignity, and by so doing earned the respect of members of both sides of the Parliament and the people of Victoria.

It is appropriate and has been customary, although this custom has not always been observed, for a maiden speech to acknowledge those people and events which have influenced one throughout the years. I have been fortunate to have a supportive family through kinship and a caring, extended family through friendship. It would be improper for me, having made reference to my father earlier, not to acknowledge my mother. She lives in the United States of America, and would have been here this evening, but she was one of the victims of the increased demand on the trans-Pacific flights. It seems odd to me that, with the effort the Government has put into publicising Australia overseas, it did not anticipate the demand and approve increased flights earlier rather than closing the door after the horse has bolted.

There are many who should be named on an occasion such as this but to do so would take too long, and in attempting to be brief but inclusive I may risk omission. There are those who know how they have helped me and there is no need to call the roll. There are those who have guided me spiritually and those who have given me prayerful support. There are those who have taught me. I particularly admire those who have executed that task honestly and, rather than try to inculcate me with their own particular view of the world, have impartially made me argue to the roots of my intellect. Would that all teachers were so honourable. There are those who, through their commitment to the community through voluntary organisations, have had a significant influence on my development.

Today, when the work of volunteers is so often devalued, I wish to give testimony and pay tribute to one of the great youth organisations in this country and the world. Through this organisation I was challenged to develop my skills to their full potential, I was exposed to outstanding role models of women in a wide variety of professions and I had an experience which altered my life. I left school when I was 14 and was working in an office when, as a result of an international exchange to Mexico, I was inspired to go back to school and continue my education. All this and more have been the benefits I have derived from my 32 years of membership of an organisation which is sometimes, but inappropriately, the brunt of humour and ill-informed comment. The organisation to which I refer and to which I owe great personal debt is the Girl Guides Association of Australia.

My acknowledgments would not be complete without reference to the Victorian Division of the Liberal Party of Australia, in particular, the women's section, which has given me so much support. In preselecting me I believe that the Party made a conscious decision to provide Victorians with a Liberal Senate team which had a balanced representation from various backgrounds. Social scientists are under-represented on this side of politics and my thesis regarding the reasons for this may be too provocative, given the guidelines for a maiden speech. Maybe I should expound upon that thesis at another time or in another forum. I believe that the Party selected me, despite the fact that I had not had a long history in it, because of my experience in higher education, health care training, youth affairs and gerontology-the study of aging. I thank the Victorian Division of the Liberal Party for the part it has played in enabling me to bring these skills to bear in the Senate.

Senator Chapman in his maiden speech made reference to some of the recently retired senators, including former Senator Jessop. I am not sure that members of the public are really aware that we are incarcerated in Parliament House from morning until late at night when the House is sitting, and they may not realise how useful it must have been to have the optometrical skills of Senator Jessop, who fixed senators' and members' broken spectacles on the spot. I am not sure that my qualifications as a psychologist will be so useful. Despite the fact that there may be more of them than broken glasses, broken egos are not so easily repaired.

Mr President, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, made a statement not long after the Budget was brought down with which I heartily concur. I am not sure that we will often be in agreement but on this occasion we were. On 19 September in Perth he warned that Australia was not out of trouble and said that he was worried that the Budget may have been oversold and that this may make the public complacent. He indicated just how fragile the Australian economy is and that, given another commodity price slide, Australia may find the International Monetary Fund knocking on the door again. I believe that he is right. By whatever test one uses, Australians cannot afford to be complacent.

Let me take just three tests: first, the test of comparing Australia's performance against that of other countries; secondly, the test of comparing our national financial situation now with that of 1983; and, thirdly, the test of a comparison of family living standards with those of five years ago. In applying the first test, a comparison of performance with those of other countries, let me take a group of countries-the United States of America, Japan, Canada, West Germany, France and the United Kingdom. How do we fare? The answer is poorly. We are at the bottom of the class on economic growth and we are, unfortunately, at the top of the class with the highest current account deficit as a percentage of gross national product, the highest inflation and the highest interest rates.

How do we fare when we apply the second test-a comparison of our financial situations now and in 1983? Again we fail dismally. Home loan interest rates have risen, credit card and personal loan interest rates have risen, our current account deficit has doubled and our gross foreign debt-that is, the total amount owed to foreigners-has increased three-fold from June 1983 when it was $36 billion to $109 billion at the end of August this year. The third test is family living standards, and there is little need to bore honourable senators with statistics. People have only to take something from their kitchen cupboard which they bought six months ago to see how prices have increased. Interest rates on home loans have increased, our Medicare levy has increased and the price of purchasing and running a car has gone through the roof.

Almost everyone here runs a budget. The thing that is most likely to keep us awake at night tossing and turning, other than concern for a loved one or concern about a personal relationship, is surely to be financial in nature. Our bankcard is overdrawn-and given the recent statistics showing the national personal loan and credit card debt at $23 billion, unfortunately there will be many in this category-a few more unexpected bills come in and there is not enough money to meet all of our commitments. Let me say this: if people toss and turn when their personal finances are in a mess, then, given Australia's indebtedness and the slippery slope we are on, we should have a nation of insomniacs.

The other day I was clearing out some books and happened to come across an old economics text from my matriculation year. I am not quite sure how the teacher coped with having David Hill of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and me in the same class but she managed. I was flicking through the old text and was interested to note that in 1956 Australia's balance of payments was favourable to the tune of #233m. In 1956 the first of the baby boom was just going to high school. We were a feted generation and I would remind my fellow baby boom colleagues that we grew up under a Liberal government. The world was our oyster, not so for those making the transition from primary to high school today-the economic climate in which they are growing up is anything but rosy. Not only is the nation looking down the barrel at the risk of bankruptcy, but individual debt is at an all time high and personal bankruptcy is on the increase. There is to boot unprecedented moral bankruptcy at all levels of our society and no group-parliamentarians, police, public servants-is exempt.

While I have my palette and brush poised, let me continue to elaborate upon this not so rosy picture. Our once well health care system is now itself in need of treatment. It has multiple diseases and symptoms, waiting lists, demoralised staff and acute hospital beds filled with nursing home patients who should, but cannot be accommodated in nursing homes. If honourable senators can bear with me a little longer, I will add a few more strokes to make the picture a little clearer.

Our education system is also suffering. As the recently retired chairman of a large academic department at the Lincoln Institute of Health Sciences and a member of Monash University Council, I can speak with some authority on the university and college sector. There are many areas of concern but I will illuminate only one or two. Much of the complex and specialised equipment-electron microscopes, computer equipment and so on-used in tertiary institutions is imported. The drop in the Australian dollar has put the purchase of such equipment out of the reach of many departments and researchers. The equipment on which our medicos, engineers, architects, chemists, physicists and computer scientists are being trained is rapidly becoming obsolete. Our libraries are suffering, too. Libraries are the heart and infrastructure of a tertiary institution. The blood supply to them is dwindling as the soaring costs, again mostly due to the decrease in the Australian dollar, of essential journals and books has meant that librarians have been forced to cancel subscriptions. If we let our libraries run down, not only will we reduce Australia's capacity to initiate research and development now, but also the legacy of depleted libraries will linger well into the future.

Currently our universities are suffering a brain drain of both post-graduate students and staff. Academics are being lured by higher salaries and better conditions overseas or into the public and private sector in Australia. If Australia is to get in front again, we need the best young minds in Australia being taught by the best, most highly motivated, teachers and researchers. Mediocrity will not see us achieve our place as a competitor in the markets of the world, nor producing the professionals with the training required to deal with the complex social, moral and philosophical issues produced by electronic, technological and biomedical developments. The training of philosophers, social scientists and others in the humanities should not be neglected, either, in the current push for education to be relevant.

To continue my analogy of painting a picture, I remind honourable senators that Rembrandt did a series of self-portraits which demonstrated very clearly the aging processes. As a psychologist with a particular interest in gerontology-the study of aging-I wish to paint the portrait of aging Australia. In the past 80 years the aged population has grown from 4 per cent of the total population to 10.6 per cent, and the prediction for 2021 is at least 15 per cent. There are differences in the rates of increase within the older population. In the 1980s and 1990s the fastest rate of growth is, and will be, amongst the oldest groups.

The impact of these demographic changes places greater strain on the already stretched services and facilities for the old. The baby boom is currently going through its corporate mid-life crisis, and this may explain the pressure on superannuation issues. The baby boom will contribute, in the first decade of next century, to faster increases in the numbers of the `young aged'. Despite the increase in the young aged almost a quarter of the older population will be over 80, and 75 per cent of these will be women. This is one of the very important social issues facing Australia and it also has profound economic implications. I was concerned that the Government, through the speech delivered by His Excellency on opening the Thirty-fifth Parliament, barely touched upon the issue of aging-except maybe in reference to the Government's `objective of restoring parity between the single adult pension and benefit rates' and references to reforms of residential care for aged people.

The final touch to my picture should be light because it is about youth, but I am compelled to continue painting with dark colours. Our youth, the target of the much heralded but now somewhat bedraggled Priority One program, have not featured in the Government's outline of its plans for the life of this Parliament. There is reference to the apprenticeship system as a major source of employment and training opportunity for young people, and I suppose there is indirect reference to youth, although not explicitly stated, in the promise of the continuation of the national campaign against drug use and the commitment to public housing to alleviate homelessness. In the Government's plans for the life of this Parliament, Aboriginals, women and immigration and ethnic affairs each command a separate section with a heading-not so youth and old age-and here I rest my case, or should I say my brush.

No, Australians cannot afford to be complacent-we should be vitally concerned about our national debt, our individual personal debt, the level of corruption and crime in our society and the plethora of social issues which confront us. Today's Sydney Morning Herald highlights Australia's particular vulnerability in the current situation of declining share markets because `it is a commodity producer and is deeply in debt'. I repeat: we cannot afford to be complacent.

I believe that Australia needs to be revived-not reconstructed by external forces such as the Australian Council of Trade Unions and government, but revived through each individual Australian being encouraged to do his or her best to work to make Australia more productive and competitive. We should seek this revival through relieving individuals and small business from excessive interference by government and bureaucracy; restoring government spending to affordable levels; reducing taxes to rekindle incentive; reviewing restrictive work practices; recapturing and capturing export markets through innovation, improved quality and reliable delivery; rewarding, not penalising, effort and excellence; recognising the significant contribution of volunteers in our society; and restoring a system where those in genuine need, and not others, are the beneficiaries of social welfare.

Mr President, I expressed my appreciation to various groups and people earlier, but the ultimate expression of gratitude must be to the people of Victoria whom I have the great honour of representing. I hope that the trust they have shown in electing me will be justified by my service to them and my performance in this chamber and in the various committees of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Wood, I remind honourable senators that this is his maiden speech and I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I am delighted to follow Senator Patterson, from Victoria, because we share the same concerns for justice and especially young people. I am sure that our concern for youth is something that we will share during the life of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I would especially like to thank you, Mr President, the staff of the Senate and other senators who have been very good to an innocent in the Senate-someone who is not used to this sort of environment. The passage through my early weeks here has been made much easier by the friendliness shown by other senators from all sides of the Senate, and especially by the Senate staff. I am amazed to find a place where people still value and are proud of their work and always seek to do an excellent job.

I also thank my family, my friends and my comrades in the peace movement. I will not go through the roll, as Senator Patterson describes it, because there are too many of them and they know who they are, so I thank them now.

As the sole representative of the Nuclear Disarmament Party in this place I follow in the footsteps of Senator Vallentine, who has paved the way and has made my transition to the Senate much easier. I give a special thank you and a special mention to Senator Vallentine for her help and congratulate her on paving the way.

The Nuclear Disarmament Party (NDP) is proud of its success in the last election but it also has great responsibility now because its mandate came from right across the political spectrum. While our primary vote totalled about 50,000, we received another quarter of a million votes from preferences. The lesson we learnt from that is that, although people were concerned to vote for a party that appeared to be concerned with a whole range of issues, nuclear disarmament was still very high on their agenda. After they had made their vote for their first party of preference, the Nuclear Disarmament Party figured pretty close to the top in just about everybody's thinking.

I need to explain the broader links between nuclear disarmament and other issues. We tried to do this during the election campaign, but the media were fairly preoccupied with the Bob and John show. All the issues in the election campaign seemed to have been subsumed into what effect this or that issue would have on the relative standings of either Mr Hawke or Mr Howard. So the smaller parties and the independents did not get much of a show during the election campaign, but in the campaign we tried to show the broader links between nuclear disarmament and all the other critical issues of our time.

Nuclear disarmament is not an issue like the Daintree or this issue or that issue which one puts together in a sack like so many potatoes. The nuclear arms race is a dynamic process. It includes a whole range of issues. The very existence, the production, the deployment and the maintenance of a nuclear warfare strategy rests on vast concentrations of power and of wealth. The vast concentrations of wealth that are necessary to supply and build the arms are made through the exploitation of the environment. I do not need to go through the whole list of environmental destruction around the world, the places where vast concentrations of capital are destroying the environment in the name of profit. These vast concentrations of wealth rest on the exploitation of workers around the world-not just workers in the Third World, but workers in all countries whose needs and just demands have to go out the window in the name of profit.

I shed very few tears over the stock market crash in the last few weeks. We hear a great deal about free enterprise, a free market, and how the market needs to be left to do its own thing. Yet as soon as there is the slightest hiccup in the stock market, as soon as shares start to fall and as soon as people have to start selling their Porsches, there is a demand for government to intervene, for government to do something. Well, is it or is it not a free market? It seems to me that the goal is profit and that these profits are used to maintain the arms race. These vast concentrations of wealth which exploit the environment and exploit workers maintain poverty in the Third World and in this country. The other day I went through the new Parliament House on the hill. That building has cost $1.1 billion, which represents a lot of homes in the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless.

Then there are the vast concentrations of power around the world. Look at the places around the world where people struggle for self-determination, for sovereignty. One can reel them off-Nicaragua, Eritrea, Belau, Fiji. Everywhere people are struggling for self-determination, the right to rule their own country, the right to have a say in their own affairs and to govern their own affairs. Everywhere where people are struggling against political oppression, they are struggling against global super-power interests.

The concentration of power around the world rests also on patriarchy. The military and hierarchical systems around the world which keep people oppressed require a patriarchal system. So we are denying sovereignty not just to peoples in general, but to women in particular, who produce most of the world's food and who care for most of the world's children. Those women are denied their say in how the world is run, in the interests of patriarchy and maintaining control on a global level.

Let us look at the South Pacific, and nearer to our north. How long will Mrs Aquino last now that the Philippines is moving towards the abolition of United States bases from the Philippines? My guess is that very soon we shall see in the Philippines a coup which brings to power a right wing military junta which will secure the bases for the United States. Let us look also at Belau, a tiny little island in a very strategic position which has been bullied and hounded into having vote after vote to maintain its nuclear free constitution. It is being forced, through economic pressure and bullying by the United States, to enter into a compact with the United States. I notice that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is talking about a compact with the Aboriginal people. I hope that he is talking about a different process and a different sort of compact than the United States wants to foist on Belau. In French Polynesia, about which Senator Schacht has been speaking in this place in the last few days, and in New Caledonia the French use intimidation, bullying and violence to maintain control over their populations.

Then there is the sad story of Fiji, with a rising military junta in what was once the friendliest place in the Pacific. The evidence is not in yet, but I am sure that in the coming years the evidence will emerge, just as it did on Chile. I ask honourable senators to learn the lesson of Chile. If we need proof of the way in which the United States maintains its sovereignty in the world, we have an object lesson in Chile; the evidence is irrefutable and undeniable. The United States planned carefully and over a period to destabilise and overthrow a democratically elected government in Chile. So it was no surprise to me that, with the combination of French attempts to militarise Fiji and United States attempts to militarise Fiji, as soon as Bavadra was elected and was moving towards an independent foreign policy for Fiji, towards an anti-nuclear policy, within weeks he was deposed. The military junta there is developing at a rapid rate, which reminds one of Chile and other places.

The question of sovereignty also goes to the heart of Australian sovereignty. Until we understand our need for sovereignty; until we understand the issue of sovereignty in our own affairs; until we understand how we are not a sovereign nation-that we are an unofficial extra State of the United States of America, that our foreign policy is subject to American foreign policy and that our economic policy is subject to US economic policy-we will not understand sovereignty and we will not understand our denial of sovereignty to the Aboriginal people.

I need to spend some time talking about the Aboriginal people and sovereignty. We need to understand our original aggression in this country. When non-Aboriginal people first arrived in this country they brought smallpox with them in little bottles-or whatever it was in which it was carried. Within a year of the settlement of this country, in a period of two months, half the Aboriginal population between the Hawkesbury and Botany Bay died of smallpox. That was between April and May of 1789. There is a debate raging as to whether Noel Butlin's estimates of Aboriginal deaths are accurate and whether the smallpox was introduced deliberately or released accidentally. It seems to me that it does not really matter, in one sense, whether it was deliberate or accidental because half of the Aboriginal population died anyway. There is plenty of proof around to show how smallpox was used deliberately in North America and elsewhere to eliminate indigenous populations.

Once the smallpox did its job there were other diseases. These were followed by the gun. It was only in the 1920s that the last hunting parties stopped hunting Aboriginal people. It was in this century-within living memory-that Aboriginal children were dragged away from their parents and sent to boarding schools, to turn them into servants for the wealthy.

We have replaced the gun and disease with legislation and regulation. Legislation and regulation have taken over from war. I would like to quote Warren Snowdon, the honourable member for the Northern Territory, in his first speech in the other place. I might also mention Warren Snowdon's recent bereavement and offer my sympathy to him and his family. In his first address to the other place Warren Snowdon pointed out that the unemployment rate of Aboriginal people is six times the national rate. On average, an Aboriginal person earns only half the income of other Australians. Aboriginal life expectancy at birth is 20 years less than that for other Australians. The Aboriginal child mortality rate is three times higher than the national rate. Up to 36 per cent of Aboriginal children under 10 years of age in some areas suffer from trachoma, compared with 1.6 per cent of non-Aboriginal children. Many Aboriginal families live in substandard housing or temporary shelter. The imprisonment rate for Aborigines is over 20 times that for the total Australian population. The honourable member went on to point out that these shameful statistics mirror the lot of colonised peoples in the Third World.

But there are two glimmers of hope. When we look at the sad and sorry history of our treatment of the Aboriginal people, there are two things that come through. One is that the Aboriginal people have never surrendered their sovereignty-they have never stopped the struggle for their sovereignty. The struggle for sovereignty by the Aboriginal people has been going on for nearly 200 years and will continue until they achieve justice. It is a small hint of pride perhaps for some people that, since settlement, there have always been figures in our history, often fairly lonely and isolated, who, from a non-Aboriginal perspective, have pointed to the cruelties and injustice to the Aboriginal people. Non-Aboriginal support for justice for Aboriginal people is not an invention of the current generation. It is a long-standing tradition, albeit within a small section of the community.

On the question of Australian sovereignty-and here we get down to tin tacks-we need to liberate our own country, to win our own sovereignty, by closing foreign bases in this country. These foreign bases are symbolic of the fact that we do not defend ourselves; we defend a foreign country. The whole debacle over Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, in which we have privatised coastal surveillance, shows that we are not even able to guard and watch our own borders-our own coastline-yet we have sophisticated bases in this country from which we can spy on our neighbours and on Europe and which have the means of launching the first strike anywhere on the globe. Yet we have to contract out our coastal surveillance to private enterprise. Perhaps we could contract out the naval functions to the Royal Sydney Motor Yacht Club at some stage.

I now refer to the demonstrations at Pine Gap and at Richmond. Six hundred people demonstrated at Richmond to object to foreign bases on our soil. These people signed a petition which we wanted to present to the commander of the Richmond Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base but no one at the base would accept it. Therefore, I seek leave to table the document entitled `Statement of Concern' relating to the Richmond RAAF base.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
STATEMENT OF CONCERN
October 18, 1987
We, the undersigned citizens of New South Wales, express our opposition to the presence of the US Airforce Military Air Command in Richmond RAAF Base.
We strongly object to the US Starlifter Aircraft using Richmond RAAF Base to ferry supplies to US Bases at Pine Gap, North West Cape and Nurrungar.
These US Bases endanger the security of Australia and implicate us in preparations for nuclear war which threatens the entire planet. We call for the closure of these bases.
We petition the Richmond RAAF Command to convey to the Federal Government our opposition to this US military presence in Australia.
(Signed by 600 citizens)

TALK.START.PARA: —After we have removed foreign bases from Australian soil, we also need to look at the question of removing foreign nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships from our waters. I belong to a group called Paddlers for Peace. When nuclear armed warships come into Sydney Harbour we go out in kayaks and protest against the presence of nuclear weapons in our harbours. Those death ships remind me of the First Fleet-with its little glass cylinders of death which killed off half the Aboriginal population. They are, in a way, analogous to the cylinders of deaths on these current warships. Whether by accident or design, half the population-at least-between here and the Hawkesbury would die.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing we need to do in this country is to end the mining and export of uranium. Uranium fuels the arms race and we need to stop the trade in death. In our quest for sovereignty as a nation we perhaps can learn a great deal from the Aboriginal people about cultural identity and cultural autonomy in the face of great persecution and oppression.

Today is International Children's Day. It is an appropriate day on which to talk about the alienation of youth. In my other life, before I came to this place, I was a youth worker. The scene for young people in this country is a pretty sad one. I cannot get out of my mind pictures of young people who have died in alleyways, in public toilets, in the depths of seedy bars-real people whom I knew. Homelessness among young people is of great concern. The sorts of shelters they use are on the beach of Manly, underneath the skateboard rink and in stormwater tunnels-today, in 1987. These young people are homeless and alienated. Yet soon we will be moving into a $1.1 billion mansion up on the hill where, some honourable senators have complained, the seating and desks in the new Senate chamber are of a lesser quality than those we enjoy currently.

Before I came into the chamber I was handed a message which said that the Nuclear Disarmament Party's flag is flying from a base camp in the Himalayas. Two young members of an Australian ascent, on the third highest mountain in the world, have symbolised the NDP's highest aspirations for a nuclear-free future for everyone.

The young people of this country are the most informed and aware generation this country has ever seen. When I go around the place and talk to young people I find the depth of their knowledge and understanding remarkable. Yet at every stage young people are subject to relentless supervision, constant criticism and alienation from the processes which control their lives. It is about time young people were invited back into the fold.

I would like to use the analogy of a log-jam to explain why my concern for all of these issues of social justice is subsumed in the nuclear disarmament issue. In the countries where there are big rivers and their logs are transported by being thrown into the river and by being sent down the river, there are very often log-jams. There are massive pile-ups of logs. The way to remove a log-jam is to find the key log. Usually one log is the first to get caught. By various means the key log is released and the log-jam sorts itself out. That is the case with nuclear disarmament. All the other issues of sovereignty, injustice, exploitation and oppression will never be addressed while we maintain a global nuclear war fighting capability. While ever there are nuclear weapons there will need to be the political oppression and economic exploitation necessary to produce them and maintain them.

I have a vision for the Bicentennial. I see the Bicentennial as a time when, rather than celebrate a manufactured history put together in some public relations sweat shop and sold to us the way they sell margarine and jeans, there should be a true reappraisal of Australian history so that we can move on from there. The year 1988 can be the time when we reclaim our sovereignty and get rid of the bases, give Aboriginal people back their sovereignty and enter into a partnership with them to care for this continent, to welcome young people back into our society, to protect, maintain and begin to heal the environment that we have destroyed and, perhaps, to implement the sort of sustainable economy outlined by Senator Coulter.

I close by using a phrase from the greens. I am indebted to the greens-the Nuclear Disarmament Party is indebted to the greens-who have shown the way in Germany and whose `green' thinking has been an inspiration to me. The Nuclear Disarmament Party seeks to preserve and promote liberty and to defend and renew the ecology through the means of nuclear disarmament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Calvert I remind honourable senators that it is his maiden speech. I ask that he be extended the usual courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the many new senators elected to the Senate who are taking the opportunity of speaking for the first time-I am the last senator to do so-it is with some relief that finally I get a chance to congratulate you, Mr President, on your election. My congratulations also go to Senator Hamer on his election as Deputy President. I also congratulate the two previous speakers, Senator Patterson and Senator Wood, on their very sincere and different maiden speeches. My congratulations go to all the new senators. I know that they will represent their States with honour and with pride.

SPEECH.PARA: Honour and pride are very widely used terms, but on this occasion I say that it is an honour to serve in this place. I am very proud to represent my State and the people in it. I hope that I can be worthy of the support given to me by the Liberal Party of Australia and its officers and supporters in Tasmania, my small but enthusiastic band of workers who helped me and, most importantly, my wife and family who have been so understanding and patient. There is no doubt, as other senators have said, that the support of one's wife and family is so important. I appreciate them very much. Therefore, I take this opportunity of expressing publicly my gratitude to my wife Jill and to my children, Anna, Kate, Belinda and William. The help and courtesy shown by my colleagues and the wonderful assistance given by all the worthy officers who have served the Senate so unselfishly and well have made the task at hand so much easier.

For those honourable senators who may be curious as to my background I will give a brief resume. Surprisingly enough, my background is very similar to the backgrounds of other senators, on both sides of the chamber, who have rural backgrounds and who have been influenced by local government. After leaving school I worked for my father and his partner on a mixed farm, principally engaged in orcharding. And being a true blue Tasmanian like my colleague in the other place, I can truthfully say that I have had first-hand experience with apples. Due to the rationalisation of the industry I felt that it was time to move on and so became a wool grower. My wife and I purchased a property close to Hobart where, for many years, we have experienced the many vagaries of rural living.

My interest in agriculture led me to become involved initially in rural youth and then with our local farming organisation. I have also had an active interest in the Royal Agricultural Society of Tasmania, currently having the honour of being its President and part time lion tamer. As some honourable senators may have experienced, frustration with government at various levels can galvanise one into action. Some 12 years ago, when I was president of our local farming organisation and experiencing problems with our local council, I found that the best way to beat them was to join them. It was during this time in local government that I began to gain considerable satisfaction from being able to help one's fellow human beings and being able to witness the satisfying results of such efforts.

During my term as Warden-let me explain for those who may not understand our sometimes quaint Tasmanian terms that my municipality was not a gaol, nor a church or a game reserve, but an area covering some 254 square kilometres and containing 48,000 people-I performed a similar role to that of mayor or shire president in some of our mainland centres. My home, the municipality of Clarence, is a thriving, mainly residential suburb of Hobart that is developing an industrial base and has many beaches. Clarence possesses much natural beauty and is an area that I hope will become a city in the not too distant future. As an example of its recent development, Clarence now contains the Hobart International Airport and the headquarters for cricket in Tasmania and is the proud home of two honourable senators and one member of the House of Representatives, which further confirms the desirable lifestyle advantage which Clarence enjoys.

As previously stated, being warden of a thriving municipality is not just so much hard work, but is an excellent opportunity to serve. It is for that reason that I come to this place: to serve-to serve the Senate and to represent my electors of Tasmania in the very best way I can. Mr President, make no mistake: I am a very proud Tasmanian. I am well aware of those very eminent senators from my State who have represented us from all sides of politics with such distinction and loyalty. In particular, I refer to my predecessor, Michael Townley, who represented my State so well for 17 years and whose contribution will be missed by many in this chamber. It is appropriate that I thank him on behalf of all Tasmanians and I wish him well in his chosen future.

I am also aware of how diligently all Tasmanian representatives have had to work to protect and assist our rather isolated island. Unfortunately, we seem to be forgotten at times and, with great shame, there have even been instances when Tasmania has been left off the map. But you can be assured, Mr President, that I, along with my colleagues in the Liberal Party of Australia, will let this Government know where Tasmania is and we will fight for our rights at all times.

Tasmania has a physical barrier which has created and will continue to create constraints on economic development and tourism. I refer, of course, to Bass Strait, that great stretch of often unforgiving sea which divides us from our fellow States. There are some who would say that it is an advantage as it keeps the invaders from the big island at bay and also that it allows us to maintain a lifestyle that is not interfered with to any great degree. But, if we are to continue the vital economic development of my State, the numerous problems of Bass Strait must be faced, particularly with the effects that severe cutbacks from the current Federal Government have had on our economy. Because of our small industrial and population base compared with the larger States, our economy is a fragile one. Every cutback in financial government support affects us severely, whereas in the larger States the effect is not so great. The current funding cuts of some $270m, and the constraints put upon our Premier to achieve a balanced Budget, have placed severe hardship on many of my fellow Tasmanians. For example, to drive around our State and see petrol at up to 67c per litre, to have the dubious privilege of having the most expensive cigarettes in Australia and to see pockets of unemployment of 40 per cent in some areas is of great concern to me. As chairman of a community youth support scheme for some five years, I am well aware of the lack of purpose and the loss of pride that unemployment brings to all people, particularly the young.

I have heard Tasmania referred to in this place very recently as a mendicant State. But, as the second oldest State of this Commonwealth, it has always played a vital role, beginning in the early 1800s, when Tasmania supplied grain to the starving colony of New South Wales. No doubt, if the occasion arose, we would do it again. I am not asking for handouts but make the point that we in Tasmania have unique problems which require special consideration by those in government. I sincerely hope that our nation's decision-makers will continue to support freight equalisation, as other governments have, which has at least enabled us in part to compete on a fairer basis with the rest of Australia and which is so vital to safeguard the employment of so many Tasmanians.

Let me explain to the Senate a number of innovative ways in which Tasmania, because of its enforced independence, is encouraging Tasmanians to develop new techniques for old industries and also new ventures of an exciting nature which will boost our local economy and provide the catalyst for further economic growth. Tasmania is a most beautiful island, and it is not surprising that much of the impetus for this development is coming from the rich resources which abound in the waters of our coastline. Abalone is a large export earner for Tasmania and this popular fish, particularly in Japan, is a valuable $50m a year industry which is constantly being monitored, with restrictions on catches and licences, to ensure this resource is maintained.

Tasmanians have learned from the scallop industry, where the over-exploitation of beds, the use of unsuitable dredges and the intrusion of outside fishermen has meant the decimation of a once very lucrative industry. Recent investigations by scientists from the Division of Fisheries Research in Tasmania of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) have resulted in minimal numbers of small scallops being found during monthly cruises of the Bass Strait area. This confirms industry expectations that the 1987 season is likely to be a poor one. The CSIRO has been involved in scallop research in Bass Strait since mid-1985 and its efforts in providing scientific assistance to aid in the management of this industry are to be commended. Hopefully, the efforts of the Government and the fishermen, along with the reseeding of the beds, will help this industry to recover. There are currently two leases being used to experiment with the farming of scallops, as occurs in Japan, and, hopefully, these will be successful.

Significant advances have been made in trawling and long-lining. Just recently a new $2m fish processing plant was opened at Beauty Point near Launceston. This complements the large fish meal plant at Triabunna, which takes advantage of the large catches of jack mackerel. Another significant plant is planned for the Huon Valley.

But it is the relatively new and regenerating fish farming industry that I believe has a great future for Tasmania. For example, we have developed a very lucrative oyster industry in a relatively short time. Last year we had 72 oyster leases, which produced some 700,000 dozen oysters worth $2m. This industry has developed because of the initiatives and determination of a few dedicated oyster farmers, with the assistance of State and Commonwealth authorities. Because of the abundance of natural food, pollution-free waters and vast areas of sheltered waterways, this industry has an assured future. Tasmanian oysters have gained wide recognition for quality and are earning important export dollars for Australia. I am sure most oyster eaters in this place have had the delight of eating oysters from Tasmania in our dining room.

Development of the salt-water salmonid farming industry in Tasmania is perhaps the most exciting new industry seen in the State for some years. It represents the high point of 12 years of applied aquaculture research into shellfish and finfish by both government and private industry interests, and will place Tasmania at the forefront in the production of Australian gourmet seafoods. Between 1984 and the 1990s the sea-water cultivation of rainbow trout on five farms will produce some 2,500 tonnes of fish per annum. It is also confidently predicted that the farming of Atlantic salmon will produce 3,000 tonnes per annum by 1989-90. The marine salmonid industry envisages employing 400 people full time by 1990, with a value of $75m to the economy. This will be almost equal to the whole of the fishing industry in our State at present.

Other lucrative fish farming enterprises include the mussel industry, which is currently using 21 leases around the State, and a very new export industry using local and Japanese expertise-the harvesting and culture of sea urchins. By international standards, individually these industries do not appear very significant but, collectively, some 140 leases employing hundreds of people and with an earning potential of many millions of dollars give us a great deal of encouragement for the future. With relatively pollution-free waters we have unlimited potential. I noted yesterday that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who represents the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in the Senate, incorporated in Hansard a second reading speech about fisheries which states:
Exports of fishery products have increased from $230m in 1980-81 to an estimated $591m in 1986-87 and have significantly exceeded the value of imports each year during that period.
It went on to state:

Estimated annual per capita consumption has risen from 6.2 kilograms in 1979-80 to 7.5 kilograms in 1984-85, measured as edible weight. These figures give a general picture of a vigorous fishing industry which is making a very important contribution to the domestic economy and food supplies as well as to foreign exchange earnings.

It does seem that in a very short time Tasmanian fisheries will be earning a great part of that amount. A concern that I have about our new aquaculture industry is the possibility of conflict between uninformed pressure groups and the industry as a whole. Because of the perceived intrusion of some of these leases into areas which have been seen by some to be traditional recreation and wildlife areas, there is always the risk that individuals or groups will protest in the name of conservation. It was pleasing to note a few days ago that the Tasmanian Government placed a freeze on new leases for 12 months to allow an assessment of the effect that this new industry is having on our environment. It is another example of the Tasmanian Government's rational approach to conservation. The emerging aquaculture industry, or any other new industry, can ill-afford the interference experienced by our traditional industries over the last few years. There are groups of people in our community who have influenced the environmental issues of our State in a very responsible way. Certainly the efforts of most of our major industries to accede to the concerns of these people have had favourable acceptance. On the other hand, pressure groups and individuals purporting to be helping the State have caused disruption and divisiveness that has been highlighted by the media from time to time.

It is appropriate just to pay tribute to the authorities and individuals within Tasmania who are making such a significant contribution to the scientific, economic and technical research which is so vital to the provision of sound fisheries management practices. Such work is not only assisting in the development of new fisheries and fishing methods but also providing previously unavailable information and training. As examples of Tasmania's involvement I am aware that, through the Fisheries Industries Research Trust Account, the Department of Sea Fisheries is to receive $170,000 to conduct an assessment of orange roughy resources off the coast of Tasmania. The Department of Agricultural Science of the University of Tasmania is to receive $30,500 to study the effects of environmental factors on microbial growth in prepared seafood products and the prediction on shelf-life safety and the CSIRO is to receive $53,500 to provide a technical consultancy service for the Australian seafood industry. These studies are to be augmented by Tasmanian-based studies on bluefin tuna, sea urchins and the aging of marine mammals.

Tasmania, in its drive for financial independence, has not confined development to aquaculture. The wool industry remains prominent and, more recently, angora wool has been making its mark on world markets. Tasmanian cheeses, produced on the north-west coast and King Island, have also won international acclaim for excellent quality.

One of Tasmania's newest industries, essential oils, which include lavender, peppermint, fennel and parsley, is expected to be worth more than $700,000 to Tasmanians this year. In the future, when operating at full capacity, this industry is expected to realise more than $6m per annum. Industries are being encouraged to move their operations to Tasmania. Recently, construction began on a frozen food plant at Burnie, which is expected to employ more than 100 people on Tasmania's north-west coast. Smaller industries are also thriving with Tasmanian wines, produced at vineyards in the east and north-east, being sold at premium prices. I believe that they have been sold at premium prices on the mainland as well.

The year 1986-87 saw Tasmania's exports exceed $1 billion for the first time and that has confirmed Tasmania's reputation as the most export conscious State. I am proud to say that, on a per capita basis, Tasmanians export goods worth 20 per cent more than the national average. Export earnings per capita for private sector employed persons in Tasmania amount to $8,238 compared with $6,762 for mainland Australia, clearly highlighting Tasmania's disproportionate contribution to Australia's export earnings.

Tasmania is constantly striving to pay its way in our Commonwealth. It is a very hard-working State and I am pleased to be able to give my fellow senators an outline of some of the current developments in my State. I would like to assure all present here tonight that I will be using my position to protect Tasmania's interests and its people. Just today I took note of an article in our local paper about the first review to be conducted since Sir Bede Callaghan's 1977 report on the structure of industry and employment in our State. The report states:
The review also predicted a startling 3.4 per cent increase in economic growth between now and 1990 . . .
The report goes on:

The economic growth figures are sure to be hotly contested, with CREA estimating a 3.4 per cent increase in annual gross domestic product. Only Queensland and Tasmania exceed the 2.8 per cent growth rate forecast for the entire country.
It is rather interesting to note that the two non-Labor States are predicted to produce far in excess of the other States.

I come now to a subject which I have experienced at first hand for the past 12 years. I refer to local government. Local government is a resource in our nation that is being underutilised, particularly in the field of community services. Nationally, local government spends in excess of $1 billion annually on the provision of human services, which represents one-quarter of its expenditure. The creation of separate departments for human services has expanded the professionalism of its role. Local government acts as a catalyst for mobilising the community and its services. It provides the resources whereby a community is able to provide much needed services, be it through the provision of land, access to equipment or administrative support. It provides developmental assistance and, importantly, it provides a planning framework to assist in bringing together providers within the local government area. These are roles which cannot be underestimated and I believe that, in many cases, local government has the ability to be able to deal with urgent social problems without the large bureaucracy which so often gobbles up so much of the funds made available.

With local government supervising the allocation of funds and providing the necessary expertise, more money would be available on the ground. For too long the man and woman in the street have been controlled from Canberra in matters that could so effectively be handled at a local level. I see the expansion of local government in the area of community services as being just another practical step in assisting the real needs of people in areas such as the elderly, youth unemployment, child care and recreation. The capacity for local government to become involved in these areas and take on programs has, to some extent, been hamstrung by the fear of being left to carry the baby if State and Federal funds are reduced or withdrawn. I see a need, therefore, to monitor policy development, resource allocation and program administration to ensure that local government can expand its role. Further, a consistent financial approach is required to ensure that local government is equipped with the necessary funding to enable it to operate effectively in the human services area. We must be prepared to lessen central control with a view to fostering community development. This will enable local government to take an active role in general community services and develop its responsibilities as the third sphere of government.

In conclusion, we as a Senate will be facing many challenges during the life of the Parliament and beyond. Not the least of these will be attempts to transform the role of this House as a House of review to an insignificant rubber stamp for the government of the day. The people of Australia have much to thank the Senate for, as was recently shown with the identity card legislation. I pledge myself to upholding the traditions of this most honoured place and fighting to retain the very important position the Senate holds in the parliamentary system of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following words be added to the Address-in-Reply:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government's declaration in the Governor-General's Opening Speech that it will seek to further Australia's ANZUS alliance with the United States-
(a) is inconsistent with its stated aim in the same speech of working towards arms control and disarmament measures, and
(b) is not in the best interests of the Australian people in that it does not promote an independent foreign policy free of alliances with any powers in possession of nuclear weapons''.

I intend to speak briefly to the amendment. I believe that an alliance with the United States of America is an immoral millstone around our collective necks. It is time that Australia sought an independent stand, free of encumbrance with a nuclear nation. As we approach the somewhat embarrassing bicentenary of European settlement in this country, I think it is an appropriate time to reflect on the future direction of this country. What kind of foreign policy do we intend this country to have? What kind of country do we intend to leave to our children and to their children? We must think not only of the past, as we address the issue of the bicentenary. We are part of the past, but we are also part of the future. I think we have a moral obligation to think of the future and of what kind of country we want this to be in the next 200 years, should we be lucky enough to be around for that sort of time.

We need to look at the ANZUS Treaty alliance as it was when it was formulated in 1951. I can understand some support for the alliance when it was formulated in that time, but it is irrelevant now, it is outmoded now and it is dangerous now-for Australia and for the world. It is very different now in its operation from its intended status in 1951. It was very loosely worded, on purpose in my opinion, by the United States because it did not want to tie itself into having to defend Australian interests in this part of the world. What it has become since 1951 has evolved by a whole series of secret agreements worked out between the Australian Government and the United States Government.

The original document, which fits on to one A4 sheet of paper, never mentioned anything about foreign bases on Australian soil and never mentioned any obligation to host the visits of nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships to our ports. Those things have all emerged and are very different from the Treaty formulated in 1951. In 1951, when the Treaty was signed, it was part of a tripartite series of agreements that the United States formed with Japan, with the Philippines and with Australia and New Zealand. So in that time the United States very effectively shored up its interests in the western Pacific.

All that the ANZUS Treaty commits the alliance partners to is a meeting once a year. It was the United States which in 1985 reneged on its agreement by refusing to meet with one of its alliance partners, that is, New Zealand, when New Zealand had the guts to challenge the United States' nuclear component of the agreement which had sprung up by a series of secret agreements. New Zealand challenged the United States and said that the ANZUS Treaty did not oblige New Zealand to host nuclear warships in New Zealand ports. The New Zealand Government, on behalf of the New Zealand people, said very clearly: `We do not need to be defended by nuclear weapons. We do not intend to be defended by nuclear weapons and we do not want nuclear weapons coming into our ports'. The New Zealand Government had every right, within the terms of the ANZUS Treaty, to make such a declaration. It was the United States which reneged on its agreement and on its responsibilities to meet annually with the alliance partners.

The bases in Australia which contribute to the nuclear war fighting strategies of the United States against the Soviet Union have come about by these secret agreements. They have never been discussed by the Australian people, nor even by the Australian Parliament. They were placed here at the invitation of the Menzies Government, worried-quite rightly-that the ANZUS Treaty did not commit the United States to come to Australia's aid in time of crisis. That Government decided that the United States needed a vested interest in this area and needed bases to be placed on Australian soil to ensure that, if Australia did get into difficulty, the United States would have some reason for coming to our aid. These bases contribute substantially to the nuclear war fighting strategies of the United States in opposition to the Soviet Union.

I do not intend to be misrepresented in this place, so I will not suggest that by cutting the alliance ties with the United States we should become a lackey of the Soviet Union. Far from it; we should have no alliances whatsoever with any nuclear states. We should not be contributing to doing the dirty work for one of the nuclear super-powers in its tracking and targeting operations against the other. We should not be used in this way. Our Government has invited the bases to be placed on Australian soil, and successive Australian governments have allowed Australia to be used and abused by one super-power tracking and targeting the Soviets.

I am not an apologist for the Soviet Union, and I think that we should not be involved in any alliance with any nuclear super-power whatsoever. I deplore the Soviet aggression in Afghanistan, for example, and I deplore the increasing Soviet presence in the Pacific Ocean. I deplore the existence of the base at Cam Ranh Bay. But I deplore even more our Government's involvement with the other super-power which is engaged in a very destabilising situation against the Soviet Union. We have no business being involved with this super-power rivalry, on either side. It is a moral stand that Australia should be taking. Australia should be involved in seeking peace, not in contributing to the nuclear war fighting strategies of one super-power. We are doing everything that the United States wants, short of having nuclear weapons stationed permanently on Australian soil. We are doing everything possible to contribute to the nuclear war fighting capabilities of the United States. We are the eyes and the ears of the United States nuclear war fighting capabilities. I believe that that is an immoral position. I believe that Australia should be looking towards an independent and self-reliant defence capability.

It is time that the peace movement in Australia presented an alternative security strategy in very positive terms, and that we stopped saying only `no bases, no warships and no uranium mining'. The peace movement is addressing the issue of alternative security. It is most important that we do that.

Before I talk further about alternative security very briefly, I want to mention the ridiculous statements that we are meant to accept as the functions of the bases on Australian soil, as enunciated by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 6 June 1984. The Australian people are meant to be gullible enough to swallow that codswallop which the Prime Minister handed out to us. It told us nothing that was not generally known and, of course, it left unsaid many of the important things that need to be said about the role and function of the bases on Australian soil. To take just one example, Pine Gap has three functions, but the Government will only ever admit to one-the benign afterthought function of monitoring and verification. The arms control treaties that Pine Gap is meant to monitor and verify were not even in place when Pine Gap was established on Australian soil. It is an afterthought function to give credibility and respectability to the other two very sinister functions, one of which, being the ground satellite terminal for the Rhyolite, Magnum and Arcus satellite systems, is like a giant vacuum cleaner sucking up information from any points of the globe that the United States wants to spy on. It is a United States spy base. It collects the information and then sends it back to the United States without any control whatsoever by the Australian Government. That information is used for penetrating the weaknesses in the Soviet air defence radar systems so that effective targeting of Soviet installations can be made by the United States.

I submit to the Senate and to the people of Australia that that is an immoral function for a base on Australian soil and that Australia should not be involved in any way in the most immoral war fighting strategies known to humanity, that is, the possible indiscriminate use of nuclear weapons against millions of people. We do not want to be used in that way. It is high time that Australia took an independent road and carved out for itself an independent defence policy outside the framework of that debilitating and immoral alliance with the United States.

I believe that we should be working towards a system of transarmament, which is a gradual step by step removal of our dependence on and co-operation with the United States. We need to talk in terms of alternative security. Defensive defence would be a very good first measure. We should not have offensive weapons systems of any kind, because I believe that they produce extra tensions in the region. We should be reducing tensions instead of increasing them and we should be moving first to a situation of defensive defence. The report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the defence White Paper released earlier this year moved some way in that direction and they had very many important things to say. We should take up the good aspects of both the Dibb report and the defence White Paper as we argue for a defensive defence policy for this country and, ultimately, move towards a defensive system which is based on civilian non-violent defence. With such a system we would not make use of weapons systems of any kind, because the ultimate use of weapons systems is to kill other human beings. That is an immoral position.

For those reasons, and also because the presence of these bases on Australian soil and the frequent visits of nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships to our ports make nuclear targets out of us-something to which the Government now will admit-I believe that we should be rid of this alliance. How dare our Government make nuclear targets of Australian people to serve the interests of a foreign nation. And how dare the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) say that the bases are situated in relatively unpopulated areas. How does it make the people of Alice Springs feel to know that they are first strike targets in the event of a nuclear war? That is cold comfort indeed to them.

The statements made by Mr Hayden also need to be mentioned here. Mr Hayden keeps saying that if the bases on Australian soil have first strike capabilities we must review our commitment to them. Arguably, from next year the bases on Australian soil will have the capacity for the launching of a first strike attack on the Soviet Union on behalf of the United States. Whether that is the case or not, I believe that we should get rid of this alliance capability. Because nuclear weapons are designed for fighting nuclear wars, the very destabilising and provocative maritime strategy of the United States Navy puts us all at peril. Because the alliance makes a nuclear target out of us-but more importantly because the alliance makes us contribute to the nuclear war fighting strategies of one nation against another nation-I believe that Australia should have no part in it. I commend my amendment to the Senate.
