The speech read as follows:
LIVING TOGETHER: MORE THAN A BICENTENNIAL SLOGAN
You chose the title of tonight's seminar. I regard it as something of a challenge.

It suggests that living together, nationally speaking, is a real goal, an achievable reality. It suggests too that it is time to move the notion of living together from the arena of rhetoric and into action.
The celebration of 200 years of white settlement in this land provides us with just such an opportunity.
It is a convenient point in our history to look back since history, like life, can only be understood backwards, but must be lived forwards.
Over the past decade, the policies of multiculturalism have done much to help us take stock and to answer the question ``Who are we?''
What remains to be done is to ensure that all Australians know the answer.
I suggest to you tonight not only that this has not happened yet, but also that there is some urgency in seeing it happen. Without accurate knowledge of our past, we cannot build a just future.
Multiculturalism is an acknowledgment in public policy of what I suspect was always the case, namely that we are a diverse society, not a homogeneous one, and that there is strength in our diversity.

In order to understand multiculturalism, it is first necessary to understand what it is not. it is not assimilation-the policy it replaced. Indeed, in the interests of looking back to some effect, it is worth recalling the assimilationist view of Australia.

Once upon a time, there were two ideals: The typical Australian and the ideal immigrant. Between them was a continuum, along with which the traffic was one-way. If we stop for a moment to analyse the ideals, it soon becomes clear that the whole process is based on a fantasy, a stereotype, ``the typical Australian.''
Whenever I ask children to describe the typical Australian, to fire descriptions at me which I record on a board, this is what I get.
``Would bet on a raindrop rolling down a window pane.''
``Champions the underdog.''
``Loves beer. Drinks too much.''
``Has a beer gut.''
and so on . . .
It is usually not long before some witty kid asks ``Hey, what about the women?''
So, the stereotype is male, and, I hope you would agree, sorely restricted. Stereotypes always are.

To me this means that if we based an entire policy on a stereotype we were bound to get it wrong. And we did. The bottom line was that people generally, if erroneously, believed that the ideal migrant was he (and I say he advisedly) who turned into the typical Australian in the shortest possible time.

This view is erroneous precisely because it is based on a false view of culture as a replacement phenomenon. It is not. It is additive. You do not somehow stop being Greek and start being Australian, you become a Greek Australian. And all that qualifies you to be identified as an Australian. I was fascinated to read recently in Tamsin Donaldson's excellent book `Seeing the First Australians' that for about eighty years in the early colony, Aborigines were referred to as Australians; everyone else was a European. It is fascinating how we appropriated the word along with the land and how words move in to shore up the reality.
Within the concept of ``Australian'' there is scope for a host of other linguistic and social and cultural notions. This is simply fact. And the context for addressing such facts is multiculturalism.
So why, as many of its critics claim, has multiculturalism not been more effective in achieving its ends?

I believe it is because we have become confused between celebrating the outward signs of cultural difference on one hand and actually addressing the different ways in which different people achieve their goals on the other. There is nothing less equal than treating different people the same, just as there is no equality in treating similar individuals differently.
And so to multiculturalism itself. It is, as I have already suggested, more than the celebration of cultural differences, interesting though they may be.
Multiculturalism, as Laki Jayasuriya at the University of W.A. puts it, has two quite distinct levels; affective and instrumental.
The first is, if you like, multiculturalism of the heart, or rather of the liver, given its emphasis on singing, dancing and eating.

The second level is structural, the level at which we address structural barriers to participation in society. These include linguistic, social, economic and educational barriers. We have a great deal more to do at this level-in fact we have hardly begun to tackle the issue at the structural level.

I say this despite the fact that I am employed at the Anti-Discrimination Board. All too often, I see complaints conciliated but feel the victory may have been Pyrrhic. A minor anomaly has been adjusted, for one individual, but the system from which it arises remains intact. The obstacle course remains unaltered, waiting for the next contestant . . .
Tonight also offers an opportunity to examine the social significance of practices and policies as they affect a multicultural Australia, both in the workplace and the wider society.

As soon as we add the notion of multiculturalism, our worldview shifts. May I give you an example from my childhood. I think it will assist us in understanding how crucial it is to include this worldview in the education system in Australia.
I will quote from a story I wrote about one of my earliest memories of school:

``The songs were unfamiliar, too. No one at my place sang the nursery rhymes that everyone else seemed to know, and I felt a bit of a goose. The stories, too-everyone but me knew just when to laugh. I never could see anything funny about a poor fox falling into prickly briars: everyone in my world told whispered stories of escape and flight. We children soon learned how precarious life could be, how fortuitous survival was, and took no pleasure in seeing pictures of the poor fox trapped and beaten.

But most strange of all, I just couldn't seem to reconcile the stories I knew of how we made it over here in tales of ``our forbears'' in their sailing vessels. The settlement of Australia, in my estimation, was a pretty recent and continuing phenomenon. My teachers always seemed to imply it was all over ages ago. In short, my sense of history and theirs were irreconcilably different. I remember wondering who was lying . . . We now know nobody was lying, at least not deliberately. But even today, there are those who propagate the mythology of the settlement of Australia as if it was fact. I need hardly say in this context how damaging it must be to Aborigines that we continue to portray this land as settled rather than conquered, as ``terra nullus'', such that British law could be established without acknowledgement of the presence of the indigenous people, and with what disastrous consequences this was both achieved and perpetuated.''

Unless in our schools, after the 1988 Bicentennial, we teach history and not mythology, the general population will have no basis for understanding an increasingly complex society except at the simplest level of conventional wisdom.

It is always amusing to speculate that conventional wisdom is a contradiction in terms. Yet, in Australia, conventional wisdom has it that this was a largely empty land which Britain quietly settled without much opposition. That the Aborigines, being nomadic, had no real attachment to any one place, and obligingly moved on wherever white settlement spread. That murder and betrayal, pitched battles and guerilla warfare are the stuff of cowboys and Indians, not the British and the Aborigines. The facts, as they are now emerging, are incontrovertible: the picture, the mythology is fallacious. It both reflects past injustice and perpetuates it in the present. It has a trapping affect on Aboriginal people, but at the same time, holds back the entire community. Because, as Martin Luther King Jr said, injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.

As with Aboriginal Australia, our view of ourselves as a society of immigrants is schizophrenic. It is at once asserted and denied, promoted and suppressed. Generations of Australians have been expected to assimilate, though with whom remains a moot point. A favorite cartoon of mine depicts a sailing vessel on whose side are the words ``Second Fleet.'' Six sorry-looking men are rowing away from it, while in the prow sits a seventh, arms folded, saying, ``Row you pommie bastards, row.''

The law of prior arrival, it seems, has always been the buttress of power. That ``they'' are not like ``us'' has for generations underpinned the power relationships inherent in migration to Australia. Whether this has been reflected in the labour market or the suburban mix, it is true to say that successive groups have replaced one another at the bottom the heap, with a concomitant slow dispersal in the ranks higher up.

Few now know that Australia made a historic decision in the period after World War II to import labour in the form of a planned migration program. Few realise that in those days of ``pull migration'' Australia actively recruited migrants overseas, competing with other nations for new settlers. When it suited us, we gave preference to childless couples so that two adults could take up two jobs immediately. At other times, for other economic reasons, preference was given to immigrants with families. When labourers were needed, the male immigrant's passport was stamped labourer, whatever skills be offered. No such stamp needed to be applied to the passports of females. For them, the immigrant women, the destination was, as the 1975 Jackson Committee Report on manufacturing industry put it, the dirtiest, most menial, most repetitious jobs available.

The situation is now reversed. We are experiencing ``push migration'' and conventional wisdom, myopic as always, restricted to the most recent of pasts, makes the unwarranted assumption that it was always so. Forgetting the immigrants who were promised second generation mobility in return for first generation deprivation, it calls on all of them to be grateful for what we in our magnanimity have accorded. Critics conveniently forget that migrants helped to build Australia and its institutions and multiculturalism is derided as a divisive force. A return to assimilationism is preached as the right way to approach contemporary problems. Here again, the mythology is deficient. It has never really incorporated the notion of ``differences'', just as our outback mythology failed to take account of the presence of women.

I am certain that it is possible to be a nation, and yet to acknowledge differences. When I recently saw that most American of soapies, Ellis Island, I knew it could be done . . . It accurately, if superficially, portrayed the American myth of nationhood, and gave due emphasis to the struggles of the Irish, the Eastern Europeans and other immigrants in the early 20th century to take their part in the democratic process. The final words that rose over the screen and over a final frozen frame, asserted that three in five Americans today are descended from an immigrant who entered through Ellis Island, which is now a museum of immigration.

We have a long way to go before such an assertion finds its way into the conventional wisdom here. And yet it is so. Millions of Australians are here as a result of a deliberate policy to augment the population 1% annually by means of immigration. People who have a right to be here and to have access to what their society offers.

Multiculturalism as a policy is belatedly taking stock of the fact that migration not only enriches our palates, our hearts and our livers, but is also about access. It must therefore address itself to questions of equity and hence to questions of structural discrimination, since the effects of certain kinds of policies are to keep particular groups from participating fully in the social, political, cultural and economic life of the community. In that sense we are talking not only about discrimination but also about racism.
It is painful and will continue to be so.
It is threatening, and will continue to threaten those historically in positions of power.
But it needs to be addressed in the pursuit of a just and cohesive society.
We tonight in this room, in all our public capacities, have a unique responsibility to promote understanding.
Understanding of the way our society works and why; and of whom it comprises and why.
Based on these insights, this knowledge, we can clearly see the 1990's and beyond, and plan and dream for the future.
A young Aboriginal colleague of mine once told me of his plans for the future. Then, to my surprise, he said, ``Now let me tell you my dreams.''
I remember being amazed that he saw a difference. But then I realised for many people in Australian society, what to me is a plan, for them is a dream.
I share with you tonight my hope that together we can harness those dreams, and help make them reality. That we can do it now.
If not now, when?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Mrs Kalowski has contributed a passionate defence of multiculturalism and the benefits which it has brought to Australia. It is a statement of faith and optimism and defence of immigration policy over the last 40 years. As we come towards the Bicentennial, the last thing we want now in Australia is a new divisive and vicious debate about immigration. This nation has been altered and enriched by the many people who have come here post-war. Those who were refugees and new arrivals 30 or 40 years ago now have to be ready to accept today's refugees and to accept those seeking a new home here in Australia. We are a better nation. Joanna Kalowski has added to our understanding of multiculturalism. I am grateful to the Senate for allowing me to incorporate her very fine words.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
